REFLECTIVE SILVER LOVE AND JUSTICE!

FULL STORY

Posted by Shaun
Last Updated:

The full story of Reflective Silver Love and Justice!. This story was run from December 15th 2024 to July 12th 2025 and was originally posted on the Clockworksun Stories Discord server.
This story is 93 updates long, plus an epilogue, spread over 347 standard pages with a total of over 105k words.
Note that some reaction counts may not be exact, as voters may have changed their reactions between the close of voting and the time this story was scraped from the server.
Mxblah 12/9/2024 6:23 PM
@Story Notifications Hello again; time for more writing! There are three prompts on the docket this time, so vote the one you want to see written out... or vote for two if you just don't like one of them. Or vote for three if you're an agent of chaos! I can't stop you! As usual, the prompts not chosen may come back later, be rewritten, or never be seen again. I'm also trying something different this time: usually, I put my thoughts about each prompt in #story_discussion, but I figured if I want you to read them, why not just put them in here right below the prompts themselves? So, I did that: Ô∏è [NOVELLA?] Evil and You: A 12 Step Guide to World Domination Action, Comedy? High fantasy OR Present day You‚Äôve always had big plans. Real big ones. Now that you‚Äôve got some superpowers, some minions, and a handy guidebook on how to be the best evil overlord you can be, it‚Äôs time to get going! Build a lair, defeat some heroes, and take over the world! ... Wait, why is the last step in this book ‚Äúbe defeated by the forces of justice?‚Äù Well, maybe you can work around that one. Blah's notes: When I think of Evil and You, my man Skeletor comes to mind. Perhaps Bowser? Dr Doof? Evil, yes, but in a more lighthearted way. Sure, the evil overlord will steal the weekly mcguffin or kidnap the princess or plan to conquer the tri-state area, but then they'll stop by for tea and go-karting the next weekend. The story will focus on the evil overlord and their relationship with their nemesis (or nemeses), along with an escalating series of wacky-but-definitely-evil plans. But of course, given who's writing this, it's entirely possibly the comedy will slip into tragedy at some point if the guide ever recommends it... And there's nothing scarier than a permanent goofball finally getting serious. But for the most part, expect cartoon-level villainy and hijinks. It'll be fun! --- ‚Äã
6:24 PM
[NOVEL?] Limit of a Legend Action / Relationships / Melancholy? High fantasy You are the hero of legend. You hold brilliant power to repel evil; no creature of darkness can stand up to you. Wherever you go, even in this bleak, war-torn world, hope follows. But... you can‚Äôt be everywhere. You can‚Äôt travel instantly, and you still must rest and sleep like any other person. You can‚Äôt hold back the overwhelming numbers of the horde on your own, and the enemy continues to encroach wherever you aren‚Äôt. It seems, this time, a hero might not be enough to save the world. Unless you and those directing the efforts to fight back can find a way. Blah's notes: The concept for Limit of a Legend came to be when I was thinking about stories where the main character is too powerful to be defeated. The obvious counters to such a character are to threaten those they care about who don't have such power, or challenge them in such a way that raw force cannot resolve the problem. So, in this story, the hero is basically invincible. Sure, they still have to sleep and could theoretically be killed, but assuming no catastrophic whoopsies, they aren't going to die. But they can't defend an entire kingdom on their own, no matter their powers. This story will focus on that dilemma, along with the hero's relationships with the royal family who they serve. Plus, there are wizards and golems in this one! It'll be fun! --- ‚Äã
6:24 PM
[NOVEL?] Reflective Silver Love and Justice! Superhero / Investigation? Present day / Near future Heroes are real. Whether you prefer to call them superheroes, mutants, wizards, magical girls; it doesn‚Äôt matter - they exist and they‚Äôre here to protect everyone from evil spirits with the powers of righteousness and justice. It‚Äôs been almost a decade since the first dark spirits appeared and only a little less time since the first heroes appeared to fight them. The status quo has mostly been established; for the average person, not a lot has changed aside from an uptick in supernatural encounters on the daily commute. But when you‚Äôre chosen to rise up as one of these defenders, you quickly realize things are a little more complicated than the general public knows. What do these ‚Äúangels‚Äù and ‚Äúdemons‚Äù really want? Where do they come from? Why do they clash in such a roundabout way, using humans as their champions? Perhaps most immediately pressing, though, is how you‚Äôre going to balance your regular life with your new demands as a hero. That one, you‚Äôll have to sort out right quick. Blah's notes: Reflective Silver Love and Justice! is the fourth iteration of a superhero / secret identity story that I've wanted to write for ages, but never got a concept together that I was happy with until now. It will follow an ensemble cast of rookie heroes and villains, each granted their powers by a spirit of either dark or light, as they clash and... make friends? Wait, you can't do that; you're supposed to be enemies! Dear, oh dear, what will the powers that be think of that? The bulk of the story will be developing their powers and relationships, trying to figure out what these celestial interlopers actually want (are they really angels and demons...?), and potentially even challenging the status quo and much more powerful supers. Plus, it's got transformation scenes! It'll be fun! (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 12/11/2024 6:41 PM
@Story Notifications Alright, time to prepare for some Reflective Silver Love and Justice! Let‚Äôs start by figuring out a few things about the setting. Due to the large number of characters and perspective switches, the story will use third person limited. How much is understood about how superpowers work? - Nearly nothing. Science is powerless to explain and the angels aren‚Äôt willing to say. - The basics make sense and outcomes can often be predicted with enough data. However, applying technology or physics usually goes poorly. - Superpowers are a field of scientific study and integrated with traditional research. Some universities even offer degrees. How involved is the government with supers? - Not much. Cops stay mostly out of the way and heroes tend to operate on a vigilante system. - Contractor-like. The cops may request heroes for tough cases, and will often be involved to some degree in clashes between supers. Ô∏è - Integrated. The federal government has a hero registry and a department to manage relations. Many of the most powerful heroes work directly for the government, though not all. How dangerous is being a hero? - Not too bad. Defense outpaces attack, so it‚Äôs hard to get seriously hurt or killed by villains. Ô∏è - It‚Äôs a tough job. Defense and attack are balanced. It‚Äôs unlikely you‚Äôll actually die, but being careless, unlucky, or just outmatched can put you out of action for days or weeks. - Dangerous. Attack outpaces defense, so it‚Äôs easy to be seriously injured by a single flubbed dodge. Only powerful or lucky heroes make it to retirement. (Winners: a tie between and - chosen by author discretion, a tie between and - the options will be blended by author discretion, Ô∏è ) (edited)

Mxblah 12/13/2024 7:00 PM
@Story Notifications A double-tie in the very first choice, huh? Well, that just means I get to pick. At least, for the two that aren‚Äôt about how much pain and suffering the characters get to go through, for which you selected the moderate choice. Probably for the best that didn‚Äôt win if we want to get to know these people. Anyway, speaking of people, let‚Äôs decide some things about the characters. How old is Brianna Whitman (aka Silver (aka the ‚Äúmain‚Äù protagonist (aka the ‚ÄúSilver‚Äù in Reflective Silver Love and Justice!))) when the story starts? - 17. A senior in high school and on track to graduate this year. Hopefully becoming a hero isn‚Äôt too distracting. - 18. In that awkward summer between high school and college. Becoming a hero will certainly spice that up. Who is the first other super that Silver meets? [Silver has the meta-power of narrative perspective; for the main cast, we can usually only ‚Äúbe‚Äù someone once she‚Äôs met them. (But don‚Äôt tell her that or she might get nervous.)] - ‚ÄúGranite.‚Äù A hero. A young man slightly older than Silver. Confident; chill. Will like her. - ‚ÄúViolet.‚Äù A villain. A young woman slightly younger than Silver. Energetic; definitely not chill. Will really like her. What do angels and demons look like to humans? - Humanoid. Halos, horns, that sort of thing. Like you would expect. - Humanoid, but also very small. For stealth, probably. ‚ôæÔ∏è - Abstract. Orbs, unclear sensations, biblically accurate whatevers. - Mascots. Cute; marketable. Probably squeak like plush toys if you squeeze them. (Winners: , , ) (edited)

Mxblah 12/15/2024 11:40 AM
@Story Notifications Reflective Silver Love and Justice!
11:40 AM
Scene 0 June 10th, 2028 For Brianna Whitman, it all started on a particular Saturday in June when an angel appeared in her room. ‚ÄúHello again,‚Äù he said in a calm, authoritative voice much louder and deeper than- ‚ÄúAAa-!‚Äù The angel was cut off by a scream that was itself cut off as Bria whirled around and saw who had just interrupted the silence of her formerly-quiet room. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt do that!‚Äù she hissed, getting up to close the door. ‚ÄúBrianna? Everything okay up there?‚Äù came a voice from downstairs. ‚ÄúY-yeah, mom. Just tripped and almost fell over.‚Äù ‚ÄúOkay; be careful.‚Äù She gestured at the door, lowering her voice again. ‚ÄúPlease just knock next time?‚Äù The angel hovered in place, tilting his head in seeming confusion. He resembled an animal, to an extent, though which one specifically Bria couldn‚Äôt say. Maybe a closer comparison was one of the cute collectible monsters in those video games that must have been designed by crossing an animal with a plush toy. In any case, it was the kind of body one would expect to have an adorable, high-pitched voice, but somehow the angel‚Äôs low tone sort of fit too. Anyway, none of that really mattered; the only thing truly important about the angel‚Äôs appearance was the color scheme of his... fur(?): pale pastels bordering on white. That meant he was definitely an angel; demons always had darker colors bordering on black. Everyone knew that. ‚ÄúMy apologies. I will make you aware of my presence in a gentler way next time.‚Äù Bria pushed her annoyance aside; it was very, very quickly replaced by excitement. ‚ÄúThanks. B-but, you really came back? I thought for sure it was just a dream last time!‚Äù The angel floated down lower, alighting on Bria‚Äôs desk and sauntering across her laptop‚Äôs keyboard. Not a single key so much as shifted; was he intangible or just really light? ‚ÄúIt was not. Have you given any thought to my previous offer?‚Äù This was it. He hadn‚Äôt been joking, or a dream. Calm down, Bria. ‚ÄúI have. A... a lot.‚Äù ‚Äã
11:40 AM
‚ÄúGood. It is a serious decision. So, have you arrived at an answer, prospective hero? Will you join forces with the angel Zeal and defend the world from the forces of darkness?‚Äù Zeal; that was his name. She had almost forgotten in all the- ‚ÄúYes!‚Äù Bria gasped. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll do it!‚Äù ‚ÄúYou will rise as a hero of light and dedicate yourself to the protection of those who cannot protect themselves?‚Äù ‚ÄúYes!‚Äù Zeal smiled, or at least that‚Äôs how Bria chose to interpret his expression. ‚ÄúThen place your hand down, right here, and let the contract be forged.‚Äù A sudden jolt of nervousness joined the excitement as Bria put her hand on the desk as instructed. No one really talked about this part of the process. But she couldn‚Äôt interrupt the moment now; not when she was really about to become a hero! ‚ÄúYou may experience some brief discomfort as your body is reformatted,‚Äù Zeal explained quickly as he pressed his hands (paws?) onto hers. ‚ÄúAny such sensations are temporary and should not cause concern.‚Äù ‚ÄúS-sorry, what did you - ‚Äòreformatted?‚Äô‚Äù Zeal said something in reply, but Bria was too distracted by the sight of her arm dissolving to pay attention. A wave of sparkly light quickly spread from the point of contact up her hand, then arm, then shoulder, then a horrible static-y, buzzy sensation as her vision and other senses dissolved too. Nothing but points of light. A starfield inside her head. Then it was over. Her body snapped back to full opacity, exactly the same as it was before. She stumbled back and half-fell to sit down on her bed, holding her head and blinking the stars out of her eyes. ‚ÄúYes, reformatted,‚Äù Zeal repeated, sitting down on her laptop - though again causing no effect on the computer. ‚ÄúYour physical body has been converted into a lattice of solid magic. The process brings an array of benefits, including increased resilience, heightened strength and agility, and of course, the ability to make use of the heroic abilities you will develop.‚Äù ‚Äã
11:40 AM
She stared at her palms, slowly lowering them. ‚ÄúL-lattice...? Of... magic?‚Äù ‚ÄúWorry not; your new body will function identically or better than the original in nearly every way. Now, are you ready to design your battle form?‚Äù ‚ÄúAh! Yes!‚Äù Bria quickly pushed aside the worries that she had maybe just been technically killed, letting her excitement return. Of course, she‚Äôd given this a lot of thought over the past week as well. Even though she had initially assumed his first visit had been a dream, there had always been that chance... ‚ÄúFirst, your transformation item. This is typically a small accessory or article of clothing that you must touch in order to transform. You will keep this on your person at all times, as without it, you will be vulnerable. And, though I can recreate your transformer with time should you lose it, you should still take care to keep it safe.‚Äù Bria knew all this, of course. Not the specific details, but every kid dreamed of becoming a hero; of receiving this very visit that she was now undergoing. Like most dreamers, she had believed it would never be her. As the years passed and she grew older, that hope diminished further. By her high school graduation, exactly one week ago as of today, she had decided it wouldn‚Äôt happen. Most people were normal, after all, and angels tended to select their heroes before her age. And yet, here she was. ‚ÄúI know what I want it to be; should I just tell you, or...?‚Äù ‚ÄúNo. Envision it.‚Äù Zeal raised his paws (hands?) and formed a blob of glowing magic between them. ‚ÄúDirect your thoughts here. Shape the item.‚Äù Without really knowing what exactly that meant, Bria just thought about it. Tried to keep the image in her head consistent, which thankfully wasn‚Äôt hard as it was a simple item. And, in only a few seconds, the blob collapsed down into a small metal hairclip - near identical to one in her bathroom right now, though heavier and... subtly magnetic when she picked it up? ‚Äã
11:41 AM
‚ÄúGood,‚Äù Zeal said. ‚ÄúThe item will attempt to stay with you unless purposefully removed, and if relatively nearby, you will have a vague sense of its location. Please wear it now.‚Äù She clipped it into her hair. It felt right. And up next was the most exciting part...! ‚ÄúNow, your battle form. It will reflect your innate affinities, the vision that lies within your heart, and your conscious interpretation of the concept. Envision it much as you just did your transformation item. Imagine the form as an overlay; let it lie atop your body. Then, when you are ready, touch the item with the intent to transform.‚Äù ‚ÄúOkay...‚Äù Bria certainly had plenty of outfits to take inspiration from. Famous heroes wore equally famous costumes; some of them you could even get at box stores for cosplay purposes or Halloween. But the outfit tended to match the powers, and Bria didn‚Äôt know what abilities she would have yet. But since Zeal was having her do this first, there must be a reason... She touched the hairclip and willed herself to transform. And, over just a few seconds as glimmering light streamed from the transformer to coat her body like a barrier, she did. Immediately, she ran for the mirror. Pale white hair (did it get longer too?) and pale blue eyes: quite a change from her normal black and dark blue. The hairclip had morphed into a pair of spiky, crystalline ornaments, one above each ear. A thin silver choker accented her neck above a sleeveless silver dress that felt like soft, comfortable fabric, but looked and moved like segments of reflective metal or crystal. A pair of silver bracelets fit snugly to her wrists and a pair of silver sandals fit snugly to her feet to complete the outfit. Not complicated, really, but certainly flashy. And, she had to admit, beautiful. Especially the dress; how did it look like that while feeling like this? ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs... really good,‚Äù she breathed, turning and moving to get a better look. ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs not at all like I was picturing.‚Äù ‚Äã
11:41 AM
‚ÄúYour heart must have had a different plan than your head,‚Äù Zeal declared. ‚ÄúBut it should reflect ‚Äòyou‚Äô regardless. Your battle form can change over time or with dramatic shifts in personality, but neither you nor I can directly modify its appearance. I am glad you find it pleasing already, as it is unlikely to change any time soon.‚Äù She did a little spin, admiring the way the skirt sent chips of reflected light dancing across the ceiling. ‚ÄúI really like it.‚Äù If she had one complaint, it might be that it was maybe just a little revealing, especially if she had to do a bunch of jumping around in battle? But it wasn‚Äôt that bad really and Zeal said that neither of them could change it anyway and honestly there were a lot of heroes who had dresses or skirts as part of their outfits so it probably wouldn‚Äôt be a big deal. Plus, just being in the form imparted a sense of confidence; energy. She could get used to it. Looking like this, she could be a hero. ‚ÄúNow, two last matters for the day. First, a warning. Your battle form includes a potent anti-recognition enchantment that prevents anyone from connecting it with your base form, no matter how obvious it might seem, unless they directly see you transforming. You are strongly advised to keep your true identity secret, so be careful when and where you transform.‚Äù ‚ÄúRight.‚Äù That made sense; aside from her outfit and the hair color change, she still looked essentially the same. Keeping a secret identity - presumably to ensure she and her family wouldn‚Äôt be harassed for her actions as a hero - would be very difficult without magic like that. ‚ÄúAnd I can transform back by... doing the same thing in reverse?‚Äù ‚ÄúEssentially, though you do not need to touch the transformation item to return. Simply envision the battle form‚Äôs overlay falling away from your base form, with the intent to change back. It should be simpler in this direction.‚Äù ‚Äã
11:41 AM
It was. With only a few seconds to focus, light flared across her body and Bria was back, along with her normal outfit. Suddenly, the warning about keeping a secret identity seemed somewhat more dire. The battle form really did change her mindset, at least a little. ‚ÄúGood. The last matter is that of your name. All hero aliases are based on colors or terms strongly associated with a color, for ease of registration and branding. It is advised to pick a term that matches your battle form, if possible.‚Äù Although the Bria in the mirror was just her regular self now, she could still clearly recall the shiny, reflective dress of her battle form. Really, only one word immediately came to mind. ‚ÄúCan I be ‚ÄòSilver‚Äô?‚Äù ‚ÄúThere are no conflicting registrations within the neighboring states. Congratulations, Silver, on your selection. I will return tomorrow morning to commence your training.‚Äù With that, he immediately leapt back into the air to hover, fading towards transparency. - ‚ÄúWait!‚Äù - Let him leave. Bria certainly has a lot to think about. [If Bria asks Zeal to wait, what does she say?] - ‚ÄúWhy did you choose me?‚Äù - ‚ÄúWhat kind of training?‚Äù - ‚Äú... Thank you. For choosing me.‚Äù ‚ùì - [Something else. Suggest in #story_discussion.] (Winners: , ) (edited)

Mxblah 12/17/2024 6:41 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 1 ‚ÄúW-wait!‚Äù Zeal paused in midair, returning to opacity. ‚ÄúYes?‚Äù ‚ÄúEr, what kind of training? Just so I can prepare a little?‚Äù ‚ÄúCombat training, of course,‚Äù he responded like it should be obvious. ‚ÄúYou are now responsible, in part, for the wellbeing of your community and there are many dark spirits to destroy. We will start developing your skills quickly.‚Äù ‚ÄúCombat training,‚Äù Bria repeated. ‚ÄúRight.‚Äù In fairness, it was obvious; that‚Äôs what heroes did. But without the confidence of just a few minutes ago, the idea of actually trying to fight something seemed a lot more farfetched. That‚Äôs what the training would help with, she supposed. ‚ÄúLike, magic powers and stuff?‚Äù ‚ÄúLater, yes. But initially, we will focus on intent. That and general defensive measures. Attacking will come afterwards, including physical and magical variations.‚Äù ‚ÄúIntent... so, what I want to do?‚Äù ‚ÄúIt seems you are intending to start your training early. While your zeal is appreciated, it is not yet the time; I must finish your registration before anything further can be accomplished. Please, await my return in the morning.‚Äù ‚ÄúRight. Okay, I‚Äôll wait.‚Äù ‚ÄúThen farewell for now.‚Äù Zeal faded into transparency and was gone. It was late. She should get ready for bed and prepare to wake up early tomor - wait, did she forget to ask him when he would come back? What if she overslept, or woke up too early and had to sit around for ages waiting? ‚Äú...‚Äù Who was she kidding? Bria knew perfectly well she wasn‚Äôt going to have much success in sleeping tonight either way. ... June 11th, 2028 ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre up early today,‚Äù Bria‚Äôs dad commented as she hurried downstairs, already dressed and ready for the day well before noon. On a weekend during summer break, no less! ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the occasion?‚Äù ‚Äã
6:41 PM
‚ÄúDad? You‚Äôre up... late?‚Äù she countered, poking through the cabinets for some breakfast ingredients. If today‚Äôs agenda included combat training, she probably needed some food. ‚ÄúShouldn‚Äôt you be at work by now?‚Äù ‚ÄúOuch; you want me out of here that badly?‚Äù ‚ÄúNo; I just thought you weren‚Äôt off today.‚Äù She looked back at him. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the occasion?‚Äù ‚ÄúOh, nothing special. I‚Äôve just got the evening shift today. Traded with a coworker who‚Äôs got a birthday party to attend this afternoon.‚Äù ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs nice of you.‚Äù Bria accidentally opened the fridge too fast, causing bottles in the door to rattle against each other. Funny; she had just done the same thing to the cabinet moments earlier. ‚ÄúNothing special here either; I‚Äôm just gonna meet up with Yasmin. She likes to get up early.‚Äù ‚ÄúIndustrious,‚Äù her dad commented. ‚ÄúWell, have fun. Don‚Äôt play on the tracks in about four hours or I‚Äôll have to scold you.‚Äù ‚ÄúGot it; I‚Äôll go be unsafe before then.‚Äù That was one of her dad‚Äôs standard semi-jokes. He worked as a conductor on the commuter rail, so if she got in trouble (or got hurt) obstructing his train it would certainly be very awkward for both of them. So far, she had kept a perfectly clean record; no rail-related crimes to report. A few minutes passed as her dad perused the (digital) newspaper and Bria kept accidentally splashing milk around with her spoon. That got annoying very fast; it seemed like her hands were just moving with more force than she was used to. It took a lot of restraint to not smack herself in the mouth or clink loudly against the cereal bowl. This has got to be a side effect of whatever happened to my body last night, right? she wondered. Maybe being ‚Äúmade of‚Äù magic makes me stronger even when I‚Äôm not in my battle form? That sort of made sense, and there wasn‚Äôt really anything else she could attribute the change to. She‚Äôd ask Zeal whenever he showed up. After cleaning up all the spilled milk (and not crying about it). ‚Äã
6:41 PM
Her dad didn‚Äôt comment on her poor eating performance, but he did bring up a different topic. ‚ÄúSay, have you given any more thought to where you‚Äôll be living in the fall?‚Äù ‚ÄúI thought I told you; first years have to stay in the dorms to get that scholarship. So, the dorms.‚Äù ‚ÄúWell, yes, but when you factor in how much money you would save by living at home instead, it‚Äôs basically the same. And your college is just a train ride away!‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs two train rides,‚Äù she corrected him; they had been over this before. ‚ÄúOr a train and a bus. Either way, it would take over an hour to get to campus compared to a minute. Plus, I kind of want to have... this sounds kind of lame, but a ‚Äòreal college experience,‚Äô you know? It‚Äôs not that I hate you guys or want to get away or anything. Plus, like you said, I‚Äôll only be a train ride away when I want to visit.‚Äù ‚ÄúTwo train rides,‚Äù he corrected her. ‚ÄúOr a train and a bus.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a real funny guy, dad.‚Äù Zeal showed up a little after breakfast, startling Bria again despite his promise by simply appearing in the middle of the hallway. He didn‚Äôt say anything this time, though, just waving in a floppy sort of way. ‚ÄúWhat are you doing?‚Äù she hissed, looking back towards the kitchen and trying to block the view. ‚ÄúMy dad will see you!‚Äù ‚ÄúHave no fear; I cannot be seen or heard by ordinary individuals unless I will it. Are you prepared to begin your training?‚Äù ‚ÄúHe can still hear me if I talk to you, though! Can we go outside first?‚Äù ‚ÄúSo you are prepared. Excellent; let us depart.‚Äù After navigating the kitchen again and saying goodbye to her parents (mom had come down not long ago), Bria left the house. Zeal seemed to have a destination in mind, so she followed him as he floated in front of her. Talking into thin air, or at least that‚Äôs how she would look to any passersby. Maybe if she put in some earbuds and pretended to be on the phone? ‚ÄúWill this time work in the future or do you have other engagements?‚Äù he started by asking. ‚Äã
6:41 PM
‚ÄúWell-‚Äù Does Bria have a summer job? Ô∏è - Nope! Free all day, every day. - Yep! [Specify below, or in #story_discussion.] If she has a job, it is... - Something food service-y. - Something retail-y. - Something teaching-y. - Something outdoors-y. - Something office-y. ‚ùì - Something else...y? [Currently set as "something library-y" based on discussion.] (Winners: , ‚ùì ) (edited)

Mxblah 12/19/2024 9:20 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 2 ‚Äú-maybe. I do have a summer job, but it doesn‚Äôt usually start this early. How long will the training last?‚Äù ‚ÄúAs long as you have strength remaining,‚Äù he replied. ‚ÄúOr until you have other matters that require attention. It is paramount that you increase your power as quickly as feasible.‚Äù ‚ÄúSo I can help deal with the ‚Äòdark spirits‚Äô you mentioned yesterday?‚Äù ‚ÄúCertainly. There is much to do. You will provide me with a list of available times.‚Äù ‚ÄúEr, sure. My schedule is usually...‚Äù After sorting that out, Bria‚Äôs summer was looking a lot busier. Zeal wasn‚Äôt messing around; he urged her to cram in extra training wherever it could fit, especially since she would be busier again in the fall. So much for relaxing, but it would be for a good cause. ‚ÄúBy the way, I was having some... um, trouble controlling my strength this morning. Would that whole ‚Äòturning my body into magic‚Äô thing happen to have anything to do with that?‚Äù ‚ÄúPerhaps. Although all of your abilities are significantly heightened in your battle form, even your base form is somewhat improved in many areas. With some practice, you should be able to restrain your strength to an ordinary level again.‚Äù ‚ÄúHow much is ‚Äòsome?‚Äô A few days or a few months or...?‚Äù ‚ÄúWithin the week, almost certainly.‚Äù ‚ÄúOh, good. I‚Äôll just have to be careful for a bit...‚Äù Bria muttered almost to herself. Then, a questioning look around. They were walking (well, Zeal was flying) along the road right next to the train tracks. ‚ÄúWhere are we going, by the way?‚Äù Surely not the station itself; it had only recently occurred to her how awkward it might be to have to interact with her dad as Silver. He wouldn‚Äôt be here for a while yet, but if they were staying around this area... ‚ÄúJust over this way.‚Äù ‚Äã
9:20 PM
As it turned out, there was a moderately sized park on the other side of the tracks, enclosed by trees and divided by a number of secluded paths. In reality, they were still only a few blocks from downtown, but the illusion of isolation was convincing. And given that it was still fairly early in the day, there weren‚Äôt many people around. Bria carefully navigated past the few who were, eventually finding a little private clearing near one of the corners. Pretty good for a fifteen minute walk. ‚ÄúNow,‚Äù said Zeal, once she had gotten settled. ‚ÄúTransform, and we will begin.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù After glancing around one more time just to make sure there really wasn‚Äôt anyone watching, Bria touched the hairclip. A few seconds and one brief lightshow later, Silver stood in her place. ‚ÄúIntent,‚Äù Zeal said, walking horizontally in midair in front of her, ‚Äúis the desire you hold when performing an action. It is the effect you wish the action to create. When you attack, the intent is to harm. When you defend, the intent is to protect. When you simply step upon the ground, the intent is to walk.‚Äù He paused. Silver didn‚Äôt say anything; this seemed obvious so far. ‚ÄúMagic behaves in accordance with the user‚Äôs intent. It does not have a natural state; if you release a strand of ‚Äòpure‚Äô magic, it will have no effect. Your body-‚Äù Another pause. Dramatic. ‚Äú-is made of magic. It acts only in accordance with your intent, unlike your prior, inferior body. If you hold unclear or weak intent when performing an action, the action is not performed.‚Äù ‚Äú...?‚Äù ‚ÄúSpeak, if you do not understand.‚Äù ‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt that the way it usually works? If I don‚Äôt want to take a step, I won‚Äôt do it.‚Äù ‚ÄúIn general, even your new body will continue acting as you consider ‚Äònormal,‚Äô because of your deep-rooted unconscious intent to do so. Therefore, yes, your day-to-day actions will tend to remain unchanged. Let‚Äôs perform a demonstration.‚Äù ‚Äã
9:20 PM
Zeal drifted closer, hovering in midair only a foot or two in front of Silver. ‚ÄúClose your eyes.‚Äù ‚Äú... What are you going to do?‚Äù she couldn‚Äôt help asking, but did as requested. ‚ÄúNothing. What do you think I would do?‚Äù ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know. Run off and hide so I‚Äôm just standing here talking to no one like an idiot?‚Äù No response. ‚ÄúOh, come on. You didn‚Äôt actually do tha - oof!‚Äù Silver stumbled backwards a step, rubbing her arm, and opened her eyes. ‚ÄúDid you just punch me?!‚Äù ‚ÄúYes. Now, I will do it again. Do not move, but defend yourself.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat does that even mea - oof?‚Äù A pause. ‚ÄúIt... didn‚Äôt hurt that time? Or, not as much?‚Äù Zeal floated back with an expression Silver could only describe as smug. ‚ÄúYou held no intent to defend yourself the first time. The second time, you did. That was the only difference; I used the same force and you did not move in either case. Intent matters dramatically when it comes to your body‚Äôs natural responses, even if you consciously do nothing.‚Äù ‚Äú... So, if I think about defense, even if I don‚Äôt do anything, I‚Äôll... automatically do something?‚Äù ‚ÄúTo an extent. Rather, all of the actions you do take gain efficiency. You may have unconsciously tensed or shifted your arm to deflect my blow in both cases, but only in the second case did those actions become more effective because of your intent. In heroes‚Äô combat, intent is everything. Your attacks are only as effective as your intent to harm your opponent. Your defense is only as strong as your intent to protect yourself. The more you understand your opponent, the more you can shape your intent to better evade their defenses or better foil their attacks.‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm... still not sure I quite get the difference between ‚Äòintent‚Äô and just... meaning to do something.‚Äù ‚Äã
9:20 PM
‚ÄúThere is less of a difference with physical actions,‚Äù Zeal admitted, ‚Äúas your unconscious intent to ‚Äòbehave as a normal physical body should‚Äô is very strong. But as you learn purely magical abilities, the power of intent will become quite clear. Strong adepts can even manipulate their unconscious intent to overcome limitations of their physical bodies. But for now, it is enough for you to simply be aware of the concept. Consider how it applies to the actions you perform.‚Äù ‚Äú... Okay.‚Äù ‚ÄúNow,‚Äù Zeal said, clapping his hands (paws?) together. ‚ÄúWe shall work on your defenses.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhy does that sound mildly ominous?‚Äù Several orbs of pastel-colored light appeared around the angel‚Äôs head, slowly increasing their speed as they orbited. ‚ÄúYour first task is to grow accustomed to your battle form‚Äôs reflexes and agility. I believe a reasonable analogue for this exercise would be the game known as ‚Äòdodgeball.‚Äô Simply dodge the ‚Äòballs‚Äô as long as you can.‚Äù More and more orbs bloomed into existence; Silver quickly lost track of how many were spinning. ‚ÄúAh. That‚Äôs why.‚Äù - ‚ÄúIntent‚Äù starts to make sense after a few days. - ‚ÄúIntent‚Äù still doesn‚Äôt really make sense. - Silver is pretty good at dodging. - Silver needs some more practice. (Winners: , ) (edited)

Mxblah 12/21/2024 4:45 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 3 June 17th, 2028 It had been a tough week. Bria had been training with Zeal every day for the past six of them and, while she had learned a lot, it seemed like she wasn‚Äôt making much progress. But beyond that, it had also been slow going trying to get used to her regular body‚Äôs new strength. The extra stamina was convenient, sure, but tasks requiring delicacy or precision (such as quite a lot of what she had to do at work) got complicated fast. At least she hadn‚Äôt actually broken anything yet; just gotten close. Whatever. She was making progress on that; the training was the real problem. Zeal was really serious about it. Or sadistic. It could be hard to tell sometimes. It turned out that, while Silver was certainly faster and more agile than Bria, it was still very difficult to dodge around dozens to hundreds of magical projectiles at once. None of the hits hurt very much, but ‚Äúnot very much‚Äù did start to add up after cumulative hours of it. And that was to say nothing about all of Zeal‚Äôs other ‚Äúgames,‚Äù like the one where he used beams or spikes instead of balls, or the one where she wasn‚Äôt allowed to see, or the one where she had to block instead of dodge, or- Bria mumbled into her pillow before slowly starting to crawl out of bed. Although damage to Silver‚Äôs clothes didn‚Äôt carry over to Bria‚Äôs (Zeal said that was because most items she had on her before she transformed were ‚Äústored as magic‚Äù until she changed back), injuries to Silver herself unfortunately did. She (either her) healed a lot more quickly than before, and Silver was impressively durable even before that, but - again - cumulative hours of this took a toll. She had to be pretty careful in front of her parents to avoid any concerned questions. ‚ÄúIntent,‚Äù she muttered while getting dressed. ‚ÄúIntent...‚Äù ‚Äã
4:45 PM
Today was Saturday again, which meant another early and long training session instead of one crammed in before or after work. That‚Äôs why she still felt kinda crap this morning; she had only had the night to recover from yesterday‚Äôs injuries instead of a full day. Maybe she should start asking for days off. But she still wasn‚Äôt moving fast enough even as-is! ‚ÄúThe effect I want to produce...‚Äù Intent still didn‚Äôt make much sense to her. Well, ‚Äúnormal‚Äù intent was fine, but the difference between that and ‚Äúmagical‚Äù intent still wasn‚Äôt quite clear. She had experimented a few times even outside of training, transforming in her room and trying various actions without ‚Äúintending‚Äù to actually do them, but that proved difficult to impossible. How could you throw a pillow in the air without meaning to do it? The opposite also seemed baffling - intending to do something without actually doing it also seemed a contradiction. Zeal hadn‚Äôt been much help either; he was always more invested in getting her to dodge faster or block better or anticipate more correctly. He just kept saying ‚Äúit will make more sense when you move to attacking.‚Äù Great, so why bring it up so early? Just so she could really think about it for a week? Probably. Today, it seemed, would be that day. Yesterday, Zeal - well, to call him ‚Äúsatisfied‚Äù would be an overstatement - but he decided that they had been working on defense long enough and Silver was doing good enough to try something different. Tomorrow, he said, she would get to attack. Which would be a lot more exciting if she weren‚Äôt still sore from all the failed dodges yesterday. But it was still pretty exciting. ... ‚Äã
4:45 PM
‚ÄúWe will start with physical attacks,‚Äù Zeal declared as he drew the outline of a training dummy in midair, creating a mostly-translucent target. A little reflective; refractive. Like glass. ‚ÄúIntent plays a much larger role in attacking than defending, as, in most cases, you must truly desire to harm or even kill your opponent for the attack to have a strong effect.‚Äù Silver frowned a little. ‚ÄúI have to want to kill whoever I‚Äôm fighting? Isn‚Äôt that a little... much?‚Äù ‚ÄúYou will be fighting against dark spirits. Personifications of evil. Your enemies will not hold back, and you must not either.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚ÄúStrike the target with intent,‚Äù Zeal instructed. ‚ÄúDesire its utter destruction.‚Äù I can do that, Silver thought, trying to reassure herself. It‚Äôs just a dummy, right? I can want to kill it. After all, it‚Äôs not even alive. He hadn‚Äôt said how specifically to strike the target, so Silver just stepped up and punched it with as much force as she could muster. It felt like whacking a bag of heavy gel; smooth and with a lot of give. The target wobbled, but nothing much happened beyond that. ‚ÄúHow was that?‚Äù ‚ÄúAgain. Attack it several more times, until you are certain of its destruction.‚Äù ‚Äú... Okay.‚Äù She pulled back and hit it a few more times, getting a little more fired up. Maybe a side kick too, like she had seen in a video? Each attack sent the jelly-target wobbling about in a frankly quite humorous way, but none of them sent it flying or split it apart or otherwise seemed to produce any permanent effect. Silver stopped again, breathing heavily with the exertion. ‚ÄúI... don‚Äôt think I can destroy it,‚Äù she admitted. ‚ÄúI mean, look at it. Nothing happened, even after all that?‚Äù ‚ÄúYour intent is weak. What do you picture happening to the target after your strike?‚Äù ‚ÄúIt... kinda wobbles around?‚Äù ‚ÄúSo it is not destroyed, even in your mind‚Äôs eye?‚Äù ‚Äú... So, that‚Äôs the problem? Just that I can‚Äôt imagine myself destroying it?‚Äù ‚Äã
4:45 PM
‚ÄúIt is not a matter of visualization, though the two are often paired. It is a matter of intent. You are not intending to destroy the target.‚Äù Zeal paused for a few moments, thinking. Silver wondered if he was frustrated. Good; she was too. ‚ÄúPerhaps... What is something you hate? A physical object or creature.‚Äù ‚ÄúHouse centipedes,‚Äù Silver answered immediately. ‚ÄúToo many legs. Wait, you aren‚Äôt going to - eEK!‚Äù As - in hindsight - probably should have been obvious, Zeal changed the abstract training dummy into a human-sized house centipede. It reared up on dozens of twitching legs, exaggerated mandibles clacking. ‚ÄúNow, destroy it,‚Äù he said calmly. With another sweeping kick (she wasn‚Äôt about to touch that thing with her hands), Silver‚Äôs frantic attack landed right in the bug‚Äôs midsection. And, unlike any of her previous attempts, there was a weighty sense of power behind this one. No flashy lights or magical bursts; the centipede simply tore in half and scattered into fragments of pastel dust with the follow-through. Silver stood there for a moment, eyes wide. ‚ÄúGood,‚Äù Zeal said, still perfectly calm. ‚ÄúFor that attack, you held an intent to kill.‚Äù ‚ÄúWas that an intent to kill or just plain fear?!‚Äù ‚ÄúYou saw the result. Now, remember how the intent felt and do it again with the original target.‚Äù Zeal waved his paws (hands?) and recreated the first, more abstract training dummy in a matter of moments. ‚Äú...‚Äù Silver pulled back, still shaking just a little with the adrenaline from before, and... - Destroys it. - Gives it a better wallop, but still does not destroy it. - Doesn‚Äôt do measurably better than before. Mxblah 12/23/2024 5:08 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 4 The dummy wobbled with a new ferocity, half-tearing its head off before plopping back together with a jelly-like slurp. ‚ÄúThat was better,‚Äù she decided. ‚ÄúRight?‚Äù ‚ÄúIt was,‚Äù Zeal nodded. ‚ÄúBut more practice on intent is needed, along with your technique. We shall continue along this track for the remainder of the morning. After that, perhaps you may find it enlightening to attempt a magical attack. At least, if your physical attacks have progressed sufficiently.‚Äù Silver continued to struggle with intent for the next several hours. The desire to hurt or kill just didn‚Äôt come naturally to her... unless she was terrified of whatever target Zeal brewed up. Giant bugs and horrible monsters? Sure, she could kill those in the moment. But if given time to think about it, or with more abstract targets, she really struggled to gather enough intent. It just didn‚Äôt seem right. And of course, the one human-like target he tried, she could hardly bring herself to even punch it normally. The illusion was unsettlingly good. But it wasn‚Äôt all bad news. Her technique improved quickly - almost naturally - though it wasn‚Äôt any ordinary fighting style. Her battle form just seemed to know how to move in effective (though flashy) ways for combat. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs intent again, isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù Bria guessed as they were taking a break for lunch. She was sitting outside at one of the cafes near the station, facing away from the building to make it less obvious she was talking to thin air (aka Zeal, hovering over the table). ‚ÄúI have the intent to know how to fight, so my body... figures it out?‚Äù Pleased at her deduction, he settled down on the napkins like a stack of carpets. ‚ÄúEssentially. You are beginning to grasp proper direction of your body through practice with your base form alongside battle training. Intent to harm is not the only useful kind - the intent to fight on its own can help a great deal with technique.‚Äù ‚Äã
5:09 PM
‚ÄúBut... does that mean I‚Äôll only be any good at fighting if I want to fight? And even if my technique is good, I won‚Äôt really do any damage unless I want to hurt my opponent?‚Äù ‚ÄúThis training works in less temporary ways.‚Äù He shuffled to the side as Bria needed to retrieve a napkin. ‚ÄúYour intent during training - with my assistance - acts as a spell that hones and adjusts your battle form. The purpose you hold will become the outcome, with some variation due to actual skill and the like.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù She chewed thoughtfully. ‚ÄúSo as long as I believe I will get better at fighting, I will get better, even if I‚Äôm not getting, like, formal training in martial arts or something.‚Äù ‚ÄúSimplified, but yes.‚Äù ‚ÄúOkay, I guess that almost makes sense. The power of self-confidence is a little more literal than usual.‚Äù A pause as she continued to digest the words and toasted sandwich simultaneously. A horn and bells sounded from up the tracks, announcing the arrival of an incoming train. ‚ÄúIs there any limit to intent?‚Äù she wondered. ‚ÄúLike, if I truly believed I could defeat anything with a single punch, like that guy from that comic, could I do it? And... wouldn‚Äôt that make, er, crazy people the best heroes? Since they... could believe something like that?‚Äù ‚ÄúRegardless of your intent, you will still be limited by the total amount of magic power stored within your body. All of your abilities make use of that magic in one way or another, so anything that cannot be accomplished with the totality of your body‚Äôs reserves will remain out of reach. There are of course ways to improve your magical capacity and thus the feats you can perform, including simple training.‚Äù ‚ÄúI guess it‚Äôs good that someone who really honestly believes they could destroy the world... actually can‚Äôt.‚Äù ‚Äã
5:09 PM
‚ÄúIndeed. As you stated, ‚Äòcrazy people‚Äô make interesting heroes. With incredibly strong intent, potentially divorced from ordinary unconscious baselines such as ‚Äòacting as a normal physical body,‚Äô such heroes can alter their own existence with startling fluidity. And unrelentingly strong intent can lead to problematic mutations of a hero‚Äôs body over time, potentially even including increases to capacity in order to fulfill the intent they believe so powerfully. ‚ÄúBut,‚Äù he continued, floating back into the air. ‚ÄúOften, individuals with such extreme intent are recruited by my brethren of darkness instead. Uncompromising vision and a desire to see it through tend to lead more towards villainy than heroism. The very strongest of these villains may become akin to... well, suffice to say, it is quite important that heroes like you destroy these burgeoning villains before they reach such a point.‚Äù The crossing gate just across the street activated and approaching bells signalled that the train from before had completed its station stop. Bria watched it pass, accelerating towards the distant skyline of the city proper. ‚ÄúYour brethren of darkness... you mean demons?‚Äù ‚ÄúThat is the name they have been given in the current culture.‚Äù ‚ÄúDo they have another name?‚Äù ‚ÄúCalling them demons does the job. It is accurate enough.‚Äù ‚Äú... Okay; do you - or angels like you - do you know these demons, then?‚Äù ‚ÄúOf course. They are who we fight, much as their dark heroes are those who you fight.‚Äù ‚ÄúRight. I - I meant more like personally, I guess?‚Äù ‚ÄúIt would be unusual but not unheard of. Nemeses from former encounters, perhaps.‚Äù ‚Äã
5:09 PM
That didn‚Äôt really answer her question, but at this point Bria had run out of social courage to keep trying and just focused on lunch. She could have come right out and asked ‚ÄúHey, where did angels and demons come from? (Was it the same place?)‚Äù but it was common knowledge that neither type of celestial was willing to talk about it, even to their heroes. It was widely believed that angels and demons were the same species - they looked very similar and had similar abilities, at least - but whether they actually came from ‚Äúheaven‚Äù or ‚Äúhell‚Äù was... an open question. Some religions believed so; others vehemently denied it. Well, it wasn‚Äôt like she had any real chance of ending a decade of uncertainty with a few questions in a single afternoon. The curiosity lingered, but it was hardly her most pressing concern. That, most likely, was figuring out how to cast magic. - Silver ends the day unable to produce a proper magical attack. - Silver is able to cast a simple unattuned magical attack, though of limited effectiveness. - Silver makes good progress with magic - better than physical, in fact. Mxblah 12/25/2024 4:56 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 5 ‚ÄúAnd now,‚Äù Zeal stated once they were back from lunch and back in the park. ‚ÄúMagical attacks. We will begin with the simplest spells you can cast: unattuned attacks.‚Äù He sketched the now-familiar jelly-like dummy in midair, preparing the target. ‚ÄúUnlike attuned magic, which is ‚Äòflavored‚Äô with your particular signature, unattuned attacks consist of nothing but raw magic infused with intent. No preparation or shaping is required, which makes them simple, cheap, and - above all - fast.‚Äù Silver doubted they would be any of those things to start with, but hopefully she would eventually get there. ‚ÄúYou may find this process quite challenging to start with; many new heroes do, despite its simplicity. Perhaps because of it. In any case, an unattuned magical attack is very similar to a physical attack at its core: they both require directing a portion of your magical power towards the target. The difference is in the source and the flow.‚Äù Silver almost interrupted to ask a question, but actually, she did know what was going on. Her physical attacks were magical because her body was magical. ‚ÄúDirecting a portion of magical power‚Äù in that case was just a fancy way to say ‚Äúthrowing a punch‚Äù or the like. ‚ÄúInstead of the source being the solidified magic that makes up your body, you will need to tap into the ether that binds it. You already do this when transforming, so it should not be a new sensation. And instead of the flow starting and ending with a physical motion, allow the magic to separate from you and impact the target. Otherwise, it‚Äôs the same.‚Äù ‚Äã
4:56 PM
‚Äú... Right.‚Äù Totally the same. Definitely no gaping leaps of intuition there. But... although she was of course thinking this sarcastically, there was a hint of truth present. The core idea did sort of make sense. She just had to try to get a feel for the ‚Äúsource‚Äù and the ‚Äúflow.‚Äù Whatever that meant. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to try transforming a few times to see if I can understand what you mean by the ether thing.‚Äù ‚ÄúA reasonable idea. Focus your attention on the energy you provide to the transformer when initiating the process. That is the same ether used in magical attacks.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù Silver changed back to Bria, then touched the hairclip again and really tried to pay attention to what, specifically, she was doing. It wasn‚Äôt just ‚Äútouch this hairclip and think about transforming‚Äù - there was something else there. A hidden, almost unconscious action. It took her a few transformations (actually nearly fifteen) before Silver started to feel confident in this ‚Äúether‚Äù thing. It was hard to describe. Maybe the best metaphor was the ‚Äúoverlay‚Äù one that Zeal had used to describe her battle form? There was her actual body - made of solid magic - and then there was the ether overlaid on top of it. Some other state; more fluid, more flexible. And containing much, much more energy. When she transformed, she was actually directing a portion of this ether into her transformer, which... did... well, something. It transformed her; she still didn‚Äôt really understand how it worked. But for now, even just this partial success was enough. Because, with that understanding of ether... ‚Äã
4:57 PM
Yeah, nope. It was never going to be that easy. It took her nearly an hour to figure out a mostly-reliable technique just to grasp the ether outside the context of transforming, and another two trying to direct it properly. It felt like how she imagined learning to use a new limb would feel: just flexing muscles at random until she could work out which ones did what. Unintuitive, mentally demanding, and surprisingly exhausting. Zeal tried to help throughout the whole ordeal, but it was clear he just naturally understood how to use it. His examples always came with a disclaimer that ‚Äúthis was how a previous hero did it‚Äù or ‚Äúanother hero understood it like this‚Äù or something. To the angel himself, it was like trying to teach her how to move her arm up and down. So simple as to be almost baffling. Still, she wasn‚Äôt about to give up until she cast a spell or passed out trying. And so it was that, in the early hours of evening as the shadows grew long and the day‚Äôs heat began to subside, Silver actually did it. To her surprise and enormous relief, something finally clicked and a burst of silvery light shot from her fingertips. Of course, she hadn‚Äôt actually been expecting to succeed, so it splashed against the ground instead of the target. A small spray of dirt erupted, leaving a mark in the grass. ‚ÄúI did it!‚Äù was all she could think to say, immediately scrambling to her feet and taking aim at the dummy again. ‚ÄúNow, to prove it wasn‚Äôt just a fluke!‚Äù Zeal hovered in silence for several moments. Silver‚Äôs outstretched arm shook; she closed her eyes. ‚ÄúIt is impressive enough that you managed to-‚Äù ‚ÄúHA!‚Äù A second bolt of light flew at the target, this time impacting it squarely in the chest. The magic burst apart, leaving a fading residue behind, as the dummy wobbled back and forth. Nearly invisible remnant wisps streaked through the air, returning a portion of the expended power to Silver for reuse. Just as Zeal said would happen. ‚Äã
4:57 PM
‚ÄúHa,‚Äù she repeated, catching her breath with hands on knees. ‚ÄúWasn‚Äôt... a fluke.‚Äù ‚ÄúExcellent work,‚Äù Zeal said frankly. ‚ÄúMany heroes do not get this far on their first day. With further training, we will work on reliability, speed, recovery, and refining the bolts into different forms. But for today, you should be satisfied with your progress.‚Äù Silver straightened up again, unable to hold back a beaming smile. She had cast a spell! For real! She had just done that! ‚ÄúI think I‚Äôm getting the hang of it now,‚Äù she said, aiming and - with a several-second pause - firing a third bolt at the target. This one was a little off-center, but it still hit. ‚ÄúHow many of these do you think I can do in a row?‚Äù ‚ÄúGiven that you have been exerting yourself all day? I am somewhat surprised you are still standing.‚Äù ‚ÄúOne more, then.‚Äù Another pause; another bolt. This one missed entirely, breaking apart against Zeal‚Äôs safety net behind the dummy. Set up for exactly this scenario to make sure she didn‚Äôt accidentally hit a pedestrian through the trees or something. ‚ÄúOr two.‚Äù ‚ÄúSilver, consider being satisfied with your progress and ending the day here.‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôll stop once I hit it dead-on again, like the first time. C‚Äômon...‚Äù Another three bolts hit the dummy off-center, but with the fourth, Bria found herself unexpectedly returning to her base form in the middle of the attack. A wave of exhaustion hit her all at once and she fell to her knees, panting like she had just run a marathon. ‚ÄúIt seems you have depleted your available energy; you are too tired to maintain your battle form. It is recommended to rest.‚Äù ‚ÄúG-got it,‚Äù she huffed. ‚ÄúOw, ow; how am I sore in places that aren‚Äôt even in my body?‚Äù [After another few days...] - Zeal considers Silver ready to go out for a field demonstration. - The field demonstration arrives of its own accord; ready or not. (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 12/27/2024 12:27 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 6 June 21st, 2028 ‚ÄúBy the end of this week, I believe you may be ready for some field experience,‚Äù Zeal said, again perched on the napkins. They were at the same cafe as last Saturday, though this time Bria wasn‚Äôt exhausted from training in the morning. Instead, she had walked here from the library where she worked to spend the afternoon training instead. After lunch, at least. ‚ÄúAlready? Even though I still can‚Äôt get the right intent to attack properly?‚Äù ‚ÄúI believe it will do you good to see the type of monsters you will fight. It may help clarify your intent.‚Äù ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs ominous,‚Äù she decided. The crossing gates activated just like last time, though this train was coming from the other direction. ‚ÄúWhat kind of monsters will I be fighting, by the way? I don‚Äôt think heroes generally fight demons directly...? Is it really all villains, like they show in the news?‚Äù ‚ÄúIt is not. Confrontations with heroes of darkness are somewhat uncommon, though they are the most spectacular battles you will face. That is likely why they are reported upon; day-to-day activities are less newsworthy.‚Äù ‚ÄúDay-to-day activities like...?‚Äù She found that he often did this when she asked multiple things at once. A lot of their conversations involved Bria just restating the question a few times. ‚ÄúMost dark spirits are less powerful than full demons, so they cannot empower heroes and cannot hide from us as effectively. They do still cause trouble, however, so those are the monsters you will typically hunt. Assuming all goes according to plan, you will see one in the field by the end of the week.‚Äù ‚ÄúAnd you‚Äôre not going to tell me now, I assume?‚Äù ‚ÄúAll will be revealed in due time.‚Äù ‚Äã
12:27 PM
‚ÄúThought so.‚Äù That was another one of Zeal‚Äôs ‚Äúquirks,‚Äù Bria supposed. Even when he did understand that she was asking a specific question, he would often withhold information ‚Äúuntil the time is right,‚Äù even if knowing it ahead of time would help her prepare better. Such as, for example, what she might be fighting in the field. It‚Äôs not like she was completely clueless. Other heroes did this too, but as she had mentioned, most of the hero reporting was on their clashes with villains (or ‚Äúheroes of darkness,‚Äù as Zeal liked to call them). It wasn‚Äôt typically done to just follow a hero around on a normal day with a camera. Though, now that she thought about it, someone almost certainly had done that; it was too obvious an idea to have never been done. ‚ÄúA day in the life‚Äù content was popular, right? And what could be more popular than a day in a hero‚Äôs life? She‚Äôd have to do some looking later. After another minute or so, Bria was about ready to leave and get started on the afternoon‚Äôs training. They would be continuing on attacks today, including shaping her unattuned magic for different effects. This didn‚Äôt involve intent to harm directly (‚Äúintent to shape,‚Äù more like), so she was pretty enthusiastic about it. But as she started gathering the wrappers to clear the table, Zeal suddenly looked up. ‚ÄúHm?‚Äù she noted. ‚ÄúSomething wrong?‚Äù ‚ÄúNot particularly. I merely noticed the presence of a hero of darkness nearby.‚Äù Bria paused for a second. ‚ÄúW-what? Here?! How nearby; w-what do you mean that‚Äôs not something wrong?‚Äù ‚ÄúWithin a mile or so, likely. Detection is notoriously imprecise; I cannot pinpoint their location.‚Äù She rapidly swept everything into a bag and hurried to throw it away. ‚ÄúWhy is this not a problem?‚Äù ‚Äã
12:27 PM
‚ÄúWhile you are in your base form, you are hidden from the opponent‚Äôs demon, and I - of course - am always invisible. It is possible they are here because your transformations have been sensed in the past, but equally possible it is on unrelated business. There is no need to engage should you not desire it.‚Äù ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs - that‚Äôs good, but still, a villain in my town? Even if they‚Äôre not here for me, what are they gonna do?‚Äù Zeal did a little flip in midair that Bria couldn‚Äôt interpret as relevant to the conversation. Maybe he just wanted to? ‚ÄúWho knows? Someone will likely stop them after a while.‚Äù ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not good enough. What if someone gets hurt?‚Äù ‚ÄúIf you wish, you are able to engage the opponent yourself. You now have the core skills to perform in a battle, though they do need further refinement. And it seems from the aura that the hero of darkness is not particularly strong.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù Bria hesitated, trying to balance her desire to be a hero and protect her town with her desire to not get hurt in a fight she probably wasn‚Äôt ready for. ‚ÄúI can at least try to find them and see what‚Äôs going on. But... you really don‚Äôt have any idea where they could be other than ‚Äònearby?‚Äô‚Äù ‚ÄúUnfortunately not. If I could pinpoint an opponent‚Äôs location decisively, it would be trivial to detect their base form when they transformed back, no?‚Äù ‚ÄúRight...‚Äù Bria wasn‚Äôt really listening after the first two words. She glanced up and down the street, seeing nothing amiss in either direction. But... ‚ÄúThe train!‚Äù It was already gone, but it had just stopped at the station only a block away. Most heroes and villains couldn‚Äôt do anything silly like fly or teleport, and if Zeal was right that this one was relatively weak, it would make sense they would have gotten here on the train. Then... transformed at the station? Maybe? It was worth a shot. ‚Äã
12:27 PM
Zeal hovered alongside her as Bria ran up the road towards the station building. What was she going to do if there really was a villain there? And, come to think of it, if she just ran in there as she was, wouldn‚Äôt that look a bit suspiciously heroic? She wasn‚Äôt sure exactly how far the anti-recognition spell on her battle form went and really didn‚Äôt want to ruin her secret identity this early. So maybe a bit of discretion was called for. To that end, she slowed to a walk when approaching the building and pressed close to the side so she could peek onto the platform without being seen herself. Anyone who got off the last train would have been on the other side, of course, but she could see that platform from here and there were only a handful of very normal-looking people. She had to assume a villain would have a flashy costume and would certainly stand out. And, as Bria peeked around the corner to look down the near platform, she was very much proven correct. A girl about her age with long black twintails stood facing the wall, presumably... reading the train schedule? She wore a dress of deep, dark purple, decorated with belts, ribbons, lace, and other details in a frankly overwhelming assortment that just barely stopped shy of ‚Äúno idea what I‚Äôm looking at.‚Äù A translucent black hooded cloak shifted gently in the low wind, somehow casting a dim shadow even on the already-shaded platform. ‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù the girl said to the wall. Her voice was somewhat high and a little scratchy. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs at 1:35, I guess. If no one shows up by then.‚Äù A pause, presumably as her invisible demon responded. ‚ÄúYeah, yeah. You‚Äôd better be right. I‚Äôm not gonna be happy if they just call the cops or something.‚Äù Another pause. ‚ÄúI guess that‚Äôs true.‚Äù The girl spun around and flopped dramatically onto a bench, sighing. ‚ÄúGod, it‚Äôs so hoooooot. What kind of crazy person would be out training in heat like this?‚Äù ‚Äã
12:27 PM
Bria slipped back around the corner, whispering to Zeal. ‚ÄúTh-that‚Äôs gotta be the villain, right?‚Äù ‚ÄúIndeed,‚Äù he said at a normal volume. The privileges of being inaudible to anyone except Bria. ‚ÄúAnd her demon as well, though I cannot tell which one unless it reveals itself.‚Äù ‚ÄúS-so, what do I do? It doesn‚Äôt seem like she‚Äôs doing anything, y‚Äôknow, evil?‚Äù A pause. ‚ÄúAnd they‚Äôve gotta be here because of me, right? She was talking about training!‚Äù ‚ÄúYes, it is likely your presence was sensed at some point. It seems plausible, given their current actions, that they intend to do something at 1:35. You may have until then to decide on a course of action.‚Äù Bria checked her phone. 1:17. Just under 20 minutes. And, while she was there, she verified her suspicion on her transit app: the next inbound train was scheduled to arrive at 1:35. What were they intending to do with the train? Blow it up? That‚Äôs what heroes do! - Just call the cops or something. It seemed she wouldn‚Äôt be happy about that. Ô∏è - Stay sneaky. Keep watch until 1:35 and see what happens. @Story Notifications Scene 7 ... ‚ÄúYou think I could make this cape do air conditioning?‚Äù Violet asked, flapping the aforementioned cape against the heat. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs made of darkness or something, so it should be cold. Still, Violet was faster; she arrived within view of the operator‚Äôs front windows before the train could get up to any real speed. ‚ÄúSorry ‚Äòbout this, but: shadow mist!‚Äù A faint line of dim light - like an inverse laser beam - briefly connected her outstretched hand to the windows. Then, the entire front of the train was coated in a shroud of opaque darkness. A product of her magic. ‚Äã
1:10 PM

@Story Notifications Scene 8 ‚ÄúThen make me!‚Äù Violet took a few steps forward, lowering her stance slightly to get ready to move quickly. Just in case. ‚ÄúOh, but first, let me know your name? @Story Notifications Scene 9 The trick, as it turned out, was pretty simple. Whether intentionally or not (and Violet really hoped it wasn‚Äôt intentional since there should have been no way for her to know it was important), Silver managed to grab onto Violet‚Äôs cloak in their struggle and pulled the hood down. Which, of course, exposed her to the toxic effects of her own mist. With an unexpected lungful of poison, Violet reflexively let go in order to pull her hood back up, and by the time she was done doing that, Silver was gone. ‚ÄúAre you kidding me? Where‚Äôd you - agh!‚Äù She hurried out of the overlapping clouds, dismissing them both as she looked around. No heroes in sight. ‚ÄúShe must‚Äôve been pretty badly hurt,‚Äù Violet reasoned. ‚ÄúMaybe she ran away. Vani, you see anything?‚Äù ‚ÄúShe went around the corner!‚Äù the demon replied, fading into view on the station‚Äôs roof and pointing helpfully. ‚ÄúYou really got her good!‚Äù ‚ÄúNot good enough, I guess.‚Äù Violet hurried around the indicated corner, cautiously preparing to dodge another ambush, but no one was there. She sidled past, nodding in what she hoped was a commiserating sort of way. The frequency really wasn‚Äôt great outside of rush hours. Then it was off down the road to go home. She was still coughing a little, even as Bria, and felt very drained. Zeal hadn‚Äôt shown up again quite yet, but she had a feeling he might be a little disappointed in her performance. She didn‚Äôt really understand how she had gotten out of that second cloud; Violet had just... let go for some reason. The angel popped up in the middle of the road a few blocks down. ‚ÄúI hope you have learned the importance of intent, now. You struck multiple blows, but none were sufficiently damaging to meaningfully progress the battle.‚Äù ‚Äú... I know. And her attacks really hurt because-‚Äù ‚ÄúIncorrect. Your opponent‚Äôs intent was all wrong too.‚Äù Bria slowed, glancing up at him. ‚ÄúHuh? Wasn‚Äôt she trying to kill me with that poison? You would not be so healthy had she displayed the proper resolution.‚Äù ‚Äú...? So, er, what was her intent, then?‚Äù ‚Äã
7:25 PM
‚ÄúWho knows? I am not a mind reader; I am merely looking at the results.‚Äù ‚ÄúS-so the attack on the train, was that even poison at all?‚Äù ‚ÄúI doubt it,‚Äù Zeal huffed, seemingly disappointed by that. ‚ÄúI observed no injuries to the passengers or crew. More weak intent. You will be able to easily defeat her with a simple increase of will.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù Zeal had her take the rest of the day off. And since both her parents were still at work, she had plenty of time to clean up and scrounge up some medicine to help with the cough. Just to stave off any questions, not because it was particularly bothering her. After that, her dad got back first and she helped him clear out some boxes of junk from the garage. After that, her mom returned too and it was time for dinner and the like. No time to really reflect on what had happened until late into the evening. But evening did come. And then she had plenty of time to think. The first question she tried to answer was that of Violet. What was her deal; what did she want to accomplish with all that? According to Zeal, she hadn‚Äôt had an intent to kill, and it was entirely possible she hadn‚Äôt hurt or even really endangered anyone besides Silver. Although her dad would be livid if she shared that line of thought with him; he could lecture for quite a while on how not to mess around near trains and blocking the engineer‚Äôs sight was certainly in the ‚Äúmessing around‚Äù category. In fact, he had already heard of the incident from the conductor on scene, so Bria hadn‚Äôt had to just imagine his reaction. But really, in the grand scheme of things... not very evil, was it? ‚Äã
7:25 PM
Violet hadn‚Äôt really taken their fight seriously either, messing around asking questions and trying to bait Silver into using magic she didn‚Äôt yet know. Why? Was she just curious about a new hero? Did she actually do real evil things somewhere else? Bria did some quick searching online, but there weren‚Äôt any mentions of a villain named Violet in the area, let alone one who was an actual menace. ‚Äú...‚Äù Well, she didn‚Äôt know. But something told her that today wouldn‚Äôt be the last time she‚Äôd see Violet, so maybe she could just ask her later. After all, it didn‚Äôt seem like she had been in much of a hurry to fight today; Silver had attacked first. Bria shook those thoughts out of her head. Most villains weren‚Äôt like that, right? That‚Äôs why Zeal kept trying to get her to want to hurt people. Monsters; truly evil villains. Not... someone like her. Still, it didn‚Äôt quite feel right. If her intent shaped her magic, why did ‚Äúkill‚Äù have to be the only option? Couldn‚Äôt she have the intent ‚Äúto stop‚Äù or ‚Äúto restrain‚Äù or something like that? Maybe unattuned magic wasn‚Äôt that flexible; maybe that‚Äôs what the ‚Äúsignature magic‚Äù Violet had mentioned was about. She still just didn‚Äôt know anything! A breath. Patience, Bria. It‚Äôs only been a week and a half. Don‚Äôt get ahead of yourself; you‚Äôll get there. - Silver works on practicing that idea of intent ‚Äúto stop‚Äù instead of ‚Äúto harm.‚Äù - Silver works on intent ‚Äúto harm‚Äù like Zeal recommends. Ô∏è - Silver tries to mix her workload. (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 1/4/2025 5:16 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 10 June 24th, 2028 ‚ÄúYour intent has not improved,‚Äù Zeal continued as they watched the train slow to a stop in front of them. Bria headed for an open door to board. ‚ÄúI told you,‚Äù she said quietly, trying not to look insane as she climbed to the second level. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm trying less lethal but still effective intents. I think I can stop someone without having to kill them, and the dummy agrees.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe dummy lives up to its namesake,‚Äù he countered. ‚ÄúThe only way to survive against your foes is with the desire to end them.‚Äù ‚ÄúViolet wasn‚Äôt like that.‚Äù Zeal sighed. ‚ÄúThat girl was hardly a proper representative of the forces of darkness. You will learn that today.‚Äù ‚ÄúAnd that‚Äôs why we‚Äôre heading into the city,‚Äù she concluded, poking through the app to activate her ticket. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm kind of excited; I get to check out my campus again and do some hero stuff.‚Äù Zeal didn‚Äôt respond, but she felt like he was annoyed. Well, the feeling was mutual. He didn‚Äôt approve of her less-lethal plan, even though her attacks were having more effect on the dummy now than when she had been trying to ‚Äúkill‚Äù it. He kept saying stuff like he just had - that true evil wouldn‚Äôt show her any mercy and she had to be willing to kill in order to defeat it. The lack of willingness to even consider her viewpoint had gotten a little grating over time. So, today he was making good on his suggestion from earlier that she would be ready for field work by the weekend. It had been two weeks since she had become a hero, and now they were heading into the big city to find one of the truly evil monsters he had been talking about. Bria felt like she should be more worried about that than she was, but for some reason she actually felt more nervous about getting lost when they got to campus. Of course, that was assuming they actually got there at all; Zeal might notice something beforehand and pull her off track. ‚Äã
5:17 PM
Apparently most of these evil spirits fed on humans in one way or another. The ones that did so literally (the particularly animalistic, dangerous spirits) were typically found in less populated areas, like actual wild animals. She knew that; everyone did. But trying to get out to some woods would be a real pain since she would have a hard time convincing her mom to let her borrow the car without a good reason, and honestly that sounded more than a little too risky anyway. It would be like trying to fight a bear, except it wouldn‚Äôt be scared of her. So instead, he was taking her into the city to look for the spirits that fed in other ways. The kind that ate emotions or thoughts (or even more abstract quantities that Zeal refused to describe until she was more advanced) proliferated in dense, urban areas. Therefore, heroes came to cities to hunt them and protect those who lived there. Heroes like the popular, powerful, and very well-known Aquamarine - he was on the news just this morning for defusing an explosives threat at the docks. Or, now, heroes like Silver. Not popular, powerful, or well-known, but you had to start somewhere. These spirits could also be commanded by true demons - dark spirits capable of empowering humans to become villains - or villains themselves. That was another important reason to hunt them down, so they couldn‚Äôt become pawns in larger, more dangerous schemes than just their own appetites. Whatever it was they actually ate. Zeal vanished at some point during the ride without saying anything, so Bria just watched trees, roads, and increasingly tall buildings pass by the windows until arriving at one of the city‚Äôs three massive stations. Then, since her angel still hadn‚Äôt reappeared, she just started walking to the transfer point to head to her college campus, as she had planned. If he wasn‚Äôt going to show up, then she‚Äôd just go do her own thing. ‚Äã
5:17 PM
But he did reappear. Just on the steps leading up to the elevated subway station, in fact, causing Bria to nearly fall down them (thinking she was about to step on a cat or particularly small dog). ‚ÄúPlease,‚Äù she gasped after managing to stay upright and embarrassingly hurrying away from anyone who just saw her trip on nothing. ‚ÄúShow up somewhere normal. Don‚Äôt just appear where I‚Äôm about to step!‚Äù ‚ÄúThere is no time; I required your attention immediately. Please follow me.‚Äù Bria hesitated a moment, but did as requested, turning away from the station to hustle down the busy street. ‚ÄúWhat is it? Should I transf - er-‚Äù Bria looked around for a moment. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs nowhere to transform in the city!‚Äù she whispered. ‚ÄúThere are people everywhere! How do other heroes do it?‚Äù ‚ÄúThere are always locations if you put your mind to it. Phones emerged from pockets, pictures were snapped, and people generally took notice of her. It was like she was a minor celebrity, just from outfit alone - and what it represented.
