@Story Notifications Scene 11 ‚ÄúOfficial hero business, sir,‚Äù she told the doorman. ‚ÄúCould you tell me how to get to the mechanical room?‚Äù On the face of it, her statement might seem ridiculous; she was a high school (college now?) student in a sparkly costume asking a fancy adult man to let her into the basement. She didn‚Äôt have any qualifications or even ID (even if her driver‚Äôs license would be useful, it had gone with her regular clothes and couldn‚Äôt be accessed until she transformed back). And indeed, she did still feel a twinge of awkwardness beneath the hero-ish exterior. But not enough to stop her. And, whether it was her confident demeanor, the crowd outside, or perhaps that this particular doorman had been through something similar before, he didn‚Äôt need to see anything else. ‚ÄúYes, though I will need to accompany you. May I have your name and the specifics of the issue you intend to resolve?‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Silver. And my angel says there‚Äôs a dark spirit in the basement somewhere near a mechanical room.‚Äù She looked up at Zeal, hovering serenely above her right shoulder. ‚ÄúDid you have any other details?‚Äù ‚ÄúIt is large and likely able to hide itself from ordinary senses. Though that ability should fade once you start attacking it.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs big and invisible,‚Äù she relayed. ‚ÄúProbably.‚Äù He wrote a few notes, put up an ‚Äúaway from the desk‚Äù sign, and nodded. ‚ÄúAlright, follow me, please.‚Äù Silver let him lead her into the elevator, after which he inserted a key and down they went. It was a brief descent, the doors opening to a short, much less polished concrete-floored corridor. Machinery hummed from behind several scraped-up metal doors. ‚ÄúThis is the mechanical room,‚Äù the doorman said, indicating one of the doors with a small window. ‚ÄúIf you are to be fighting in there, I will stay in the hall for my safety. Please do not damage anything if you can avoid it.‚Äù ‚ÄúRight. I‚Äôll try.‚Äù ‚Äã
7:46 PM
At his gesture, Silver crept up to the door and placed her hand on the handle. Peeked through the window to spot banks of electrical-looking panels, a few... pumps(?), a larger... thingy - she didn‚Äôt know what all this stuff was. But it was a fairly big room with a lot of machines inside. No monster visible yet, though Zeal had said it would probably be invisible. Cautiously, she crept inside. ‚ÄúWhat should I be looking for?‚Äù Silver whispered, barely audible over the room‚Äôs baseline level of noise. ‚ÄúOr, not-looking. How am I supposed to find it?‚Äù ‚ÄúLook for inconsistencies. Objects that seem out of place or otherwise incorrect. Alternatively, you could make yourself obvious and wait for it to attack you first.‚Äù ‚ÄúI think I‚Äôll try the first option,‚Äù Silver decided. ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs going to be hard to see what‚Äôs out of place when I don‚Äôt know what any of this stuff is supposed to look like. I‚Äôm not a mechanic, you know.‚Äù ‚ÄúPerception is key. Observe.‚Äù Ah, right. The old ‚Äújust try harder.‚Äù Well, she could do that, she supposed. Silver looked around the room, turning back towards the entrance every so often to make sure the doorman was still there and not looking too impatient or suspicious. Nothing seemed obviously out of place in the electrical work or most of the freestanding machines; there sure were cables and lights and loud noises that generally fit together. But, for some reason, she found herself drawn to the arrangement of piping near the far wall. Pumps (or some other unknown machine) thrummed, pushing water up the building. Or perhaps accepting water coming back down? Or both? She stopped, considering the pipes. ‚ÄúWhy do I feel like something‚Äôs off here?‚Äù Zeal said nothing. ‚ÄúActually, why is the flow so loud? How tall is this building; how much water could the upper floors possibly need to be going so fast down here? This pipe is thicker than my arm!‚Äù ‚Äã
7:46 PM
Again, Zeal said nothing. But by now, Silver had it figured out. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs here. Somewhere... right about...‚Äù A pause; a shuffle slightly closer and slightly to the side. Something felt warm nearby. ‚ÄúHere.‚Äù She pulled back, focused her intent, and punched into the air with as much force as she could muster. Something warm and squishy deformed under her fist, rolling and rippling like a massive mound of jelly. Distorted waves flowed through the air, washing away a shroud of invisibility on a very large creature. Its main body, in which Silver‚Äôs arm was now buried up to the elbow, was the shape of a gumdrop and the size of a car. It was dark, dull grey with stripes of lighter grey in a bee-like pattern. It had no legs - or they were invisible beneath its massive, flabby body - and its head was a tiny, neckless, eyeless blob of the same light grey shade. Only a pair of slitted nostrils and a comically small mouth added definition. And, last but certainly not least, it must have had a dozen or more arms. Thin, spindly, with knobbly lumps on the joints, the thing‚Äôs fingers were lodged in dozens of pipes around the room. Wiggling, writhing, doing who-knew-what to the water contained within. The thing‚Äôs head rotated to peer sightlessly in her direction. Silver tugged her arm out of its body, watching its skin slop uncomfortably back into place with an audibly moist plop and a visible deformation left from her attack. She felt a tingle of base fear as the creature regarded her. ‚ÄúZeal,‚Äù she whispered. ‚ÄúWhat on Earth is this thing?‚Äù ‚Äã
7:46 PM

Mxblah 1/8/2025 9:16 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 12 She started by backing up, ducking beneath the two swiping arms in her path and getting out of the thing‚Äôs melee range. From that position of relative safety, she could focus on an opening barrage of ranged attacks - aiming primarily for the spirit‚Äôs limbs and secondarily for its massive, squishy body. Accuracy continued to present a problem; the arms were too thin and nimble to hit with any regularity. Silver scored a few hits just due to how many projectiles she launched, but most broke apart on thick rolls of flab, dealing minimal damage. Those that did hit arms seemed to be more effective, but it was clear she wouldn‚Äôt be able to do much with this tactic. The spirit could move. It waddled slowly along with little wriggling motions near the base of its body, advancing towards the room‚Äôs center and expanding the area its arms could reach. But just because she was out of its melee range didn‚Äôt mean it was out of attacks. Fingers dipped into pipes without seeming to break the material, emerging coated in droplets of sparkling liquid. Not water, certainly; a silvery hue was the first she saw, but every color of the rainbow made an appearance on its dozens upon dozens of fingers. Silver hesitated, watching it warily and trying to determine how to respond. Run? Duck? Jump aside? Find some cover? There was a - !! The creature flicked most of its arms towards her, creating a targeted rain of multicolored liquid. Silver chose to leap behind one of the larger, sturdier freestanding machines for cover, listening to droplets splatter against concrete and metal. Only a few splotches got onto her clothes or skin, though the ones that did burned painfully. Wisps of smoke curled into the air. ‚Äã
9:16 PM
‚ÄúErk-‚Äù Silver stumbled, tremors shaking her left leg like it had a mind of its own. A drop of silver liquid clung to the skin there, just above her knee. She quickly rubbed it off with her dress, thinking it would be a bad idea to get whatever it was on her hands, and her leg began to return to normal. Still, a pale blotch remained like a burn or scar. Some sort of nerve agent? Did that even make sense in the context of her magic body? A hand crawled around the side of the casing; Silver reflexively slammed it with her elbow. The creature whistled and withdrew the arm; Silver hurried to back up further, grateful she hadn‚Äôt missed and elbowed solid metal. ‚ÄúZeal,‚Äù she huffed, finding different cover closer to the door as the creature pulled more liquid out of the pipes. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not hurting this thing much.‚Äù ‚ÄúAre you intending to?‚Äù ‚ÄúNot this again!‚Äù Silver pressed further against the cool, humming metal to avoid splashes as more droplets flew through the air. ‚ÄúObviously I want to get rid of it!‚Äù ‚ÄúHurt it. Kill it. Destroy the creature; show no mercy. You must not confuse moral treatment of a human with moral treatment of a natural force of evil. Even now, you refuse to so much as speak the word. Kill, Silver.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù Was that really the problem? Could she still just not desire to kill this obvious monster? What was it even doing here; feeding? Did it really feel malice, or was it just trying to keep itself alive? Could she hate it for that? Enough to truly want it to die? It was kind of like a bug with all those arms, which she had been able to want to kill before, but always under quick, instinctual fear or stress. Here, it had already been long enough to outlast that immediate reaction. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just not aiming right,‚Äù she decided instead. Even if her intent was wrong, she probably couldn‚Äôt fix it in the next thirty seconds. ‚ÄúIts arms are too fast and its body is too squishy. I just gotta...‚Äù ‚Äã
9:16 PM
Silver popped out of cover for a moment, just long enough to bait the thing into launching another volley of droplets at her. Then, after dodging most of them by retreating behind the machine and trying her best to ignore the remaining burns, Silver ran closer this time while focusing another burst of unattuned magic. She kept a close eye on the multitude of nearby hands, but as she had expected, most of them were busy digging through pipes to retrieve more ammunition. None of them just tried to reach out and grab her. She shot the thing in the head. It was an off-center shot, but it still hit with enough force to send the little blob spinning impossibly around, its mouth and nostrils doing three full rotations before slowing to a stop. A smoking, glowing wound burned on the right side of its head; a splatter of grey goo decorated the far wall amidst the glowing residue of her magic. Arms and hands went limp, flopping to the floor with a drawn-out series of slaps. A pause. ‚ÄúDid I-‚Äù The creature howled with an impossibly piercing shriek; Silver covered her ears but couldn‚Äôt block out the sound. Arms went berserk, flailing and slamming into walls, machines, and heroes seemingly at random. Silver tried to crawl back, out of its reach, but kept getting slapped further towards its body. The shriek reverberated in her skull, making it impossible to focus on any magic. Hands whirled everywhere, some still dripping with various fluids. Silvery liquid smeared down her right side, causing more tremors as she tried to clean it off, protect her ears, and get out of reach all at the same time. ‚ÄúKill it,‚Äù Zeal whispered, somehow perfectly audible over the cacophony. ‚ÄúShow. No. Mercy.‚Äù - Try to regain enough focus to shoot it again from here. - Try to get up close and finish it off. - Try to get out of range and to safety first. ‚≠ê - (Someone else shows up to help.) @Story Notifications Scene 13 She extended her left arm, trying to aim through all the mess. The unending scream rang in her ears. Arms and hands slammed down around and on top of her. The right side of her body refused to cooperate. Somehow, even with all the distractions, Silver managed to fire another blast of magic at the creature. Severed hands and fingers dotted the ground; the room shook with the monster‚Äôs howl. ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs finish you off,‚Äù he said, again unable to hear himself. 8:34 PM

Mxblah 1/12/2025 6:08 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 14 ... A good while later, Silver sat on a bench in a nearby park, trying to figure out how to eat a hot dog without getting her hero outfit dirty. After wrapping things up with the doorman from the building (both heroes had to sign some papers to affirm the damages caused were from a legitimate battle - for insurance purposes, apparently), Mahogany had decided he wanted lunch. And thus, since Silver had already agreed to talk with him afterwards, she accompanied him to the park and waited for a bit while he found a hot dog vendor. She wasn‚Äôt sure if he had transformed back to actually purchase them or if he somehow had some money in his battle form, but they were both still transformed now, thus drawing some minor attention from the occasional observant passersby. Mahogany‚Äôs outfit was just as flashy as Silver‚Äôs, or potentially even more so. He seemed to be a year or two older than her, with short, spiky, kinda maroonish hair. Really muscular, like ‚Äúprofessional athlete‚Äù level, and it definitely showed through the reddish, not quite skintight bodysuit sorta thing that formed the base of his hero costume. Plates of grey wood accented it at strategic points for protection, or maybe just decency. In any case, the sleeveless design and shorts made it so he was probably showing more skin than her overall. Which Silver definitely hadn‚Äôt noticed. Anyway, Justice was also here, hovering gently overhead and snacking on a bag of chips Mahogany had bought. It was kind of weird to have an angel just hanging out so casually, let along eating. Did he need to do that or was it just for fun? Zeal never ate anything during their lunch breaks; was he running off to the supermarket when she wasn‚Äôt looking? Speaking of, where was he? Silver wasn‚Äôt sure to feel a little worried or a little annoyed, so settled on a bit of both. ‚ÄúSo,‚Äù she decided to begin. ‚ÄúWhat did you want to talk about?‚Äù ‚Äã

9:29 PM

@Story Notifications Scene 16 But... Silver snuck into a secluded area mostly hidden by a row of decorative pillars and transformed back. Silver‚Äôs confidence disappeared with the battle form, leaving behind the really quite terrifying memories of her encounter with the horrible multi-armed creature. @Story Notifications Scene 17 ‚ÄúWh - yes? But no thanks to you; I was worried!‚Äù She glanced around to make sure there weren‚Äôt any people close enough to hear as long as she kept her voice down. 5:52 PM
Traitorously excited at the prospect despite her annoyance with him, Bria couldn‚Äôt quite decide what mood to be in as she walked back from the station to finally return home after a long day. Really, why was it so hard to try to be heroic rather than just being a hero? She became Silver, focused on a particular item she had been holding as Bria, and tried to bring just that part into her battle form. And it was certainly a good thing she hadn‚Äôt tried it out in the park, because it was very easy to slip up and change back entirely. But it wasn‚Äôt as hard as he had implied. Either ‚Äúhe‚Äù - Zeal or Mahogany. Within the space of just a few hours‚Äô practice (and staying up well into the next day), she was able to retrieve her phone, a hairbrush, a notepad, and even her nightshirt (replacing her hero dress) back from her base form. Mxblah 1/20/2025 4:25 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 18 June 28th, 2028 ‚ÄúMornin‚Äô,‚Äù Vanity yawned, showing off her fangs. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs too early, isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs afternoon,‚Äù Lillian reminded her. ‚ÄúWhat were you doing last...‚Äù She yawned too, covering her mouth with one hand. Vanity snickered. ‚ÄúOkay, that was just because yawns are contagious. I‚Äôm not tired.‚Äù Rain speckled the train‚Äôs windows as it gained speed, heading west out of the city. It was past noon, more or less, and this was the first train she could have reasonably made after her obligations in the morning. But... ‚ÄúYou think they‚Äôre still gonna be out there today even in this weather?‚Äù Lillian winced lightly. ‚ÄúLook, the forecast said 30% chance and it was dry this morning. I would have waited if I‚Äôd known it would actually hit that 30%!‚Äù She shook her head. ‚ÄúNo, they‚Äôre still going to be there. You said her angel‚Äôs a really tough one, right?‚Äù ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what my sources say! What else?‚Äù Vanity hummed, doing a flip in midair as she drifted over to the window to see what Lillian was looking at. ‚ÄúBut why? You‚Äôre not even going to steal anything?‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs evil enough to be sneaking around like this, right? I don‚Äôt have to find a proper target as long as she actually pays attention this time. Which is why we‚Äôre going to find her instead of the other way around.‚Äù ‚ÄúBut you aren‚Äôt gonna get anything out of it, right?‚Äù Vani asked, obviously confused. ‚ÄúFighting a hero isn‚Äôt, like, evil; that‚Äôs just why they‚Äôre here. I think it‚Äôd be easier to just do your normal thing. You‚Äôre good at it!‚Äù ‚Äã
4:25 PM
‚ÄúYeah, but...‚Äù Lillian paused, trying to figure out how to explain. Ah! How about- ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a vanity thing. I didn‚Äôt beat her last time - not really - so I need to prove that I can.‚Äù ‚ÄúHmmm...‚Äù the demon hummed. ‚ÄúFlattering! But I don‚Äôt buy it.‚Äù ‚ÄúWha - why not?‚Äù ‚ÄúI can feel~ your intent!~‚Äù she half-sang. ‚ÄúDid ya forget that?~‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù Lillian shuffled in her seat. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs creepy how you guys can just feel emotions directly like that.‚Äù ‚ÄúBut useful!~‚Äù ‚Äú... Yeah. So, why am I doing it, then? Miss empath?‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not telling!~‚Äù ‚ÄúWh - they‚Äôre my emotions; what is not telling me going to do?‚Äù ‚ÄúMaybe you just don‚Äôt know why yourself! And telling you would be cheating!‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù No, I know why. And part of it really is pride, no matter what Vani says. But the other part... ‚ÄúHm? What‚Äôs up?‚Äù she asked, distracted from her thoughts by Vanity‚Äôs ears twitching as she pressed against the window. ‚ÄúI feel a certain grumpy angel nearby!‚Äù she said happily. ‚ÄúMaybe I should go tell him to lighten up a bit!‚Äù ‚ÄúNo!‚Äù Lillian exclaimed. ‚ÄúStay hidden, please! I don‚Äôt want him to know we‚Äôre here yet.‚Äù ‚ÄúOoh, a sneaky mission?‚Äù Vani twirled around in excitement, lowering out of view from outside. ‚ÄúYou got it! Stealth mode on!‚Äù ‚ÄúGood,‚Äù Lillian calmed down. ‚ÄúWhen we get there, can you lead me to the right area without him noticing?‚Äù Vanity did a little salute. ‚ÄúYes sir ma‚Äôam! But my accuracy isn‚Äôt very good with angels or heroes.‚Äù ‚ÄúThen we‚Äôll look around manually. But I don‚Äôt want to transform until I have to.‚Äù ‚ÄúReally? But I thought you liked your battle form way better than your-‚Äù ‚ÄúI do; it‚Äôs not about that! I just-‚Äù She paused, again trying to figure out how to explain. Why was she so adamant on making this a stealth mission, when she‚Äôd obviously have to reveal her presence to do the fight anyway? She wasn‚Äôt planning on doing an ambush or anything. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre gathering intel first. Strengths, weaknesses. I‚Äôm not going to lose again.‚Äù ... ‚Äã
4:25 PM
‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt have picked a worse day to do this,‚Äù Lillian declared a while later, just after slipping on a patch of slick mud and only avoiding falling over by managing to grab a nearby tree. ‚ÄúI wish I could have worn boots at least.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhy didn‚Äôt you?‚Äù ‚ÄúCome on, you know why. I came straight from practice today.‚Äù A few more moments of slogging along the rough path in shoes absolutely not designed for that. She didn‚Äôt want to think about what it would take to clean them later. Honestly, it might be safer to just make up an excuse and come home barefoot than to reveal where she‚Äôd been. ‚ÄúBut also, I didn‚Äôt think it was going to rain. Or that I‚Äôd be searching a whole park while it was raining.‚Äù ‚ÄúAt least it‚Äôs getting a little lighter?‚Äù Lillian sighed, finally escaping the muck onto drier grassy dirt. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad you can be so positive. It‚Äôs actually weirdly encouraging.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs supposed to be encouraging! Why‚Äôs that weird?‚Äù ‚ÄúShh!‚Äù Lillian hissed suddenly, crouching down a little. ‚ÄúDo you hear that?‚Äù A pause; raindrops pattered on leaves. But, ahead, a voice. ‚ÄúWho else would be out here in the rain?‚Äù she whispered. ‚ÄúIt has to be them.‚Äù ‚ÄúMaybe!‚Äù Vanity didn‚Äôt have to be quiet, since only Lillian could hear her. ‚ÄúBe careful! Grumpy angels have really good hearing!‚Äù ‚Äú---‚Äù Lillian agreed, miming zipping up her mouth. She‚Äôd also have to come up with a reasonable excuse for what on earth she was doing if they did catch her. Maybe pretend to be a nature buff or a very lost jogger? No, her outfit didn‚Äôt support either of those stories. Or she could just transform now and not risk anything with her base form, but the angel would definitely notice. When she did transform, she had to be ready to fight. So, for now, just some regular old caution would have to be enough. Rain would mask the sound of her footsteps, at least. ‚Äã
4:25 PM
She crept closer, approaching a secluded clearing near the corner of the park. Lights became visible through the trees, glittering silver on droplet-covered leaves. Success; it was her. Silver was facing slightly away from Lillian, focused on an invisible presence that was thus facing slightly towards her. The angel, probably; she shied back a little. ‚ÄúOkay, ready,‚Äù Silver said, raising both hands. There was a pause as her angel presumably replied, then an assortment of small glowing orbs appeared in midair and rushed towards her. Hands up and coated in discs of faint light; she reached for each orb in turn. And at her touch, they quickly reversed direction with a quiet ping. Well, most of them; there were far too many orbs for her to get them all and a few impacted with similarly quiet smacks. Reflection, Lillian decided. Her signature theme is ‚Äúreflection‚Äù - it has to be. It fits; her outfit is like a bunch of mirrors! ‚ÄúHuh?‚Äù Silver asked after the volley was finished, starting to turn. ‚ÄúOver where?‚Äù ‚Äú!‚Äù The angel must have noticed way faster than expected! Lillian had to- - Run! - Hide! - Make some sort of excuse! [And then...] - Get out of sight briefly, transform, and head in for that fight. - Get somewhere dry and clean up. Don‚Äôt fight right now. (Winners: a tie between and , ) (edited)

Mxblah 1/22/2025 6:02 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 19 -run! Or hide? Lillian couldn‚Äôt decide whether to sprint back down the path to get away or press further back into the foliage to get out of sight, split the difference, and ended up slipping on a slick patch of mud. And... splat. Oh god no - just go! She scrambled to her feet and ran for it. Silver called out from the clearing: ‚ÄúHey! Who‚Äôs there; can I help you?‚Äù Lillian didn‚Äôt respond, but just took a few sliding turns to get out of immediate sight, then focused on trying to find the way out. She wasn‚Äôt being followed, it seemed, so she slowed down to avoid another fall and looked down to see how bad it was. ‚ÄúOuch,‚Äù Vanity commented, hovering overhead. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a real mess!‚Äù ‚Äú... Yeah, it really is.‚Äù There was mud all over her clothes from ankle to waist and on the arm that broke her fall. She could maybe clean some of it off with rainwater or something, but it would be super obvious. Oh, this was a really big problem. Why hadn‚Äôt she just turned around when it started raining? Or at least been a little more careful? Lillian took a few deep breaths, trying to calm down and not think about what would happen if she went home looking like this. Forget fighting Silver for the moment; she had to solve this problem first. ‚ÄúDid you see, like, a laundromat or something?‚Äù ‚ÄúNope! But I bet there‚Äôs one somewhere!‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù Lillian sat down on a bench under a little shelter, trying to wipe away some of the muck with her hands and assistance from the rain. It wasn‚Äôt working very well; she gave up and tried to do the reverse, wiping the muck off her hands to use her phone properly. This was mortifying; maybe it would be worth it to become Violet just for a change of clothes, Silver‚Äôs presence or not. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd have to walk ten minutes, and buy new clothes on the way, and not mess them up too with some other stupid idea.‚Äù ‚ÄúOr steal them!‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not in the mood today,‚Äù she sighed. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve never felt less cool in my life.‚Äù ‚Äã
6:03 PM

Me?‚Äù she asked, trying to play dumb. Silver made it under the roof as well, dry despite the weather. A few straggling raindrops pinged off her hair. Reflection magic. ‚ÄúAre you the person I startled in the woods back there? I‚Äôm really sorry, especially if I made you slip. At least she had been handed a ready-made excuse. ‚ÄúI-I‚Äôm fine. I didn‚Äôt expect to find a hero back there either; I guess I thought you might have been a villain?‚Äù ‚ÄúO-oh! Sorry again! She would have had to be blind not to. ‚ÄúEr, can I help with all that mud somehow? 6:03 PM
‚ÄúWarning: hero training in progress. 6:03 PM

@Story Notifications Scene 20 With that thought in mind, Lillian tried to focus on the more immediate objectives rather than directly interrogating Silver. To start with, that meant finding some new clothes. The top was easy; even in this relatively quiet suburb, there were plenty of random souvenir or graphic t-shirts available all over downtown. But for whatever reason, souvenir or graphic t-shorts (what would that even mean?), or just regular pants, weren‚Äôt as common. Still, it wasn‚Äôt an impossible task and Silver was able to point out a smallish general store nearby that she remembered having something in stock a while ago. This turned out to be correct, which meant both the acquisition of a pair of stretchy, lounge-like sweatpants, and that Silver (or whatever her real name was) probably lived in this town. That had already been pretty likely given this was where she practiced all the time, but it was more evidence. ‚ÄúYou look good!‚Äù Silver decided after Lillian emerged from the changing room (the bathroom) in her new clothes. Nondescript grey sweatpants and a black graphic tee with a stylized lake and forest scene on it, if you were wondering. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to say anything; I know this is a dumb outfit.‚Äù ‚ÄúNo, I mean it! @Story Notifications Scene 21 ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay to take a break if you want to,‚Äù Lillian suggested. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not healthy to spend all your time trying to please some overbearing parent or angel.‚Äù ‚Äú... I‚Äôm just starting college this fall, so it‚Äôs going to be a big change with moving and new classes and people and all that on top of my hero duties - it‚Äôs just a lot all at once.‚Äù ‚ÄúOh. Are you going out of state, then?‚Äù For some reason, the idea didn‚Äôt appeal. ‚ÄúActually, just downtown. But it‚Äôs still a big change from... here!‚Äù ‚ÄúOh! Y-yeah, it is.‚Äù Unexpected relief. 12:08 PM
Time passed as the washer, then the dryer did their respective jobs. Silver and Lillian didn‚Äôt really do anything of note; just sat around and chatted about this and that. School, heroes, parents, angels, but also much more important topics like music or a certain recently-released and very controversial novel. Somehow, despite ostensibly being enemies, it just felt comfortable to Lillian. ‚ÄúCozy,‚Äù perhaps, as Silver had said. It just wasn‚Äôt very often she got to sit around like this without any looming deadline beyond the train that would take her home. ‚ÄúI guess I‚Äôm putting a lot of trust in that anti-recognition enchantment,‚Äù Silver admitted sheepishly as they prepared to leave. ‚ÄúProbably shouldn‚Äôt have said nearly as much as I did, but you‚Äôre just... easy to talk to? If I wasn‚Äôt transformed, I‚Äôd probably ask for your number or something.‚Äù ‚ÄúYeah; I don‚Äôt usually like to talk about my home situation too much either, but today it was fine.‚Äù She hesitated awkwardly, debating saying that they could exchange numbers anyway, but eventually decided against it. Mixing hero and regular identities like that was a recipe for disaster for both of them. If only she could have a conversation like that as Violet then everything would be fine! Or if Silver had transformed back - whatever. ‚ÄúWell, I guess I‚Äôll get going. Hopefully everything‚Äôs fine when you get home. I can‚Äôt tell there was any mud there, if that helps.‚Äù Lillian looked down at her outfit again, even though she had checked it meticulously a few times already. ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs as good as it‚Äôs going to get. They probably won‚Äôt notice anything.‚Äù Another pause; how did you end a conversation? They both had places to be! ‚Äú... Thanks for helping out. I‚Äôll, uh, go catch my train now.‚Äù ‚Äã
12:08 PM
And so she did. It was an uneventful ride into the city, an uneventful transfer, and an uneventful (though busier) ride back out in a different direction. Then she just had to walk over half an hour from the station back to her house on the quieter side of town. She probably would have been expected to take a cab or call for a pickup instead of going all the way herself, but her parents only begrudgingly allowed her to take the train at all and she worried that making it more inconvenient for them might cut off even that lifeline. At least she only had to do this coming back, as the studio was much closer to the station and she got driven there. ‚ÄúGo wash up before dinner, Lillian,‚Äù her mother instructed her when she finally got back. ‚ÄúAnd do be more careful; signs of exertion are unladylike.‚Äù And that was it. As expected, she had only been reprimanded about how tired she looked after all her walking (though mother probably expected she had been doing extra practice or something, not returning from the train station). Nothing about the just-barely visible remnants of her fall. She had gotten away with it. ‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt do anything evil today,‚Äù Vanity noted from somewhere near the ceiling. ‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt even transform!‚Äù It was much later and Lillian‚Äôs room was dark, so it was difficult to pick out the demon amidst the shadows. ‚ÄúI got a lot of information on an enemy through a secret mission; I think that‚Äôs pretty evil.‚Äù ‚ÄúHmmmm...‚Äù she considered. ‚ÄúNope! It‚Äôs only evil if you‚Äôre gonna be evil with that info!‚Äù ‚ÄúAnd who says I‚Äôm not?‚Äù ‚ÄúMe! You didn‚Äôt even want to fight her today, after all the complaining you did saying you wanted to. All week!‚Äù Lillian rolled over in bed, her reply now a little muffled. ‚ÄúLook, it just... wasn‚Äôt the right time. After being with her all day, it just - wasn‚Äôt right.‚Äù ‚ÄúBut the fun of evil is that you get to break the rules! It doesn‚Äôt have to be right to do it.‚Äù ‚ÄúWasn‚Äôt right for me, not in general. I‚Äôll get her next time for sure.‚Äù ‚Äã
12:08 PM
Vani hummed a few measures from a pop song that had been playing in the laundromat earlier. But when she spoke, her tone was a little different than usual. Higher? Maybe just a little more strained? ‚ÄúI like you, Vi-o-let!~ But if you‚Äôre gonna be a villain, you gotta be evil! C‚Äômon, get a good scheme going! Give me something fun to watch, or to help you with! Don‚Äôt just roll around like a... a rolling pin!‚Äù She peeked up a little, trying to see Vani‚Äôs expression after the weird way she had said that. No luck; too dark. ‚ÄúOkay, okay. I‚Äôll do something actually evil. Just let me think about it a little...‚Äù ‚ÄúOkayyy!~ Make it something fun!~‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù [If you have any ideas for evil schemes, suggest them in #story_discussion . Otherwise, Violet will come up with something on her own.] - Make it something involving Silver. - She‚Äôs messing you up. Make it something unrelated to her. - Maybe you‚Äôre messing you up. Mxblah 1/28/2025 8:50 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 22 June 29th, 2028 ‚ÄúYo, Rod,‚Äù Hugo said, waving him over. ‚ÄúYou better have a good excuse for bein‚Äô so late.‚Äù ‚ÄúDo I ever,‚Äù Roderik sighed as he sat down, sliding his backpack onto the bench. They usually met up for Taco Thursday at this very restaurant to take advantage of the weekly specials, but today he was over half an hour late. Hugo, he noted, had started without him. Guy had a bottomless stomach. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre lookin kinda not-great,‚Äù Hugo observed. ‚ÄúGet into a fight on the way here or something?‚Äù ‚ÄúYes, surprisingly. And I‚Äôll tell you all about it after I place an order. Just a minute.‚Äù ‚ÄúReally? Not jokin‚Äô around? Aaand he‚Äôs gone.‚Äù Hugo considered his options, then decided to get more food himself. Obviously it wouldn‚Äôt do to leave his friend the only one eating. A bit later, returned to their seats and refilled on tacos, Hugo prepared to get the details. ‚ÄúAlright, fill me in. What happened? Who started it?‚Äù ‚ÄúOkay, but keep it down. I know it‚Äôs loud in here, but-‚Äù ‚ÄúOh ho ho! It‚Äôs one of those fights.‚Äù He semi-shrugged. ‚ÄúYes, it‚Äôs one of those fights. What, do you think I‚Äôd get into a punch-up myself? No, it was a villain.‚Äù ‚ÄúOne I‚Äôve heard of?‚Äù ‚ÄúI doubt it; I hadn‚Äôt until tonight. Listen, do you want to hear what happened or do you want to keep interrupting?‚Äù ‚ÄúGo on; I‚Äôll shut up.‚Äù Hugo stuffed half a taco into his mouth to prove he could be quiet. ‚ÄúOkay. I was heading here when Vigil sensed a villain nearby, around the north side of downtown. So I had to go check it out, obviously, and I was just in time to hear a really loud burst of wind, metal clanging, and a few seconds of an alarm before it shut off.‚Äù ‚ÄúDaylight robbery?‚Äù Hugo mumbled almost unintelligibly through his mouthful of food. ‚ÄúChew,‚Äù Roderik reminded him. ‚ÄúWhen I got over there, I found a side door blasted open and a villain inside looking like she didn‚Äôt expect it to be so loud.‚Äù ‚Äã

‚ÄúHow‚Äôd you tell that?‚Äù he asked, having swallowed enough to be understandable again. ‚ÄúShe said ‚ÄòDamn, guess it really was that loud‚Äô when I showed up.‚Äù ‚ÄúShe? You find another cute girl to be your new nemesis?‚Äù ‚ÄúI keep telling you; it wasn‚Äôt - whatever. And, no, I doubt she‚Äôs going to be my nemesis, because she won our fight handily. She was like a rocker girl type - piercings, crop top; like you‚Äôd see in a band - and her attacks were all sound-based. Shockwaves and such; my magic wouldn‚Äôt be a good counter even if we were on similar power levels. But the fact that she can summon a weapon means she‚Äôs even more advanced than you, let alone me.‚Äù ‚ÄúDude, you mean I can have a cute girl as my new nemesis?‚Äù ‚ÄúYou know what? Go for it. And I would bet she‚Äôs going to try again somewhere nearby sometime soon, after dark this time.‚Äù ‚ÄúShe tell you that too?‚Äù ‚ÄúNo, but the police showed up shortly after our battle and she had to leave empty-handed. ‚ÄúAs for powers, it‚Äôs like I said; they‚Äôre all sound-based. The blasts from her guitar really got me the most; she‚Äôs way more accurate than you‚Äôd think and it hits hard. If you‚Äôre facing her from the front...‚Äù Roderik paused, arranging his hands as if holding an imaginary instrument. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs holding it like this, right? So you‚Äôll want to head for your right - my left - for the best shot of dodging, I think.‚Äù ‚ÄúDude, it‚Äôs super obvious you have never picked up a guitar. July 1st, 2028 Mahogany yawned deeply, letting his legs swing off the roof into open air. It was just past midnight on Friday night, which he supposed meant it was technically Saturday now. What a way to start his weekend: on stakeout. ‚ÄúAnything yet, J?‚Äù ‚ÄúNothing nearby,‚Äù the angel replied, amusing himself nearby by shuffling a pack of playing cards. Justice claimed he was learning how to play solitaire and that meant he had to know how to shuffle. 8:50 PM

The dude‚Äôs this city‚Äôs number one hero; he hasn‚Äôt lost a fight in years!‚Äù ‚ÄúHis powers rely on water,‚Äù Justice said, spraying cards all across the rooftop with a look of mild disappointment. ‚ÄúTake it away and he becomes powerless. It‚Äôs surely no accident that he spends so much time by the lake.‚Äù ‚ÄúWell, sure, but good luck getting him somewhere with no water,‚Äù Mahogany countered, picking up a few cards that had slid over near him. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs the lake, sure, but also the river, ponds, sewers, main pipes, water fountains; hell, I bet he could use the water inside a human body if he wanted to. You?‚Äù ‚ÄúI know; I know. I‚Äôm turnin‚Äô over a new leaf.‚Äù Mahogany shifted his arms into large, membranous wings. @Story Notifications Scene 23 The two of them slowly descended over the length of a block, Mahogany shifting his ears to increase their sensitivity along the way. And that shift was immediately proven useful when he picked out a muffled crack followed by a few clinks - like the shattered glass of a broken window, for instance. ‚ÄúHeh, right where I thought. Better hurry.‚Äù He maneuvered into a dive and landed not long after, shifting back to his normal form. ‚ÄúSee?‚Äù he asked Justice, pointing out the jagged hole in a nearby glass storefront. String instruments lined a display just inside. ‚ÄúI checked it out ahead of time. I can be responsible when I want to be!‚Äù ‚ÄúVery impressive,‚Äù Justice agreed. ‚ÄúBut where is our perpetrator?‚Äù ‚ÄúInside, I bet. Let‚Äôs go make friends.‚Äù He hopped through the same hole, vaulting the display counter to land in the empty shop itself. No lights; no sound. ‚ÄúHiding?‚Äù he asked at a normal volume. ‚ÄúHey, where‚Äôs the villain who broke that window? Come on out; we gotta talk about what you did to my buddy.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù They both listened for a few seconds. ‚ÄúNothing, really? You afraid or something? Come on, get out here. I‚Äôm not gonna leave till you do.‚Äù Another few seconds of silence. ‚ÄúWell, damn. Guess I‚Äôm playing hide and seek.‚Äù Mahogany walked further into the shop, peeking behind the counter and into a few of the aisles. No one was around, though there were a few more doors. And, interestingly, one was cracked open. ‚ÄúBack room?‚Äù he wondered aloud, pulling it open to reveal a steep, narrow staircase. ‚ÄúGuess not.‚Äù ‚Äã
9:22 PM
As he climbed, faint noises could be heard from upstairs. Rustling, clattering. Like an energetic squirrel, or a burglar. He shifted some muscle mass around to prepare for a fight as he emerged at the top, past another open door, to find himself in a ransacked studio-looking area. Soundproofing, miscellaneous equipment, and just general junk had been thrown all over the place. And, hearing his footsteps and peeking out of a smaller practice room, was exactly who he had been looking for. ‚ÄúSup,‚Äù he said casually. ‚ÄúName‚Äôs Mahogany, or just Hog if you like. My buddy‚Äôs Justice. We‚Äôre here to stop you.‚Äù The villain looked to be about Mahogany‚Äôs age, with a few vibrant blue streaks through her spiky brown hair and startlingly yellow eyes (part of the transformation, he assumed). She was dressed in the sort of punk-esque outfit that Rod had reported: crop top, skinny jeans, belts and spikes and the like. Pretty abnormally normal as far as hero outfits were concerned; honestly, he wasn‚Äôt even sure if she was transformed at all until a gorgeous, metallic blue guitar materialized from a mass of light and dropped into her hands. Definitely a guitar, not a bass; Rod hadn‚Äôt messed that up. Cooler than he had even imagined. ‚ÄúWoah. Hold up, maybe I‚Äôll back up on that ‚Äòhere to stop you‚Äô thing long enough to get your name at least?‚Äù She shifted her grip on the guitar, resting her fingers on the strings. Glittering eddies of light formed into a similarly metallic blue pick as she did so. ‚ÄúLapis. Now turn around and leave if you know what‚Äôs good for you.‚Äù ‚ÄúLapis; sweet. You come here often?‚Äù ‚ÄúIs that a real question-‚Äù ‚ÄúWell, I heard you ‚Äòstopped by‚Äô a shop down the road just a few days ago. Ya like music?‚Äù Lapis briefly glanced down at her guitar. ‚Äú... Is that a real question?‚Äù ‚ÄúJust making conversation. I‚Äôm here to avenge my buddy from Thursday, but we can have a chat first.‚Äù ‚Äã
9:23 PM
‚ÄúOh, you knew him? That guy didn‚Äôt stand a chance and you won‚Äôt either. Last warning; get out or it won‚Äôt be fun for you.‚Äù ‚ÄúI bet it will.‚Äù He shifted a bit more mass into his arms; the distance was close enough to not need too much speed. Just enough to duck to the right. Wait, whose right? What had Rod said...? ‚ÄúYou just here to steal instruments, by the way? Why? You‚Äôve already got a super cool one.‚Äù ‚ÄúObviously I can only use it when transformed!‚Äù Lapis played a single chord concurrently with the last word, releasing a blast of jagged, electric sound straight at Mahogany. He leapt diagonally aside, further into the- ‚ÄúWh-oof!‚Äù He wasn‚Äôt close to fast enough and the shockwave caught him off-center in the chest, throwing him down the stairs and crashing back to the first floor. ‚ÄúDamn,‚Äù he muttered, picking himself up. ‚ÄúHe wasn‚Äôt kidding; she‚Äôs quick.‚Äù ‚ÄúI can be even quicker!‚Äù Lapis shouted from the second floor, strumming another heavy blast down the stairs. This one, Mahogany managed to avoid because he had already been halfway out of the door back into the main shop. Wooden boards strained and brickwork trembled with the vibrations. I probably shouldn‚Äôt leave the store, he decided. It‚Äôs wide open out there and her range is way better than mine. But if I can just get up close and get that guitar away from her... ‚ÄúGet back here!‚Äù she yelled from the staircase. ‚ÄúThought you weren‚Äôt scared!‚Äù ‚ÄúNever said that!‚Äù he called back, retreating to the nearest aisle and preparing to snatch. ‚ÄúJust that I‚Äôd have fun!‚Äù Footsteps. Coming closer; closer... ‚ÄúHa!‚Äù He leapt out of hiding, wrestling the guitar to the side with his shifted strength. Lapis let go to avoid being thrown aside with it - the instrument had no strap probably for situations like this - and then simply screamed at him. ‚Äã
9:23 PM
Mahogany tumbled across the floor and crashed into the opposite wall dizzy and bruised. To add insult to injury, the guitar he had been holding that whole tumble was unharmed and had ended up in his lap in the perfect position to play. Unfortunately, he had no idea how to. Plus, it probably wouldn‚Äôt work for him. ‚ÄúReady to calm the hell down and admit you‚Äôre in over your head?‚Äù she asked smugly, strutting confidently forward to lean over him, one hand on the guitar‚Äôs neck. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll beat as many heroes as it takes till you all leave me alone!‚Äù She tugged at the guitar, but Mahogany held it tightly. ‚ÄúOh, you want this back? Guess you‚Äôd better-‚Äù A sudden shift let him shoulder Lapis away, tossing her inelegantly into a shelf, and run for the window while redirecting mass to his legs and still clutching her guitar. ‚Äú-come get it!‚Äù Having a weapon may make you more powerful, but it sure makes for a big weakness when you can‚Äôt defend it! The guitar dissolved back into light. Mahogany stopped on the sidewalk, turning around to see Lapis peeking out of the broken window. ‚ÄúI can summon it back, dumbass,‚Äù she politely informed him. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt steal it.‚Äù ‚ÄúAh,‚Äù he elegantly replied. ‚ÄúSo that‚Äôs how it works.‚Äù Honestly, he hadn‚Äôt fought a villain with a weapon before. Most of his work was dark spirits and they didn‚Äôt follow the same rules. ‚ÄúYeah, it is. Can you fuck off now and let me get back to it?‚Äù - Let her get back to it. - Obviously not; get back in there and stop her properly! ‚ùî - Talk her out of it in some way. @Story Notifications Scene 24 ‚ÄúNo can do, I‚Äôm afraid. But I‚Äôd be okay with you leaving if you promise not to do it again.‚Äù Lapis scoffed from the window. ‚ÄúYou haven‚Äôt hit me once and you think I‚Äôm gonna run?‚Äù ‚ÄúHey! I knocked you into the shelf like a minute ago!‚Äù ‚ÄúDoesn‚Äôt count; didn‚Äôt hurt. Come on, tough guy, can‚Äôt you do any better?‚Äù Mahogany considered his options as she carefully climbed out of the window to face him, guitar reappearing with a glitter of light. He could charge her right now without thinking about it, but he didn‚Äôt really fancy his chances, despite his words. Even up close, if she could just yell and throw him that far? Ideally, he could convince her to leave peacefully, but diplomacy wasn‚Äôt his strong suit. He didn‚Äôt even know why she was stealing instruments at all! Wait, maybe- ‚ÄúLook, why are you here at all? You just want a guitar for yourself? I can maybe-‚Äù ‚ÄúShut up!‚Äù Another blast of harsh sound, followed up by several more notes forming the intro to a vaguely familiar melody. All angled to catch him no matter which way he went, except... ‚ÄúHup!‚Äù With a full shift to his legs, Mahogany leapt straight up with enough power to crack the sidewalk beneath him. And even still, despite his incredible speed, the first blast caught his feet and spun him crazily in midair. Another rapid shift added wings to his legs instead of his arms - it would take too long to move the mass all the way up there - and he ended up with an unstable variant of the glider from before, angling down towards Lapis. ‚ÄúBank left,‚Äù Justice whispered an invisible suggestion, darting past his ear in the lightning-bolt guise. He didn‚Äôt think about it; just hurled himself in that direction... and dodged another set of powerful notes by inches; shuddering vibrations rippled through his wing membranes. ‚ÄúAnd dive.‚Äù ‚Äã
5:53 PM
He did, just as Lapis aimed further up to cut off his flight path an instant in the future. Another miss, but now he was hurtling towards the ground at a frankly concerning speed. And he definitely hadn‚Äôt practiced with leg-wings nearly as much as the regular sort. Mahogany banked up, shifting the wings away and converting them into more of a smooth, armored plating. This‚Äôll hurt a little, he prepared himself. Like a curled-up armadillo, he hit the ground with a tumbling spin. Protective plates shifted into place across his body as he rolled, replacing the immediate pain with a strange rumble - as if he were a tire on a rough road. He grinned a little as Lapis reacted to his tactics - ‚ÄúWhat the hell-?!‚Äù - and then focused on strengthening the plates further as she surely would get into position in time for one more blast. He heard it, but didn‚Äôt feel anything. She missed? How? But then it made sense, as he rolled on a little longer than planned. He should have hit her by now - uncurl; re-anaylze. Lapis was standing a dozen feet away diagonally, outfit still settling as if she had just landed from a high leap - probably propelled by her last shockwave. He was uncurling a bit past her previous position and now stood in the middle of the street. Good thing there wasn‚Äôt much traffic at this time of night. He grinned, catching his breath after the repeated rapid shifting. ‚ÄúThat any better? I think I‚Äôm figuring you out.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat the hell is your theme?‚Äù she asked warily. ‚ÄúMutations?‚Äù ‚ÄúShapeshifting,‚Äù he declared proudly. ‚ÄúAnd it doesn‚Äôt have‚Äôta be super obvious like I just did; it can get real delicate too. Wonder how I heard you from so far away earlier? Shifted ears.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù A slight change of footing. ‚ÄúNot gonna save you.‚Äù ‚ÄúOh yeah?‚Äù An idea occurred to him; a way to get out of this without having to beat her up. ‚ÄúHow ‚Äòbout this: you hit me with your strongest shot, and I‚Äôll prove I can shrug it off no problem. Then you give up and leave. Sound good?‚Äù ‚Äã
5:54 PM
A look of disbelief. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre jokin‚Äô. You‚Äôll be paste.‚Äù ‚ÄúC‚Äômon, have some faith. Tanky as an elephant, I can be. But it‚Äôs sweet you‚Äôre worried about me.‚Äù ‚ÄúFuck off; I just don‚Äôt wanna get charged with murder. That‚Äôs a quick way to get Aquamarine on my ass.‚Äù ‚ÄúOh, so you‚Äôre scared of him but not of me? Come on, give it your best shot. Promise I won‚Äôt die!‚Äù ‚ÄúAre you sure it is wise to anger her like this?‚Äù Justice whispered in his ear, still invisible. ‚ÄúDo you truly have that much confidence in your constitution?‚Äù He winked, murmuring a response. ‚ÄúGotta have faith, J. I‚Äôve got a plan.‚Äù ‚ÄúY‚Äôknow what?‚Äù she shouted. ‚ÄúFine! No dodging; just hold still. If you‚Äôre still standing, I‚Äôll give up. But if not, you can‚Äôt bother me again. Got it?‚Äù A thumbs up. ‚ÄúWorks for me!‚Äù Lapis breathed out; focused. Mahogany smiled; shifted. She played a full song. Well, the first verse of one. Mahogany didn‚Äôt recognize it, unlike the partial melody from earlier, but he kind of wanted to listen to it properly later when it wasn‚Äôt trying to kill him. Strong guitar lead (obviously), but with enough missing identity to imply the existence of several other parts. Original? Was she in a band? Anyway, he had to focus on surviving the blast before appreciating the composition. Hearing was stifled dramatically and he shifted most of his body mass forward into a set of thick, angled armor plates to break and deflect as much of the impact as possible. Behind that, flexible connection points to absorb any remaining vibrations and cushion the vital organs he couldn‚Äôt move or change without damaging them. He even anchored himself to the pavement with a set of fine, chitinous hooks to avoid being thrown clear across the road. Of all the things to give way in this setup, he honestly didn‚Äôt expect it to be the street. ‚Äã
5:54 PM
The concrete holding him to the ground crumbled under repeated, powerful shocks, and Mahogany went flying. He had enough presence of mind to curl and angle properly, adding a little more protection to his relatively unarmored back, but he didn‚Äôt have much mass or time to work with - it was always harder to make or dissolve armor and bone than more flexible muscle and flesh. He did in fact go clear across the street, slamming improbably into a street sign on the other side and bending the metal severely. Armor cracked, but not bones. His protection did its job and by the time Lapis finally concluded her guitar solo, he was still alive and kicking. ‚ÄúHa!‚Äù he called across the street, taking in the ripped-up pavement and storefronts littered with chunks of broken concrete as he slowly got up. ‚ÄúStill standing! Guess you aren‚Äôt as strong as you think!‚Äù ‚ÄúOh yeah? What do you call what you were just doing, then? On the ground?‚Äù He looked down. ‚ÄúReally? You‚Äôre gonna say you won just because the road gave out?‚Äù ‚ÄúYou weren‚Äôt standing when I finished.‚Äù ‚ÄúBut I‚Äôm standing now!‚Äù ‚ÄúThat wasn‚Äôt the deal!‚Äù ‚Äú... You - that‚Äôs just a - J, help me out here.‚Äù The angel appeared in the middle of the street, hovering serenely over the destruction. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm afraid the wording was ambiguous. Neither of you specified a timeframe during which Hog had to be standing in order to be considered successful. I may suggest considering the contest invalid and ensuring a proper set of rules for a future repetition.‚Äù ‚ÄúWas that really helping?‚Äù Mahogany muttered, but Lapis seemed to agree. ‚ÄúFine; neither one of us has to leave. But you‚Äôre looking pretty hurt and I‚Äôm all fresh. And you still haven‚Äôt hit me even once! You sure you want to keep going?‚Äù ‚Äã
5:54 PM
‚Äú...‚Äù Despite his trademark bravado, she was at least partly correct. He had blocked a good portion of the impact, but between the magic itself, hitting the street sign, and all the shifting to avoid damage, he was close to spent. But... ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre lookin‚Äô pretty tired too,‚Äù he noted, taking a few steps forward and causing Lapis to lift her guitar again. ‚ÄúBet it took a lot outta you to use that attack.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù She didn‚Äôt respond before both of them heard something else: the rapidly-approaching sound of emergency vehicle sirens. ‚ÄúI guess that was pretty damn loud,‚Äù Mahogany decided. ‚ÄúOkay, I‚Äôm willin‚Äô to fight some more till the cops show up. In fact, lemme start!‚Äù He jogged forward, slowly returning to his normal form as he had a feeling he‚Äôd need to transform back pretty soon. Once Lapis- ‚ÄúFine! Hell; you explain this to them.‚Äù She dissolved the guitar back into light, then ran into the alley right next to the instrument shop. Mahogany didn‚Äôt give chase; she‚Äôd transform back as soon as she got out of sight and he‚Äôd never be able to find her. Plus, even if he did, she might very well beat him. Ow. He found himself grinning again as he decided what to do next. God, she was great. - Reluctantly stay and explain it to the cops as Mahogany. - Transform back and get outta there. Go to bed as Hugo. [Violet‚Äôs evil scheme takes place...] ‚åõ - Roughly now, in fact. ‚è∞ - The next day. - Skip it; pick up on July 4th. (Winners: , ‚è∞ ) (edited)

Mxblah 2/3/2025 7:54 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 25 Mahogany did consider staying to explain to the cops; he really did. But they really loved to make him do too much paperwork and it was late and he was very tired after the fight. They‚Äôd figure it out without him. With that thought, he ducked into a nearby doorway, checked for cameras, and changed back to his base form. Then, Hugo departed the scene moments before the first few cop cars arrived. Right now, he just wanted to go to sleep. ... ‚ÄúAnyone looking?‚Äù Lillian whispered, poised quietly at her bedroom door. ‚ÄúNope! All clear!‚Äù Vani answered, excited for the heist. ‚ÄúYou should have a minute or two.‚Äù Lillian nodded, eased open the door, and closed it just as silently. Then it was a quick but careful tip-toe down the stairs, across the dark, still house, through the garage, and finally out the side door into the humid and still annoyingly warm night air. She locked it behind her and hustled out to the street, finally returning to a normal walking pace after turning a corner to get out of any possible sightlines. ‚ÄúPhew. But now we have to hurry. The bus is...‚Äù She fumbled through her bag in the semi-dark between streetlights while half-jogging. ‚Äú... Four minutes away. I can make that.‚Äù ‚ÄúGo! Run for it!‚Äù Vani egged her on from above, yelling as loud as she wanted without having to fear attracting any attention. Lillian tried to be a little more discreet, jogging with a balance between speed and stealth. But she really did not want to miss the bus, so speed won out as it got closer and closer to the stop on her tracker. It wasn‚Äôt stopping at all, which made sense at this time of night. It was well past 11pm; no one would be on board. She normally wouldn‚Äôt be on board either, and her parents definitely wouldn‚Äôt approve. Going out alone? At night? In the dark? Taking (gasp) public transport? No way, no how. She just didn‚Äôt tell them. It worked as long as she was careful. ‚Äã
7:55 PM
Lillian made it to the stop moments before the bus, only able to beat it there due to a fortunate red light at the preceding intersection. A tap, a beep, and off she went, alone aside from the driver (who thankfully didn‚Äôt seem the chatty type). She caught her breath in the back, checking the timetables once more to make sure she‚Äôd be able to get home. The 1:44am departure still showed as ‚Äúon time,‚Äù though the actual vehicle hadn‚Äôt even left its origin yet. That was the last one until the morning; if she missed it, she‚Äôd be stuck walking home in the dead of night for possibly hours. Lillian hadn‚Äôt bothered researching just how long it would take. She‚Äôd make that bus. Vanity kept bouncing around near the ceiling, muttering something about bread. Lillian didn‚Äôt say anything; she was busy planning and also didn‚Äôt want to seem crazy in case the driver looked back to check on her. At least this way, swiping through timetables and maps on her phone, she‚Äôd look the part of a... what stereotype did she resemble right now? Hopefully not a suspicious one. She got off the bus at the annoyingly-named ‚ÄúMarketplace Corner‚Äù stop, which was neither a marketplace nor a corner, then walked another few minutes across the gigantic parking lot to the market the stop ostensibly served: the town‚Äôs biggest (and only) general supermarket box store. 11:50pm exactly; just under two hours to enact her evil plan and make it back to the bus stop on the other side of the street. Not for the first time, she wished Violet‚Äôs powers included flight, teleportation, or at least super speed. But aside from the enhanced endurance that made it easier to run for longer, no such luck. ‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù she said to Vani, hurrying into the store before it closed in just 10 minutes. ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs do this.‚Äù ‚Äã
7:55 PM
She transformed in the bathroom, ignored the warnings about the store closing being played over the announcement system, and made her way towards the back. She spotted an employee once, but a little application of her new technique - ‚ÄúSleep mist!‚Äù - took care of that and it was like she‚Äôd never been here at all. ‚ÄúDo you think it‚Äôs like falling asleep or like passing out?‚Äù Vani wondered overhead as Violet continued walking. ‚ÄúWhen you get ‚Äòem with the mist?‚Äù ‚ÄúWant me to try it on you and find out?~‚Äù ‚ÄúHehehe! It wouldn‚Äôt work! But maybe try it on you~ later - it could help you go to bed after a tiring night of evil schemes!‚Äù She considered the potential application as a sleep aid, but filed that away for later as she pushed through one of the large doors into the stock room. ‚ÄúIf I read the schedule right, the truck we want should be arriving in... ten minutes. More or less.‚Äù ‚ÄúGonna find somewhere to hide or just take ‚Äòem all out?‚Äù Vani made fake martial-arts movements in the air, chopping and kicking at imaginary enemies. ‚ÄúKapow! Sleepytime!‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôd prefer to hide, if I can. I don‚Äôt want to alert any of the security guys too early; I bet they remember me from last time.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou think they‚Äôll have guns this time?!~‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù She quietly doubted it - that seemed probably illegal? - but they were really mad last time. ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs hope not,‚Äù she decided. ‚ÄúThat might be a little much for me.‚Äù ‚ÄúNo way! You can take ‚Äòem! Shapow! Bang! Poison gas!‚Äù ‚ÄúDid you take a caffeine pill or something? You‚Äôre even more hyper than usual.‚Äù ‚ÄúI just get hyped up when my little hero is doin‚Äô something cool! You‚Äôre gonna be the coolest, impressive-ist person in town after this!‚Äù ‚ÄúI hope so. Alright, maybe up here?‚Äù Violet climbed up a set of shelves, nestling between a set of boxes with a good view of the loading dock. ‚ÄúNo one ever looks up, right?‚Äù ‚ÄúKapow!‚Äù ‚Äã
7:55 PM
She grinned slightly, gaining just a bit of energy even at this late hour. ‚ÄúY‚Äôknow, maybe I can let loose just a little. It‚Äôs been a while since I‚Äôve had just a solid scheme going on.‚Äù - Let loose. Just a little. As a treat? Vani will approve, too. - Try to keep it contained. Mxblah 2/5/2025 9:39 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 26 July 2nd, 2028 The truck did not show up in ten minutes, but thankfully it wasn‚Äôt much longer after that; she didn‚Äôt want to run into problems with time. A pair of workers opened the loading dock‚Äôs door and helped guide the semi into position, eventually opening its rear door as well to get at the contents inside. Namely, boxes upon boxes worth of bread and bread-adjacent foodstuffs (pastries, doughnuts, that sort of thing) from the chain‚Äôs own brands. Her original plan had been to somehow steal an entire pallet of bread and feed it to ducks at the park. But it had been hampered by two major concerns. First: how to actually move the pallet. She didn‚Äôt have telekinesis or super strength and it was quite a way from here to there. She couldn‚Äôt exactly bring it on a bus. And second: it turned out after some research that bread actually wasn‚Äôt good for ducks and she didn‚Äôt want to mess them up that much, no matter how funny it would be. So the plan had shifted. If not the ducks, what else could she do with a pallet of bread? And if it was too hard to move it on its own... Violet noted the truck driver yawning as he walked into the store to compare paperwork with the workers there. The grin from before came back. ... Well, it would sure be a lot easier to move if she didn‚Äôt take it out of the semi at all. ‚ÄúSleep mist,‚Äù she whispered, dispersing a cloud of the substance across the three visible workers. It worked very quickly on regular people, especially those who were clearly pretty tired already. Within moments, they were asleep on the floor. Violet hopped down from her perch and scampered across the open area to reach the bubble, double checking to make sure her hood was up before crossing the faintly shimmering boundary. All good; she didn‚Äôt pass out. A huge bounty of high-carb food awaited her. ‚Äã
9:39 PM
‚ÄúWell, off we go,‚Äù she said cheerily, shoving the heavy doors shut. ‚ÄúBetter hurry before someone finds these guys. Vani, can you check the parking lot?‚Äù ‚ÄúYou got it!‚Äù Off she went. Violet pilfered a large, truck-looking key from the driver and casually hopped down from the loading dock to test it out. The door opened and the engine started. She now sat at the wheel of the largest vehicle she had ever attempted to drive, sitting way too low and way too far back in the seat. Where were the controls? ‚ÄúVi-o-let~!‚Äù Vani sang as she returned. ‚ÄúSomeone‚Äôs coming~!‚Äù ‚ÄúHm?‚Äù She looked up from fiddling with the seat controls. ‚ÄúWho? Did they notice anything?‚Äù ‚ÄúSome grumpy guy in dark blue. He‚Äôs got a guuunn~!‚Äù ‚ÄúBlue? Like, a cop? You do know what cops look like; I know you do.‚Äù ‚ÄúDunno. I don‚Äôt think so, but he‚Äôs really maaad!‚Äù ‚ÄúAh, screw the seat then,‚Äù Violet decided. ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs just go! Lillian had gotten her driver‚Äôs license somewhat recently and had a reasonable amount of experience driving normal, regular-sized cars. Violet, while primarily the same person, had very different opinions on traffic safety, reasonable speed limits, and (of course) stealing giant semi trucks from supermarkets. All that is to say that, while Violet understood how to operate the truck in principle, doing so in practice was an entirely different matter. ‚ÄúSure is nice that there aren‚Äôt any cars around!‚Äù Vani said over the wind as Violet clipped a stop sign and blew straight through two rows of parking spaces as well as the intersection the sign had marked. ‚ÄúI can go fast,‚Äù Violet agreed, jostling over a dip in the road. ‚ÄúWhich way to the lake? It‚Äôs left, right?‚Äù ‚ÄúDid you say left or right?‚Äù ‚ÄúI said left, right! Like, left!‚Äù ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs right!‚Äù ‚ÄúSo, left?‚Äù ‚ÄúRight!‚Äù She looked up at Vanity interrogatively. ‚ÄúOkay, enough of the slapstick act; I actually need to know which way to go.‚Äù ‚ÄúLeft! Yeehaw!‚Äù ‚Äã
9:39 PM

After going probably a little too fast over probably a little too large of a bump, something very loud happened in the back. The mirrors weren‚Äôt adjusted properly for someone of Violet‚Äôs height, so it was initially difficult to see what had happened. But with some help from Vani, it quickly became obvious: the rear door had fallen open and a bunch of boxes had tumbled onto the main road. Violet slowed the truck, intending to hop out and lock it properly this time (only now realizing she had forgotten to do that initially), when they encountered their second hurdle. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the fuzz!‚Äù Vani shouted maniacally, twirling in midair to indicate one of the rearmost-facing mirrors. Mxblah 2/7/2025 10:28 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 27 Violet floored it, but that only dropped more stuff out the back and also made it way too risky to turn. She couldn‚Äôt keep that up without crashing the truck. So, a different idea came to mind. ‚ÄúVani, take the wheel!‚Äù she shouted, rolling down the window to poke her head and arms out the side. Wind whipped at her hair and Vani‚Äôs maniacal, unstable driving wasn‚Äôt making it any easier, but she could do it. The bubbles were large and her aim was good. Focus; get it exactly right, and... ‚ÄúSleep mist!‚Äù A translucent bubble sprang up in front of the line of cop cars, essentially invisible in the night. Some swerved or slowed, but they were still coming. Made sense; they were going fast and the cars would be blocking much of the mist anyway. But... ‚ÄúSleep mist!‚Äù She could just... ‚ÄúSleep mist!‚Äù Keep making more... ‚ÄúSleep mist!‚Äù Until... The lead car drifted too far right at the next intersection and glanced off a traffic light, spinning crazily to crash into a sturdy building just beyond. Several other cars met similar fates, tumbling over curbs or - in the most brutal of the crashes - missing a turn and slamming directly into a storefront. Flames spilled from the building. The remaining cars cut their losses and stopped pursuit. Probably their best option, given that it was certainly clear they were dealing with a villian of some description. Would they know who Violet was? Probably; she had caused trouble around here several times before. Never to this extreme, though. The better question, however, was ‚Äúwhat were they going to do about it?‚Äù ‚ÄúLemme take that back,‚Äù she said, sliding back into the driver‚Äôs seat as Vanity spun back towards the ceiling, cackling. ‚ÄúBoom! 10:29 PM
More emergency sirens pierced the night behind them as fire trucks and ambulances raced towards the carnage she had just created. Try it!‚Äù Violet leaned out the window again, squinting against the wind and glare. Her range wasn‚Äôt really that good, but the helicopter was flying somewhat low... ‚ÄúSleep mist!‚Äù No change in its flight pattern. She couldn‚Äôt even see the bubble in the dark to see how badly she had missed. Another few failed attempts solidified it; either she was out of range or just couldn‚Äôt aim well enough. Or they were wearing gas masks, or- They were at the lake in another few minutes, leaving the bulk of the city behind as flames and emergency lights painted the bottom of a large cloud of smoke downtown. The truck rumbled over uneven roads; she slowed somewhat to avoid toppling over. Most of the boxes had fallen out by now. The helicopter still hovered somewhere overhead. ‚ÄúReady for the finaaale?‚Äù she asked. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the finale?!‚Äù To be honest, this part of the plan wasn‚Äôt very well thought-out. She had initially kinda intended to do a loop towards the main city - to the south - in order to ditch the truck somewhere so that other people could just take all the food that she couldn‚Äôt steal herself. But with the cops hot on her tail, that probably wasn‚Äôt much of an option at this point. Hence the detour to the lake. If she wanted to annoy this corporation as much as possible (which she did, hence why she almost exclusively targeted them), there was one good way to make sure of it. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre GOIN‚Äô IN!‚Äù She drove the truck into the lake. ‚Äã
10:29 PM
More than a dozen tons of truck rolled down the boat launch and straight into the water at pretty high speeds. Violet dramatically underestimated the slowing power of slamming directly into a lake - and had inadvisedly taken off her seatbelt to sling mist at her pursuers - so she was immediately flung into the steering wheel hard enough to see stars. Water flooded the cabin through the open window; she spluttered and tried to get her bearings before plunging beneath the waves in only a matter of seconds. Violet broke the surface a few moments later, gasping for air and still dazed from the hit to the head. But she tried to appreciate the spectacle anyway, treading water as the semi rapidly sunk, fountaining air from hidden compartments. ‚ÄúAnd th-that‚Äôs the... finale.‚Äù God damn, her head hurt. Vanity was thrilled, though. ‚ÄúWhat a splash! Bread everywhere! The fish are gonna love it!‚Äù Similar compliments peppered the beleaguered villain as she swam back to shore - only to remember that she was still being tracked by a helicopter, now a very long way from the bus she intended to catch back home, and had just dumped her ride in the lake. She may have gotten just a little bit carried away. ‚ÄúOkay,‚Äù Violet decided, holding her forehead to try and think better. ‚ÄúFirst thing: lose the cops. Gotta... find somewhere to change back...‚Äù She was standing on the eastern shore of the town‚Äôs lake, near the boat launch and marina. The town proper was directly in front of her, but she could already hear more approaching emergency sirens - presumably they were more confident now that she had sunk the truck. There were semi-mansions along the lakeshore; she could hide amongst the suburbia or try her luck in some of the small patches of trees nearby. Or, of course, dive back into the lake. Would that fool the helicopter? ‚Äã
10:29 PM
And she had to make it back to somewhere on that bus line... sometime soon, probably. What time was it? She didn‚Äôt have a watch and her phone was with her base form. She‚Äôd check after transforming back. - Lose them in the town proper! Mxblah 2/9/2025 2:07 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 28 The helicopter was the biggest problem right now and there was only one nearby option that offered anything akin to a roof. Violet hurried towards the long, narrow band of trees that separated the mansion zone from the town proper and slipped under the canopy. Great, now it probably couldn‚Äôt see her anymore. But if she just changed back and popped out, she‚Äôd probably be taken in for questioning even if they didn‚Äôt make the connection between her forms. And that would be really, really bad for really, really obvious (parent-related) reasons. So she had to get fully clear of the area and not just rely on the anti-recognition enchantment. Okay; it was fairly dark here outside of the town proper, at least if she got away from the helicopter‚Äôs searchlight. And the line of trees stretched quite a distance to wrap around the lake. The beginnings of a plan began to take shape. ‚ÄúShadow mist,‚Äù she whispered a minute later, three times over. Three bubbles of darkness (more than she could have done at once even a week ago) appeared in three careful locations, each bridging different gaps between this band of trees and one of several buildings where she could theoretically hide from the helicopter under overhangs or similar. ‚ÄúWhich one are you going to check?‚Äù she asked the sky as she jogged up the band. Apparently, it decided to check all three of them in order. South to north, based on its position when she had started this. Which would have been a good idea... if she hadn‚Äôt quickly crossed in the open while it was otherwise occupied, relying on the night‚Äôs darkness to hide her and her own darkness to act as a distraction. It started circling to try and pick her up, and at this point another set of cop cars had arrived at the crashed semi, but Violet was fairly fast and had fairly good endurance; she could run for a good while to get out of range. All it took was that one initial leap to give her a minute to do just that. ‚Äã
2:07 PM
‚ÄúI think we‚Äôre clear,‚Äù she decided after a while, now close enough to the still lightly populated downtown to be comfortable blending in as Lillian. So she dipped into a convenient corner, transformed back, and slipped out onto the normal streets again. S-surely, she hadn‚Äôt... ‚ÄúVani, do you think those are...‚Äù Lillian trailed off, both because she was unwilling to finish the question (Vani didn‚Äôt seem to mind) and because she had spotted something concerning in a different way to look at. There was a girl with impractically long, impractically pink hair, wearing what was obviously some sort of frilly pink hero costume, talking with a cop. Lillian couldn‚Äôt hear anything they were saying from here - and certainly couldn‚Äôt get closer - but it was clear the hero wasn‚Äôt being interrogated. In another minute or so, she lifted gently into the air and shot upwards to leave behind a sparkly light trail. ‚Äã
2:07 PM
‚ÄúShe can fly?!‚Äù Lillian asked Vani a bit later, now jogging to not miss her bus. ‚ÄúWho was that?‚Äù ‚ÄúHmmm, hmmm!‚Äù Vani rubbed her head, acting out the act of thinking. ‚ÄúI think that‚Äôs my lovely enemy Com-pass-ion~‚Äôs partner! Usually, heroes with the power of flight would only be able to hover or glide at first, slowly gaining ability as they matured. 2:07 PM

Mxblah 2/11/2025 9:27 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 29 Well... Violet was a fairly new hero of darkness. She had met Vanity less than a year ago and had agreed to the deal because she just needed something to do where she didn‚Äôt have to be the person her parents wanted her to be. Going out and stealing from the box store, or causing some minor property damage, or putting down blinding mist in inconvenient but funny places - that was the extent of it. Just some harmless (well, minimally harmful) antics to get it out of her system, you know? But over time, things had escalated. Just a bit, but it hadn‚Äôt felt as cool or rewarding or generally fun to do the same little things every time. Vani encouraged her to think bigger. More exciting. To branch out. Even so, tonight had been a pretty massive escalation. She hadn‚Äôt intended to steal the entire truck in her original plan, and even after deciding to do so at the last minute, she really hadn‚Äôt intended to get into a car chase. But once she had... Well. Even just in her thoughts, the question ‚ÄúDid I actually kill someone?‚Äù was too difficult to ask. The image of those two white-sheeted bodies was too uncomfortable to recall. So, instead, she rationalized. She couldn‚Äôt have. Her sleep mist only made people drowsy, then put them to sleep. Obviously. She hadn‚Äôt used her poison mist, or even the shadow mist that could have blinded a driver and caused a crash. The cars had some level of airtightness, and they were going fast, so it would have been given in small doses. They would have had plenty of time to realize what was happening, slow down, and give up. It wasn‚Äôt her fault, even if anything had happened. Even if anything had happened, it had been because they just didn‚Äôt make the right decision. That‚Äôs all. Thoughts like this occupied her mind on the ride, then walk, then slow, careful climb back up the stairs to her room. Where, finally, Lillian could fall into bed and utterly fail to sleep. ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚Äã
9:27 PM
Well, now was as good a time as any. Hiding under her covers to conceal the lightshow, Lillian transformed back into Violet in order to cast the sleep mist on herself. Maybe it would work. Maybe she‚Äôd be able to just go to sleep. Oop, hood down first. Then, ‚ÄúSleep mist,‚Äù she whispered, casting it just above her bed. Within moments, she felt her eyelids getting heavy. Violet only barely had enough time to remember that maybe she should transform back in case anyone barged into her room, then do that, before she passed out entirely. It sure was a good thing that the mist bubbles only lasted a matter of minutes before dissipating, or she might never have woken up. But it sure wasn‚Äôt such a good thing that the mist only helped her get to sleep, and not necessarily get a good sleep. Lillian‚Äôs dreams that night weren‚Äôt exactly pleasant. ... July 4th, 2028 ‚ÄúYo, Silver, you made it.‚Äù Mahogany nodded to her, then at the person leaning against the wall nearby. ‚ÄúThis‚Äôs Granite. Dude I was telling you about.‚Äù ‚ÄúHi; good to meet you.‚Äù There was an awkwardly formal handshake. ‚ÄúSo, what‚Äôs he been telling you?‚Äù Granite asked. ‚ÄúAll my best heroic exploits, I assume?‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù Silver didn‚Äôt immediately answer, but her expression said enough. ‚ÄúAll my worst heroic exploits, I see.‚Äù He sighed good-naturedly. ‚ÄúWouldn‚Äôt expect anything less from this goober. But don‚Äôt worry, he told me only good things about you.‚Äù ‚ÄúReally?‚Äù She felt like she had to share at least something embarrassing about her own performance, given that Granite was of course completely correct. ‚ÄúHe skipped the part where I had just been knocked out and was probably about to be eaten when we first met?‚Äù ‚ÄúNo, he must have left that part out.‚Äù He leaned just a bit closer, as if to exclude Mahogany from the conversation without actually lowering his voice. ‚ÄúThis man is a very unreliable storyteller. Don‚Äôt trust a word he says about someone else.‚Äù ‚Äã
9:27 PM
‚ÄúOi! Stop dissing my good name!‚Äù Mahogany shouldered in. ‚ÄúI was just tryin‚Äô to be nice about my new friend!‚Äù ‚ÄúAnd not about your old friend?‚Äù As the two of them half-argued, half-joked with each other, Silver took a moment to look over Granite‚Äôs outfit. He seemed about her age, with short sand-colored hair partially covered by a futuristic-looking visor/helmet sort of thing. His main theme color seemed to be tan, like an expensive countertop, which matched fairly well with his sort of park ranger-esque hero outfit. Really, she didn‚Äôt know how to describe it any better; aside from some obvious sci-fi touches here and there (such as the visor, some inlays on the vest, and circuit-looking designs on the pants) it seemed like he could be giving tours at a mountain or forest or something. ‚ÄúAnyway, enough about that,‚Äù Mahogany waved the conversation away. ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs get goin‚Äô. Sil, you good to go?‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm good. But I can‚Äôt be too long or my parents will get worried. I came here with them.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe can take breaks; no worries. Let‚Äôs give it, say, a good half-hour to start with and see what we find? Sound good, G; Sil?‚Äù Two expressions of assent. Off they went. ‚Äã
9:27 PM
Silver, Mahogany, and Granite were in the city, near the river, and specifically at one of the many firework festivals across the country today, the most American of all days. Fireworks attracted people, people attracted dark spirits, and huge crowds of people attracted huge crowds of spirits. Huge crowds of dark spirits, then, drew heroes to fight them. There were almost certainly other heroes - and likely villains - mixed in with the crowd tonight for similar reasons, so these three heroes had decided to stick together in order to track down and destroy as much evil as they could find. Preferably before it ruined anyone‚Äôs night. - All goes well until it‚Äôs time for Bria to check in with her parents. - Wait, who‚Äôs that? - Wait, who‚Äôs that?! - Wait, who‚Äôs that? - Wait, who‚Äôs that?! (Winners: a tie between and . Both were chosen by author discretion) (edited)

Mxblah 2/13/2025 8:57 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 30 The festival was large, lively, and filled with enough distractions that even their group of three transformed heroes didn‚Äôt draw much attention. Beyond just the fireworks, the streets along the riverbank were closed to cars for the event and populated by many dozens of pop-up stands or performances of all kinds. Music overlapped from various instruments at conflicting tempos and volumes. The atmosphere wasn‚Äôt exactly harmonious, but it was still energizing. ‚ÄúHey, that reminds me,‚Äù said Mahogany as they followed a mostly-invisible Justice towards their first target. ‚ÄúI was trying to see if I could at least find the song that villain I told you about was playing, even if I couldn‚Äôt find her, but it didn‚Äôt work. As ya might expect.‚Äù ‚ÄúAre you saying this band sounds somewhat familiar?‚Äù He tilted his head, listening. ‚ÄúMaybe. S‚Äôpretty good either way. And their lead guitar‚Äôs pretty cute too.‚Äù ‚ÄúHonestly,‚Äù Granite said, peering over the crowd to get a better view. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre quite tactless sometimes.‚Äù ‚ÄúHuh? Why?‚Äù ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt mind,‚Äù Silver reassured them. ‚ÄúAs long as you‚Äôre not going to try anything weird with me.‚Äù ‚ÄúOh!‚Äù Mahogany figured it out. ‚ÄúNah, all good. You‚Äôre cute, but not really my type of cute. Unless you‚Äôre secretly a badass guitarist?‚Äù ‚Äú... Nope.‚Äù ‚ÄúJust hero pals, then. Like me ‚Äòn Granite! You know, one time last summer, there was a limbo contest and-‚Äù ‚ÄúI believe we‚Äôre here,‚Äù Granite hurriedly interrupted. ‚ÄúJustice?‚Äù ‚ÄúYes,‚Äù the angel affirmed, hovering about a story above their heads. ‚ÄúIt appears to be a humanoid-type. Limited threat to any of you; low range.‚Äù ‚ÄúHa!
