Mxblah 4/29/2025 8:46 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 62 ‚ÄúViolet!‚Äù she coughed. ‚ÄúDrop the poison, please!‚Äù No immediate response. Maybe she was too busy to dispel it; maybe she was too hurt. Whatever the case, Silver had to deal with it herself. And quickly. She did have that idea about an air filter sort of thing she had tried on the mist the last time they fought, but it hadn‚Äôt worked very well and she hadn‚Äôt been able to test any changes since then. Still, there was no better time than now. Except... Silver shifted in the monster‚Äôs many-handed grip. She couldn‚Äôt split her focus like that in such a stressful situation; raising up the filter barrier would bring down the one that was currently keeping her un-crushed. But if she didn‚Äôt do something about that poison very soon, being crushed wouldn‚Äôt be her biggest problem. She changed focus, pushing the deadly air away from her mouth and nose with an unconscious filter, since she obviously couldn‚Äôt interrogate each air molecule herself. Poison: reflect. Air: let through. Somehow her magic would figure out which was which. Air grew denser to her senses, making breathing harder, but there was at least a partial success. Less pain in her airways; less dizziness in her head. Not a perfect system, but an improvement. Of course, pain from the monster crushing her torso quickly replaced any pain from the poison. Bad; maybe even worse. Silver tried to regain her earlier reflective barrier, but the filter wavered when she even thought about it. Too complicated; she couldn‚Äôt envision both at once. But there was a different kind of magic that was much simpler. Drawing on her unattuned intent to stop this horrible creature, Silver wreathed her fist in light and strained against the thing‚Äôs grip. By wiggling just right, she could contest each arm one at a time rather than all at once: a contest her enhanced strength could win. ‚Äã
8:46 PM
She pulled her hand out of the constricting mess and leveled it at the thing‚Äôs tiny head, already smoking from her previous attack. At this range, there could be no missing. An explosion of light and splattering liquid. Silver blacked out. ... Bria woke up some time later with almighty bruises on her ribs and an incredible headache. Her lungs felt like they were full of sand. But she wasn‚Äôt dead. And, without even needing to look around, it was obvious that the monster was. Mainly because it was crumpled in a heap on the floor and Zeal was blurrily visible doing... something to make it disappear. The cleanup portion. Wait a minute- ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre awake!‚Äù someone suspiciously Violet-sounding gasped from nearby. Quickly, Violet appeared upside-down in her field of view to confirm that guess. ‚ÄúOh my god I‚Äôm so sorry about the poison; I was buried in arms and it took so long to get out that by the time I did, you had been in there for... I don‚Äôt know, but way too long!‚Äù ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs okay,‚Äù Bria said through a series of sharp coughs. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm okay, I think.‚Äù ‚ÄúY-you are, I‚Äôm pretty sure. But, um... you‚Äôre not... um...‚Äù ‚ÄúTransformed,‚Äù Bria finished, starting to sit up. ‚ÄúI noticed.‚Äù There was a slight thrum of fear as she started to understand what had happened, but realistically she had bigger problems. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre even now, right? That‚Äôs all that means.‚Äù Lillian wouldn‚Äôt do anything bad with that knowledge, surely. Not now that she was a light-side hero, right? ‚Äú... Yeah. I guess we are...‚Äù An awkwardly long pause. ‚ÄúL-look, I‚Äôm just glad you-‚Äù Bria began, but was interrupted. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt help at all!‚Äù Violet exclaimed. ‚ÄúI just got in your way; I‚Äôm pretty sure I even ended up hurting you more than the monster did! I‚Äôm sorry I‚Äôm such a useless hero that I don‚Äôt even deserve an angel. I‚Äôll - I‚Äôll do better somehow...‚Äù ‚Äã
8:46 PM
‚Äú...‚Äù She hesitated for a few moments, trying to come up with something reassuring to say that didn‚Äôt sound trite. ‚ÄúI think you did fine. Indeed, all traces of the monster were now gone aside from the destruction the battle had left. ‚ÄúIt is time to report and depart.‚Äù ‚ÄúAh! Wait, Violet had a question for you!‚Äù ‚ÄúCome along,‚Äù he said impassively, drifting towards the door. ‚ÄúYou have several staff members to speak to.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù Bria gestured after him. ‚ÄúI - I guess we need to go...‚Äù It took only another ten minutes to clear everything up with the building staff (after Bria managed to squeeze out just a little more recovered energy to return to Silver), but by then, Violet was almost out of time. She had to catch a train heading back north to return to her parents, so after returning to their base forms, Bria walked with her to the station while they both tried to get Zeal to give any straight answers. ‚ÄúWhy doesn‚Äôt she have an angel?‚Äù Bria asked. ‚ÄúWhat does she have to do to get one?‚Äù ‚ÄúIt takes time,‚Äù he shrugged. ‚ÄúOne of us must find themself drawn to her as a partner in order to form the bond. There are, of course, always more humans around and many angels prefer to avoid those with suspected poor temperaments or distrusted pasts.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat did he say?‚Äù Lillian asked anxiously; Zeal was again only visible to Bria. ‚Äú...‚Äù Don‚Äôt say anything mean; Zeal‚Äôs probably just being pessimistic. ‚ÄúIt can take some time,‚Äù she decided. ‚ÄúTo, um, find the angel that‚Äôs the best fit for you.‚Äù ‚ÄúHow long?‚Äù ‚Äã
8:46 PM
She looked over at him helplessly; he could obviously hear her just as well as Bria could. But she still had to repeat the question before he would deign to answer. ‚ÄúHow long?‚Äù she relayed impatiently. ‚ÄúA while. Perhaps a day; perhaps a year.‚Äù ‚Äú... Was it bad to give her this extra optimism that might not be true, or would it be worse to just accurately relay Zeal‚Äôs pessimistic and honestly kind of condescending answers? - Edit his answers a little; be a tad optimistic. - Relay his answers accurately, pessimism and all. @Story Notifications Scene 63 It... probably wouldn‚Äôt be a good idea to tell her exactly what Zeal was saying, Bria decided. Lillian was going through a lot. And, because it seemed to be taking her a while to come up with her next question and Bria was curious too, she asked one herself. Quietly, just in case. ‚ÄúCould you... also be her angel, as well as mine?‚Äù Bria sorta-whispered. Enough to hide her words, but not necessarily that she was speaking at all. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know how that would work, but...‚Äù ‚ÄúIt would not,‚Äù he declared decisively. ‚ÄúThe partner bond is highly exclusive; attempts to share or shard it have always led to dramatic failures. In the simplest cases, it has caused a total blockage of magic flow between angel and human, resulting in a loss of regenerative ability, but it is certainly not unheard of to cause more extreme issues. Such as lattice degradation - where the solid body loses its cohesion and dissolves into an irrecoverable solution of unattuned ether - or even spontaneous existence failure.‚Äù He side-eyed her in a rare display of something adjacent to humor. ‚ÄúI imagine you could determine the symptoms of such a condition from its name alone.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou just... poof? Just like that?‚Äù ‚ÄúJust like that.‚Äù ‚ÄúM-maybe it‚Äôs a good idea to not try that, after all...‚Äù That doesn‚Äôt sound like a real thing. Is he joking? He doesn‚Äôt joke. IS it a real thing? Why do I still have my powers, if I don‚Äôt have an angel at the moment...? Begrudgingly, she repeated the question. ‚Äã
8:38 PM
‚ÄúCorrect, to an extent. A hero‚Äôs solid lattice body will naturally recover itself by converting input matter into energy to replenish any lost - a similar process to an ordinary, physical body.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou mean, eating.‚Äù ‚ÄúI do. But the ether that binds it is another matter. That portion is not recovered by physical processes simply because it is not physical. For normal heroes, ether is recovered via their linked partner or, rarely, by siphoning it from other heroes through specialized attacks. Without replenishment, each use of magical power is a permanent expenditure. Over sufficient time, abilities will cease to function. Eventually, transformation will follow. And finally, even controlling one‚Äôs solid lattice body will become impossible without the fluid ether to direct it. I am assured it is quite a terrifying means of death.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù She stared at him. He floated serenely forwards. ‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt say anything good, I take it?‚Äù Lillian guessed. ‚ÄúWhat, um, was it? Something about eating...?‚Äù ‚ÄúWait wait wait,‚Äù Bria repeated, lowering her voice again. ‚ÄúYou said you can quit being a hero and it‚Äôs fine, right? But if our bodies are like this forever, and you just said that the link is needed to refill the ether or whatever - how does that work if you quit?!‚Äù A shrug. ‚ÄúInactive heroes exhaust their ether extremely slowly, as they do not expend it to transform or utilize magical abilities. It is vanishingly rare for it to be depleted to a dangerous degree before the end of a human‚Äôs natural lifespan.‚Äù ‚ÄúSo she‚Äôll be fine as long as she doesn‚Äôt use any powers?‚Äù ‚ÄúI assume so.‚Äù She looked back at Lillian, who was still wearing a questioning expression. @Story Notifications Scene 66 July 32nd, 2028 ‚ÄúMalice is out at the moment,‚Äù Purity explained as they headed quietly down a long, wide hallway. ‚ÄúSo this is the perfect time to bring you here for an introduction. She can be a... a little hard to deal with, sometimes.‚Äù ‚ÄúAh, like Zeal, huh?‚Äù ‚ÄúNo! Not like him; at least she lets me do things the way I think is best.‚Äù ‚ÄúIf she‚Äôs not mind-controlling you,‚Äù Vanity did not say. This was one of the reasons she had gone to Zeal in the first place: Malice, the ‚Äúleader‚Äù of this group, had always been more than a little manipulative. But with her powers multiplied, she was now capable of bending minds to her will - and not just human ones. It was a scary thought, and Malice was absolutely not one who could be trusted with the power. Which made Zeal‚Äôs recent delvings into the same field of study even more concerning, because she super didn‚Äôt trust him with that kind of thing either. It was certainly possible that Purity was being controlled to some degree, but it was unlikely to be a huge amount. Everyone knew that the more you controlled someone else‚Äôs mind, the more their creativity and problem-solving skills declined. That might be okay for regular grunts, but not for one of your top scientists. Purity certainly still controlled most of her own thoughts; her results proved that. (Although maybe a little less right this instant, with that card still in effect.) ‚ÄúThat might be nice,‚Äù Vanity actually did say, deciding to just agree. 8:51 PM
Ah. The wellspring. One of only four known sources of the mysterious power that blessed and cursed the celestials willing to imbue themselves with it. Vani didn‚Äôt really know much about how it worked - no one did, unless they had taken it into themselves - but it was the reason why Malice, Despair, Purity, and the like were so much stronger than anyone else. The power contained in the wellspring dramatically increased celestial powers, though that increase came at a cost. Some celestials thought the benefits were worth that cost; others did not. At its core, that‚Äôs what this whole conflict was about. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm... not sure if I‚Äôm ready to commit to that just yet,‚Äù Vani said, trying to speak like Purity did. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a lot so soon, after so long being against it...‚Äù ‚ÄúN-no, that‚Äôs okay!‚Äù She moved on, leaving the wellspring‚Äôs door unopened and any secrets beyond it unseen. ‚ÄúI get it! @Story Notifications Scene 67 Jorge 090st, 20288 A continuous stream of quiet giggling emanated from somewhere within the walls. Purity found this hilarious, but could only manage a few sporadic chuckles. She counted the stars in the ceiling, but it was difficult as they kept moving around and overlapping. ‚ÄúYou good?‚Äù Vani asked from the vague direction of a ventilation shaft far too small to fit any of her standard forms. This room didn‚Äôt need ventilation, anyway. ‚ÄúYou look goooooddd.......‚Äù An outburst of snickering. The lights bent out of shape; tied themselves in knots. Illumination became stuck. The ventilation shaft figured it might serve better as a door and became one. ‚ÄúWhere... even are youoouoooouu...???‚Äù Vani swam through gelatinous space, ducking between aberrant furniture. Something chortled. ‚ÄúWhere even is... anything??‚Äù Nothing presented itself, but it was not an acceptable anything. Vanity moved on. The ventilation door decided to try life as a window, complete with a cooling pie on the sill. Fragrant particles wafted through its duct-like corridors, passing into every corner of the facility. Nothing became infused with the scent of lemon-cinnamon. Anything laughed out loud. ‚ÄúPuuurrrriiiii??......?‚Äù Vani called into the pie-galaxy. Something muttered under the wind. More illogical snickering. The ventilation window sprouted another pie. Apple-apple-apple mixed with lemon-cinnamon. ‚ÄúWho left the lights...?‚Äù she mused. The tangle became flavored. Lemon-apple-cinnamon-apple-apple coated every surface in a brilliant glow. Something tasted it and laughed. Nothing responded in kind. ‚ÄúWhat was I.........???‚Äù Vani couldn‚Äôt remember. All of the things chuckled, and snickered, and chortled, and- ‚Äã
4:50 PM
No. She remembered. But... ‚ÄúWhere did I...?‚Äù Vani rummaged through her belongings. An endless flood of socks poured into the walls, painting them sock-colored with the texture. ‚ÄúThese aren‚Äôt mine...‚Äù They weren‚Äôt. The ventilation window commiserated and offered a third pie. The heady scent of distilled pie essence consumed the socks. The walls couldn‚Äôt understand and threw up. Dozens of lost keys pelted the tangled light fixtures orbiting nothing in particular. ‚ÄúNo, I put it somewhere else... !!‚Äù The card was already inside her. Vanity squeezed down into a smaller space, shrinking and compressing and pressing against the card in just the right way. The ventilation window peered closer, pie-drops dripping onto her form with painful plips. Scorching hot pie-flavored vortices whirled closer as something cackled from beyond the- August 2nd, 2028 Vanity woke up. She sat up, catching her breath and coughing up little sooty particles from the card she had eaten previously. Her form trembled with instability as the spell from that pattern fought against the frankly irresponsible dose of ico-bricks she had taken... she checked: two hours ago. It hadn‚Äôt been too long. She stood up, pressing a hand against her temple as a headache thumped through her human-shaped skull. Her form was stuck like this for now, as trying to shift it would send her right back into the drug-induced abyss - but without a card to recover, this time. Damn, it hurt. How did humans stand it all the time? Purity gently snickered to herself on a nearby couch, muttering something about pie. Her form, too, was locked as human for safety, but without the card there were twinges of fluidity around her extremities. Vani patted her on the head, draped a tablecloth over her as she couldn‚Äôt find a blanket, then padded unsteadily out of the room. Where were her shoes? How did she get this many socks? Ggguhhhf... ‚Äã
4:50 PM
Okay, in retrospect, the ‚Äúdrug Purity and also yourself‚Äù plan might not have been the best idea, Vanity admitted. But it had worked. The extra card had let her escape the bricks‚Äô influence far faster than she should have - and crucially, far faster than Purity, still completely out of it in the other room. How had she even convinced her to go along with it, actually? Everything was a bit blurry. Focus. The guy. Where was the lab again? Vanity stumbled through darkened corridors for a while, passing by the wellspring room (or at least doors that looked like it) thrice before finally arriving. The door had somehow become a window at some point, complete with three weird-looking pies, so she didn‚Äôt even have to break in. She just popped the latch open and climbed through. The guy was there, just chilling in its little bed-like thing. Asleep... Nope! Eyes open; looking at her. ‚ÄúHey, little dude,‚Äù Vani whispered. ‚ÄúJust here to pick up some stuff for Purity. You don‚Äôt mind that, right?‚Äù It didn‚Äôt say anything; just tracked her with those strangely luminous but otherwise very human-looking eyes. She decided to assume that meant it didn‚Äôt mind. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs right; you wouldn‚Äôt snitch.‚Äù She rubbed her head again, groaning at the aching pressure. ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs get started, then.‚Äù ... Purity woke up as a puddle on the floor. It took her a while to pull herself together enough to approximate a solid form, then even longer to accomplish something approximating locomotion. Briefly, she wondered what had happened last night, but it was immediately clear those memories were completely gone. Replaced entirely by ico-brick hallucinations. Oh, this was so very irresponsible. Why had... Vanity had been there! Where-? ‚Äã
4:50 PM
Purity shifted her form several times in quick succession, trying to expel enough lingering toxins to be able to move. As usual, she found a human-like form most stable and easiest to maneuver. Most celestials did, since - well, it wasn‚Äôt totally clear. Shaking off the remnants of a probably terrible headache, she wandered the facility for a while looking for Vanity. No luck. Uh oh. With something approximating panic beginning to rise (not improving her headache or queasiness, by the way), Purity hurried back to the lab. She had been suspicious of Vanity from the start, right? Surely she should have been - but somehow she couldn‚Äôt remember doing any of the usual security checks. Had she even told anyone that Vanity was here? ‚ÄúThe door is a window,‚Äù she remarked to no one in particular. Maybe the pies. They were cold by now; this had been here a while. @Story Notifications Scene 68 A portion of anxiety dropped away as the homunculus waved mutely from its enclosure. A quick examination revealed nothing obviously amiss: no fires, no missing equipment or notes, and no damage to the quasi-living template that formed the backbone of this project. She exhaled in relief. Maybe Vani had just had to go? But without leaving a note or something...? Besides, where would she be going? Not back to Zeal, if she had been telling the truth... In the middle of trying to marshal her thoughts into something approximating a plan, Purity noticed a soft thump of pressure dispersing through the facility. The anxiety returned: Malice was back. Oh, no no no; she couldn‚Äôt face her right now. She had to hide this terrible breach of protocol, whether or not Vanity had actually done anything. Surely by now, this would be the last straw. She‚Äôd lose her position, and then... No. Don‚Äôt panic. Malice couldn‚Äôt read minds - only change them - so as long as there wasn‚Äôt any evidence of a problem, she‚Äôd never know! @Story Notifications Scene 69 The train stopped; the doors opened. Bria hesitated as other passengers boarded and disembarked. This sounded like a trick, a trap, or generally just a bad idea. Yet, of course, there wasn‚Äôt really any way she could say no, was there? There were too many unknowns and too much to learn by going. And if Zeal was actually right, or if Strawberry was telling the truth (surely, right?)... Bria stepped aboard, fishing out her phone to buy the unexpected ticket. Her friends wouldn‚Äôt lie to her. Would they? ... Strawberry fell from the sky. But that was okay, because she meant to do that. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre far enough!‚Äù she yelled to Mahogany over the rushing wind. ‚ÄúNext drop, kay?‚Äù ‚ÄúYou got it!‚Äù he shouted back, starting to shift his wings away. Strawberry slowed and redirected her descent with a curved ring of pink energy, angling back into the air just as an entire tree whipped past. Her slide shattered on impact, spraying her and her passenger with fragments of dissolving energy and altogether too many pine needles. It‚Äôs fine; that‚Äôs what the redirection was for. Just one more clever trick and they‚Äôd be away. Two more trees ripped themselves out of the ground, followed by a dozen more in a rapid-fire attack. Umber was getting serious, or at least she really hoped he was. If this amount of firepower was still him playing around- ‚ÄúBRACE!‚Äù The trees were huge. Even with her extreme midair maneuverability, carrying Hog increased her weight too much; she couldn‚Äôt dodge everything. A smaller side branch whipped past, breaking through her barriers and carving a shallow cut down her side with its remaining energy. Splintered wood and needles sprayed into the air. Strawberry let herself be carried along with the momentum of the hit, beginning to fall back towards the ground. ‚ÄúReady?‚Äù ‚ÄúHit it!‚Äù And hit it they did. The ground, that is. ‚Äã
8:37 PM
Blasting along at a sharp angle and rapid speed, Mahogany‚Äôs shifted form took point and carved a narrow path through roots and dirt. @Story Notifications Scene 70 ... Bria disembarked and found a nearby restroom to transform. Strawberry and the others still only knew her as Silver, so she had better arrive looking the part. Of course, with Violet also involved, who knew exactly how many people would be here. 6:13 PM
Silver hurried over to the group of heroes on the far side of the main hall, squeezing past a growing group of normal people curious about why there were so many of them in one place. Aside from Silver herself, she spotted Strawberry and Granite trying to bring some level of order to the gathering, Mahogany mostly ignoring them, Violet sitting quietly with Lapis, three suited guys she didn‚Äôt recognize chatting amongst themselves, and a fourth suited guy standing off by himself but seeming to be listening. Ten heroes, all in one place and all (presumably) on their way to do the same thing. Had that ever happened before? If it had, she couldn‚Äôt think of when; heroes tended to go solo or rarely team up in twos or threes. This many heroes together would represent a sizable portion of all the heroes in the entire metropolitan region. Violet noticed her and seemed about ready to walk over, but Strawberry noticed too and was faster. ‚ÄúFinally! You‚Äôre the last one here and we really gotta hurry. Everyone else already knows what‚Äôs going on, so I‚Äôll explain on the way!‚Äù A little intimidated by all these eyes on her, Silver just agreed. ‚ÄúSo that‚Äôs what we know ‚Äòbout those ‚Äòworse-than-demons,‚Äô got it?‚Äù Strawberry said loudly a few minutes later, talking over the wind. She was carrying three of the group (plus herself), Lapis held Violet, and it seemed the lonesome suit guy had a power involving magnetism or something, because he raised the rest by invisibly pulling along large metal trapeze-like bars. The whole group flew in a mostly northern direction, though no one was entirely stable with so many passengers. ‚ÄúI - I think so?‚Äù Silver was having a hard time hearing. ‚ÄúSome celestials are trying to grab more power than they should. But you‚Äôre leaving out a lot of details!‚Äù ‚ÄúComplain to Compy and Havoc! You know what celestials‚Äôre like when you ask them for details!‚Äù ‚Äã
6:13 PM
A pause. She did. ‚ÄúYeah, I get it. So, we‚Äôre going after one of them? And they‚Äôre so powerful, that‚Äôs why we need so many people? Where did you even find everyone?‚Äù ‚ÄúYep! Mxblah 5/20/2025 9:33 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 71 Events moved quickly for a time. Flying heroes landed; people hurried around to get into prearranged positions that Silver had apparently been too late to learn. She and Violet got bumped a bit farther away to crouch uneasily behind a thick set of bushes surrounding a small park. Then, silence for slightly less than a minute. Silver very much wanted to say something - maybe ask Violet what she thought about this whole thing - but didn‚Äôt dare break the quiet. Then, a cheerful but otherwise very normal-looking girl came into view wearing a backpack and carrying a slightly dirty cardboard box. An angel faded into view above the trees, pointed briefly, then disappeared. Silver held her breath anxiously; what was about to happen? What had everyone else agreed on? Not all that much, apparently. Strawberry, as the closest in age and potentially the least intimidating, just sort of stepped out from behind her tree and stopped the girl. A quiet greeting, followed by a nervous ‚ÄúWho are you?‚Äù from the girl. Followed again by a significantly more nervous question as more of the heroes gathered in a loose ring around her. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like this,‚Äù Silver whispered to Violet, now that other people were talking. ‚ÄúAre you sure they‚Äôre not going to hurt her at all?‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure about anything!‚Äù she unhelpfully replied. ‚ÄúI barely even know why we‚Äôre here or what she has to do with this really bad demon that everyone was talking about!‚Äù ‚ÄúShould I stop them?‚Äù she asked, unfairly. Of course Violet wouldn‚Äôt have a good answer and she didn‚Äôt expect her to. But she needed to ask the question anyway. ‚ÄúBut if everyone was telling the truth...‚Äù ‚Äú... I don‚Äôt know...‚Äù ‚Äã
9:34 PM
As expected. Silver hesitated a little longer, carefully noting that no one was doing anything besides talking and standing in the girl‚Äôs way. No attacks, no overt threats of violence. She could intervene if anything actually happened, right? They promised - even Zeal said. And it was all to take down a powerful monster. It just... it really didn‚Äôt feel heroic just sitting here and watching her friends harass someone like this. Then again, being a hero didn‚Äôt feel terribly heroic most of the time anyway. Something changed. The wind picked up. Angels popped into visibility above the ring of heroes, including Zeal and - wait, was that- ‚ÄúVanity?‚Äù Violet breathed, immediately recognizing the darker, almost bat-like form. ‚ÄúWh-what are you-‚Äù And then a brilliant burst of light and sound erupted from the center of the ring. Illuminant wings spread into the sky; a halo of brilliant white drenched the trees in radiance. The image of what angels should have looked like, before humanity discovered they tended to resemble little flying animal mascots. A voice thundered across the surrounding neighborhood: ‚ÄúYOU TRAITOR!‚Äù Someone shouted back. ‚ÄúATTACK!‚Äù Events got a little chaotic from there. Heroes scattered; the manifested angel-demon fired brilliant, scorching bolts in multiple directions. Silver ducked down further, wondering what on earth she was supposed to be doing. Defend her allies? Against that? Or was she supposed to be keeping an eye out for something worse? ‚Äã
9:34 PM
The bush was on fire. ‚ÄúMove, move!‚Äù She and Violet dashed off in search of sturdier cover, taking in the fight as impressions while they ran. Curved pink shield domes suggested Strawberry was also taking more of a supportive role. Bolts of lightning arced in slow motion between metal objects. Flames spread amongst the greenery; wood charred and smoked with flames ranging in color from red through orange and blue all the way to a pale purple-white. Bursts of painful heat finally provided the first meaningful way for Silver to participate, reflecting the rapidly fluctuating temperature away from her and Violet as they crossed the park. ‚ÄúWhere did everyone go?‚Äù she asked urgently as they caught their breath near the far end of the park. Flames burned around the entire perimeter already, as well as part way down both side streets. Smoke already clouded the air, making it difficult to see even the blazing angelic/demonic presence, let alone any of her less-visible allies. ‚ÄúHow did it get so hazy so quick?‚Äù ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs over by those trees; some people are probably still close by?‚Äù The sharp crack of an explosion punctuated Violet‚Äôs sentence; dirt sprayed into the increasingly smoky air. ‚Äú... Let‚Äôs go!‚Äù Unfortunately, by the time they ran the perhaps forty feet over to the trees in question, the sound of battle had moved across the park again. All that was left here were several burning trees pouring acrid smoke into the air, a few strange, glittering afterimages of a bright light, and a partially melted copper rod split unevenly in two. ‚ÄúThis way?‚Äù Silver guessed, listening. Her eyes watered from all the smoke; was this actually normal for this much fire or was it being enhanced? She might have to start that air filtering barrier soon if this kept up. ‚ÄúSounds right; hurry!‚Äù ‚Äã
9:34 PM
This process repeated twice more as the smoke grew chokingly thick and emergency sirens became audible nearby. Somehow, the battle always moved on just before they arrived, no matter which angle or how fast they ran. Worse, it was clear people were being hurt - just somewhere out of sight. Screams of pain mixed with crackling flames and the occasional sharp, rattling explosion. But... ‚ÄúWhere is everybody?!‚Äù Silver yelled, exasperated. ‚ÄúHow are we supposed to help if we can‚Äôt even find anyone?‚Äù ‚ÄúShould we get out of the smoke for a second?‚Äù Violet coughed. Silver didn‚Äôt have enough practice to make the filter apply to her too, but at least her cloak helped to some degree. ‚ÄúGet our bearings? I don‚Äôt even know where we are anymore.‚Äù ‚Äú... If this is like my mist...‚Äù Silver paused too. ‚ÄúIf the currents are going that way, then...‚Äù She straightened up, pointing in what seemed a completely arbitrary direction. ‚ÄúThe source of this smoke is this way! @Story Notifications Scene 72 ‚ÄúHEY!‚Äù Acting on impulse, Silver leapt forward as the girl stood, fumbling for the box. It had to be important, right? Maybe it was the source of the smoke? Silver lunged for it, snatching the cardboard away with just a quick tug; the girl seemed both to not be very strong and to want to leave as quickly as possible. @Story Notifications Scene 73 ‚ÄúThe smoke‚Äôs just going to be hurting Purity as much as anyone else,‚Äù Silver asserted, trying a different tactic. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just causing confusion for everyone and she won‚Äôt be able to see attacks coming either. Most of the heroes lay scattered across the park, burned and unconscious or worse. 4:36 PM

4:37 PM
Silver herself, Violet, and Snow were fine. Granite was utterly exhausted and had a slight fever, but would live. Strawberry had survived without critical injuries and had spent the last few minutes crawling around to seal as many terrible wounds as she could with her pink shields. Onyx was awake before long and able to help tend to the many, many burns - apparently his signature magic involved electricity, so he was familiar with this type of injury. Her hair had half-burned away, and her eye- Silver had to pause and look away. She was still alive, but only barely. It was getting harder to find anyone else as her search broadened towards the edges of the park. Someone was talking with the firefighters who had arrived earlier. Probably Granite. There were still three people to find. There weren‚Äôt many places left to look. Finally, Mocha (who had joined her in the search) found Moss impaled on a charred branch halfway up a tree. Blood flowed steadily towards the ground and the branch broke off as soon as they touched it, leading to a macabre scramble to catch him. The wound was critical, but with Strawberry‚Äôs last dregs of energy, they managed to seal it to prevent any more bleeding. Still, it was unclear whether he would live through the rest of the day. Granite led in a pair of regular paramedics, as this was beyond what any of the heroes present could handle on their own. Two left. They reached the borders of the park. 4:37 PM

Silver couldn‚Äôt get enough leverage to budge the tree for a reflection to be of any help - friction sapped any energy before she could get a chain reaction going - and Mocha‚Äôs signature magic was ‚Äúbased on radiation,‚Äù he said, and wouldn‚Äôt be of any help. Mxblah 5/27/2025 9:03 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 74 ‚ÄúMove, please.‚Äù Silver stepped aside without protest, making room for Granite to briefly inspect the tree. ‚ÄúI can move it, but it will probably break. Can you two protect him?‚Äù Nods. No words. Silver and Mocha moved around behind the shattered tree. She prepared to reflect any stray fragments; he prepared to catch any falling heroes once the pinning tree was removed. Granite pushed a large column of rock out of the ground, crashing through the main part of the sideways trunk. Splintered wood sprayed in multiple directions; a huge segment of trunk slammed into the broken street. He breathed; moved a little closer. A smaller spire; a little more precision. More broken wood. Step closer. Again. Smaller. More precise. One more time. The tree became unstuck and with a single loud crash, it finally fell away. Mocha leapt into the debris as Silver kept the fragments at bay. Mahogany could shift again. Could seal that terrible wound. If he had the energy. If he had the focus. If he was awake. If he was alive. ‚Äú...‚Äù Granite felt for a pulse; for breathing. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not gone yet,‚Äù he breathed with a surge of relief. ‚ÄúBut I don‚Äôt know how long he‚Äôll stay that way without help. Mocha, help me stop this bleeding; Silver, find those paramedics from before. West side.‚Äù She ran off. At this point, it was only the emotional enhancement from her battle form keeping her coherent. Silver located a second ambulance crew and led them back to the fallen tree. Mahogany was still unconscious, but Granite and Mocha hadn‚Äôt given up yet, so there must still be some hope. She couldn‚Äôt do much there besides just get in the way - she had no magical healing abilities and no medical training - so she returned to the fountain in the center of the park to sit down, calm down, and think about what had just happened. ‚Äã
9:03 PM
Unhelpfully for trying to marshal her racing thoughts, Violet and Snow were still there. Strawberry and Onyx were too, but the former was nearly unconscious due to how much energy she had expended and the latter was busy a bit away helping tend to the worst burns. ‚ÄúHow‚Äôs she doing?‚Äù Silver asked Violet, just because it felt like she had to say something even though she‚Äôd much rather just pass out and not have to think about anything. ‚ÄúFine.‚Äù Snow was sitting against the fountain, knees to her chest and face hidden from view. She wasn‚Äôt restrained anymore, but she wasn‚Äôt moving anyway. ‚Äú... Are the last two okay?‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù Silver copied Snow‚Äôs pose. It felt a little safer like this, blocking out the world just a bit. ‚ÄúNo. Maroon‚Äôs d-dead, and Mahogany‚Äôs... almost the same.‚Äù Her throat felt thick, like she was about to cry. Saying it aloud... ‚ÄúS-sorry.‚Äù A long, drawn-out pause. Firefighters and police officers hurried here and there. No one bothered the heroes. ‚ÄúI hate this,‚Äù Silver finally said, forcing the words out like they were barbed. ‚ÄúWhy are we even here? What was even the point? According to her, there might not even be a point! And all this for nothing...‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs... not what I thought being a light side hero would be like,‚Äù Violet admitted quietly. ‚ÄúMe neither!‚Äù Silver choked on her words and suddenly found her eyes wet with tears. ‚ÄúIt never feels like we‚Äôre doing anything good or heroic! Maybe with the monsters sometimes, but they just come back the next day. And these ‚Äòdark spirits‚Äô that create them - they‚Äôre just celestials too! If angels can be like that and demons can be like this , then what‚Äôs even the difference?! What‚Äôs the point of all this? The ‚Äòwellspring?‚Äô Some sort of ‚Äòcorruption?‚Äô No! One! Ever! Explains! ANYTHING!‚Äù ‚Äã
9:03 PM
She pressed her fingernails into her scalp in frustration, dragging red marks down to her face. ‚ÄúNone of us would have gotten hurt if we just knew what was going on,‚Äù she murmured. ‚ÄúNone of us would have died. It‚Äôs all just so pointless...‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just, what‚Äôs the point of being a hero if you‚Äôre still hurting people, right?‚Äù Violet looked over, but Silver still had her eyes closed. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think I would have changed if I knew it‚Äôd be like... this.‚Äù ‚ÄúIf the me right now was the me who met Zeal for the first time back in June, I‚Äôd tell him to go away and never come back.‚Äù ‚Äú... What about the you right now and the Zeal right now?‚Äù ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not even here,‚Äù Silver knew without looking up. ‚ÄúBut if he was...‚Äù Would she quit? Right on the spot? It was tempting, but somehow, despite everything, Silver still knew her answer. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she sighed. ‚ÄúI feel like I‚Äôm close to finally understanding what‚Äôs going on. And once I do, I can finally stop it. Actually help people. And stop all this pointless fighting.‚Äù ‚ÄúHow noble.‚Äù Silver looked up. That wasn‚Äôt Violet‚Äôs voice. ‚ÄúBut how very boring.‚Äù A muscular guy in a black t-shirt casually walked towards the fountain, hands in his pockets. ‚ÄúYou sappy morons just don‚Äôt get it.‚Äù Her heart rate just about doubled. Silver shot to her feet, near-instantly transitioning from despair to panic. Ghostly white eyes with just a hint of yellow-orange glow. She hadn‚Äôt met him before, but she absolutely knew who he was. ‚Äú---‚Äù ‚ÄúSpeechless, huh? Keep trying.‚Äù He sauntered past Silver, angling for the still-curled up Snow leaning against the fountain. ‚ÄúHey, tiny. Get up. You‚Äôre comin‚Äô with me.‚Äù She didn‚Äôt raise her head, just shaking it instead. ‚Äã
9:03 PM
‚ÄúFinally,‚Äù Umber semi-grinned. ‚ÄúSomeone who‚Äôs not a total pushover. Shame you‚Äôre a wimp, though.‚Äù He blinked; looked up and past the fountain. ‚ÄúHey, is that pinky over there? Just lyin‚Äô around? What have you chumps been up to?‚Äù He shrugged; rotated his shoulders a few times. ‚ÄúWelp, better kill her too real quick.‚Äù Silver had to do something. She couldn‚Äôt just stand here and let this guy do whatever he wanted. There had been too much pain and death already today; it just wasn‚Äôt FAIR that he showed up now too! But what could she possibly do against the monster who could fire streetlights like bullets and crush entire buildings without breaking a sweat? How could she possibly keep anyone safe? @Story Notifications Scene 75 ‚ÄúS-Snow,‚Äù she exclaimed, finally finding her voice. ‚ÄúYou said you didn‚Äôt want to hurt anyone - look what he‚Äôs about to do! If you know him, stop him!‚Äù Snow shook her head again, only squeezing into a tighter curl if anything. She didn‚Äôt say a word. Umber laughed, just once. ‚ÄúYou think she‚Äôs gonna help you? After what you just did? Yeah, good luck with that one.‚Äù He reached down to pick up a smooth pebble from the ground around the bench, littered with many such stones. ‚ÄúSit tight; I‚Äôll be outta your hair in a minute or two. And - as he lowered his arm to point the rock straight at Strawberry‚Äôs barely-conscious form - Silver knew that despite Zeal‚Äôs warnings, he would succeed. She stepped in front of him. Violet reached out, as if to pull her back, but Silver took another step further away. ‚ÄúGet everyone else out of here,‚Äù she said with more calm than she felt was possible. Her reflection had to be perfectly timed and perfectly aimed. ‚ÄúAlthough...‚Äù He peered a little closer. ‚ÄúThink I‚Äôve heard‚Äôve you. Zeal, was it? You‚Äôre his vessel? In an instant, it accelerated like a bullet from a gun, tearing across the space between them too fast for any human to react. ‚Äã
9:12 PM
Luckily, Silver hadn‚Äôt been reacting to the rock itself. She timed her reflection against his hand‚Äôs motion, sending it ricocheting off her chest - just between her heart and collarbone, it would have undoubtedly been a fatal wound - right back at him. Well, sort of. Though she had gotten the timing just about perfect, her angle was slightly off. The rock shot between Umber‚Äôs upraised arm and his side, cracking into the side of a building bordering the park. He lowered his arm, flashing a brief expression of surprise. Then, a deep grin, followed by a much louder laugh. ‚ÄúHa! Interesting, I see. You‚Äôd better not disappoint, then. Let‚Äôs see what you‚Äôve got.‚Äù Umber tapped his knuckle against the fountain with a muffled thunk, easily tearing the entire thing out of the ground to rain down dirt and water on a surprised Snow. She scrambled to her feet to get out of the way before hundreds of pounds of stone and water accelerated rapidly towards Silver. This was what she had been afraid of. Pebbles, she could reflect. It had taken a toll to do the last one with how fast it had been going, but she was still fairly fresh and could do many more. But a whole fountain, moving this fast? Silver threw herself forwards and aside, trying to duck under it, but the highest tier clipped her shoulder as she passed, reflecting it on a wobbling course into the air and her ungracefully into the dirt as she split the momentum to avoid overwhelming her reserves. ‚ÄúLess impressed,‚Äù Umber noted. The fountain flattened a tree behind Silver, sending a wave of water across the park. Had Violet not already picked up Strawberry, she would have been crushed beneath the stone. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you have any attacks? You‚Äôre making me do all the work.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù She was still picking herself up from the grass, trying to come up with any sort of plan beyond just stalling. ‚Äã
9:12 PM
‚ÄúAnd you won‚Äôt even say anything,‚Äù he groaned. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like you want me to get bored. Fine; I‚Äôll bite.‚Äù A quick swish across the grass with one foot led to a strip of sod rolling up into a coil, aiming directly for her. This one was too fast and too wide. She couldn‚Äôt fly or jump particularly high; she ran towards it. With an outstretched arm to reduce the area of impact down to a point, Silver reflected the soil‚Äôs motion separately, envisioning it as a clump of dirt rather than a cohesive whole. A spray of broken grass and earth shot from the roll, extending in size as Silver leapt through the hole while reflecting just enough to fit her body through. Another inelegant landing, but she got up quick and ran for Umber. She didn‚Äôt have much of a plan, but it was pretty clear she wasn‚Äôt going to win this fight by just playing defensively. All of his attacks carried so much speed or weight that she‚Äôd tire herself out in only a few more minutes at this rate. ‚ÄúHmph.‚Äù Umber stomped into the decorative stones beneath the bench, raising hundreds of little rocks into the air before sending them all cannoning towards Silver. ‚ÄúHow many can you deal with at once?‚Äù A lot, but not that many. Rocks deflected off her body, bouncing back towards and occasionally colliding with their fellows. Quite a few escaped the onrushing cloud, or missed her entirely, screaming off in random directions to impact trees, buildings, or bystanders. At least a handful definitely hit Umber, but they just bounced off. And each new reflection required a significant amount of energy due to how much speed she had to cancel. A few, no problem. Dozens, manageable. Hundreds... ‚Äã
9:12 PM
Silver reflected herself instead. Her trajectory changed in an instant, abruptly reversing with speed that would have broken every bone in her body had the rules of force and acceleration applied to whatever logic fueled her magic. Rushing air tore at her, whipping any loose hair or fabric into a frenzy. The park passed in a blur as shockwaves filled her ears, but she hardly even had a moment to consider what would happen next. All she knew was that she had to reflect again whenever she hit something, or she‚Äôd instantly die. A wall exploded. Silver fell to the ground, utterly spent and surrounded by scattered rocks and debris. She had reflected all her momentum into the wall of whatever unfortunate building she had collided with, which had resulted in - !! Silver half-scrambled, half-limped towards the street as the roof - now unsupported by the missing wall she had essentially annihilated - collapsed and took the remaining walls with it. A sturdy brick or concrete structure now lay in ruins before her. Umber. Where the hell was he? Silver trembled with exhaustion and adrenaline, unsure how much energy she had left to fight. It couldn‚Äôt be much, surely. Had everyone else escaped by now? Could she run? Dare she return to the park to check? Where had Snow gone in all the chaos? - You‚Äôve done all you can. Run. @Story Notifications Scene 76 ‚Äú...‚Äù Despite the churning fear and multiple warnings that told her this could only end in disaster, she just couldn‚Äôt leave her friends behind. If anyone was still being threatened by Umber, she had to help them. That‚Äôs what being a hero was about. Should be about, at least. What she could do about it was unclear, but... Silver pushed herself into a shaky jog and returned to the park. There was an obvious path of cracked concrete and torn-up grass leading straight back to the former location of the fountain, just another indication of how unbelievably fast she had been moving only a minute ago. No one was nearby, whether hero, villain, or civilian, but she still had to check the rest of the park. Or at least the little temporary area where Onyx and Strawberry had been treating the others. And that was on the other side of the wide-open area in the center, destroyed by two battles in a row. She slowed to a stop. Umber was still here. He was talking on his phone with one hand, seeming quite annoyed at whoever was on the other end, while holding Snow‚Äôs hand with his other as she stood with head bowed and hair covering her face. She seemed unharmed, though covered in dust and water from the broken fountain. Silver briefly considered trying to hide, but there wasn‚Äôt anywhere to go and it was too late anyway. Umber noticed her quickly, made some excuse to the person on the phone, and ended the call. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre back,‚Äù he observed neutrally. ‚ÄúWhat, you got a death wish or something?‚Äù ‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs everyone else?‚Äù He shrugged. ‚ÄúWho cares? 5:42 PM
The pole rushed at her like an enormous javelin, traveling fast enough to shake the air in its wake. Silver started to move out of the way, but her body seemed to react in slow motion - instantly, she knew she wouldn‚Äôt be fast enough. Mustered her energy for a reflection, but felt a resistance as she pulled ether from the extremities of her form. The lamp post impacted her body just below her ribcage. A burst of desperate energy; a spray of torn metal and fabric as she poured everything she had into the reflection. The pole crumpled in on itself as only part of its mass rebounded towards the rest of it. It split like a banana peel, tearing apart and sending scraps of broken metal in all directions. Blood arced into the air. Silver fell to her knees, shaking with exhaustion and pain. The more solid, armor-like part of her dress around her torso had cracked apart from the impact and slow, thin streams of blood trickled from broken skin beneath. Metal shards stung from where they had cut or embedded in her limbs or face. She was so winded she could barely breathe. Her outline flickered; shifted. She couldn‚Äôt hold it together and her battle form collapsed, leaving just plain old Bria on the grassless, debris-strewn dirt. Mxblah 6/3/2025 6:50 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 77 ‚ÄúNo!‚Äù ‚ÄúYou really push your luck sometimes, tiny. Get. The fuck. Out of my way.‚Äù Snow shook her head. Umber half-sighed, half-growled. Die.‚Äù The rock fulfilled its purpose. Blood painted the ground. Snow had to look away. ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs go,‚Äù Umber sighed, turning around to pull Snow back to her feet. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt look so goddamn sad; you didn‚Äôt even know this one.‚Äù ... Later that evening, Snow sat against the wall and rotated her bracelet around her wrist, over and over again. Technically, she wasn‚Äôt transformed at the moment so she had a different name, but that ‚Äúnormal‚Äù name hadn‚Äôt felt real in months. So, Snow. Water flowed through pipes in the wall. Umber was taking a shower down the hall, but Snow was already all clean and nestled in her fluffy, comfortable robe. He always made sure of stuff like that; that she could shower first or choose what slice of cake she wanted or get new clothes more often. At home, he really was nice to her. She spun the bracelet again. It bumped against that protruding bone opposite her thumb and stopped quickly. Why couldn‚Äôt he be like that all the time? Why couldn‚Äôt he see that he wasn‚Äôt doing the right thing? Snow took the bracelet off and looked through it around her room. Dark; she hadn‚Äôt turned on any lights yet, so the only illumination was from the hall and the window. There were numerous tiny, precise glyphs carved all around the band, but she didn‚Äôt know what any of them meant. Purity had said they were just decorative, but she didn‚Äôt fully believe... ‚Äã
6:50 PM
She slid down the wall to lie sideways on the carpet, letting the bracelet thunk to the floor nearby. Purity was gone. They had killed her, just like she had worried would happen. Snow, of course, hadn‚Äôt been able to help at all. Her powers didn‚Äôt work like that. And once her angel had returned to the ether, there wasn‚Äôt a single thing Snow could do to put her back together again. No amount of her healing magic could reverse death, whether human or celestial. And yes, she had tried. ‚Äú...‚Äù A soft push off the wall let her flop onto her back, staring vacantly at the ceiling. She had been so stupid earlier, she realized. Unbearably so; she had been overwhelmed by emotions and just. Didn‚Äôt. Think. When Umber told her to get out of the way, she - she should have just done it. Moved back a little bit. Stayed close enough so that she could still reach out and - and... and what? Heal the wound as it shot through? Umber would have noticed; he wasn‚Äôt stupid. But maybe if she had just been careful, or distracted him, and made sure... No. It wouldn‚Äôt have worked. Snow had to believe that, or she‚Äôd go mad. There wasn‚Äôt anything she could have done today, or yesterday, or last week, or any other time. She had been doing something - she had been working with Purity on the homunculus. The artificial vessel. The thing that would make it so the celestials wouldn‚Äôt need humans anymore; so they could leave earth alone and fight their stupid fight somewhere else. It wasn‚Äôt a perfect solution, but it was the one she could help with. Her abilities allowed her to make incredible progress in creating what was, essentially, artificial life. Combined with Purity‚Äôs understanding of the mechanics behind it, they couldn‚Äôt have been more than a few weeks away from completing it. ‚Äã
6:51 PM
She rolled over a few times, ending up lying against her bed and staring at the crack of light shining beneath her door. It vaguely occurred to her that she was probably the only human on the planet to really know what the celestials were doing. That mean girl who tackled her had known about the wellspring, but... Snow smoothed her hair, rubbing at a specific spot just above her ear that still tingled with phantom pain sometimes. She could heal her own memories after Malice erased them, breaking the sole condition under which Purity had been allowed to bring her to the upper world. Maybe... maybe she could heal her own grief, too. Maybe she could heal her stupidity away and come up with some way to fix everything. Maybe, if she got the spell just right, she could still reach into the ether and pull Purity back out. She shook her head, accidentally thunking into a bedpost and squeezing her eyes shut in pain. No, she couldn‚Äôt think like that. Death was final; trying to hold onto impossible hope would only lead to more pain later. Plus, her powers would probably stop working soon anyway. With Purity gone... Scenes from earlier in the day drifted behind her closed eyelids; she gasped and opened them again, locking her gaze on the reality of her room. Snow wasn‚Äôt used to violence. Her powers didn‚Äôt include anything that could be used to hurt anyone, not even unattuned magic. She could only heal, so she never found herself in a battle. Not until today, at least. Maybe... maybe that idea of healing her own grief wasn‚Äôt such a bad plan after all. She got up onto her hands and knees and started patting the carpet for the bracelet, locating it after a few seconds. It would probably drain the last magic she could spare, but... well, if it worked, she wouldn‚Äôt have to care. Maybe she could go even further, healing away all her capacity for misery. ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚Äã
6:51 PM
Somewhere deep inside, Snow understood it didn‚Äôt work that way. After all, she never could heal away her brother‚Äôs anger or desire to fight and kill, no matter how much she tried. All she could do was clear away Midnight‚Äôs mental shackles, but it was never enough to get him to disobey anyway. And if she couldn‚Äôt fix him, she certainly couldn‚Äôt fix herself. She put the bracelet back on. Transformed. Tried it anyway: tried to clean up her feelings and wipe away the images she saw when she blinked. Of course, it didn‚Äôt help. There was no ‚Äúinjury,‚Äù no matter how much it felt like one. Someone knocked on her door. ‚ÄúYou awake in there?‚Äù Umber asked gruffly. She hadn‚Äôt even noticed the shower shut off with all her racing thoughts. ‚Äç‚ÜïÔ∏è - Yes. ‚Äç‚ÜîÔ∏è - No. - Yes, but you don‚Äôt want to talk to him. - Pretend to be asleep. (Winner: ) (edited)

Mxblah 6/5/2025 9:27 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 78 ‚ÄúGo away,‚Äù she mumbled. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt wanna talk to you.‚Äù An exasperated sigh. ‚ÄúLeast just tell me if you‚Äôre going to school tomorrow.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù Snow didn‚Äôt have actual school again until September, of course, but she had been helping one of her teachers over the summer. It gave her something to do that wasn‚Äôt magic-related, and sometimes pretty flowers to take home. Today‚Äôs hadn‚Äôt made it. ‚ÄúFine. I‚Äôll tell them you‚Äôre sick or something.‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôll go,‚Äù she murmured. ‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôll go!‚Äù Snow said more loudly, then trailed off again. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt want to sit here by myself all day...‚Äù Umber paused on the other side of the door. ‚ÄúI can stay here tomorr-‚Äù ‚ÄúSTOP KILLING PEOPLE!‚Äù she screamed, surprising both of them with the sudden outburst. It should have been a simple, easy request. But for Umber, it wasn‚Äôt. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt. You know that.‚Äù Another pause, uncharacteristic of him. ‚ÄúI am sorry you had to see this one, though.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou can tell Despair you don‚Äôt wanna do it anymore. I can protect you from Midnight! We could-‚Äù ‚ÄúWe could WHAT?! Spend two days on the run before your magic ran out and I had to kill you myself? Hell, without Despair we wouldn‚Äôt even last an hour.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe could get help from the other side. Zeal and them aren‚Äôt...‚Äù She trailed off on her own before Umber even interrupted her. ‚ÄúStop living in a fantasy land,‚Äù he said in a low voice. ‚ÄúThey wouldn‚Äôt trust either of us after all this and I sure as hell don‚Äôt trust them. And they can‚Äôt do anything against Midnight and Malice even if they wanted to. Remember why we‚Äôre here in the first place; what got us into this mess.‚Äù She couldn‚Äôt forget. ‚ÄúSurvival.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe wellspring team is gonna win. They‚Äôve got too much power to lose. And we‚Äôre gonna survive by being on the winning team. Got it? Nothing has changed about that.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚ÄúFine. Stay in your room if you want. If you need anything, you know where I‚Äôll be.‚Äù ‚Äã
9:27 PM
Footsteps receded from her door. Snow, again, wished that she could do anything to help him understand. He pretended it was just about survival; about keeping her safe. Sure, it probably was, at least to some degree. But really, she knew, he just hated the world. Everything about it except, sometimes, his sister. If all they wanted was to survive, neither of them would have accepted their celestials‚Äô contracts, but they had. They wanted to fight back. It‚Äôs just, the two of them had very different ideas of what ‚Äúfighting‚Äù meant and how much collateral damage was acceptable in that fighting. She heard the TV turn on from the other room, muffled through the door. He‚Äôd watch sports when she wasn‚Äôt around, but would change to something she found more interesting if she came out. He always did. Snow hesitated on the floor, but the idea of going out to the living room like nothing was wrong - like her angel wasn‚Äôt gone; like she hadn‚Äôt watched someone die right in front of her - it just grated. Tonight, she truly didn‚Äôt want to see him. Maybe he‚Äôd understand at least a little if she just stayed put all night. But then again, maybe not. Nothing had worked so far. ... August 3rd, 2028 ‚ÄúZeal-‚Äù ‚ÄúIt was a simple miscalculation,‚Äù he explained rapidly, arranging the second metal bar atop the homunculus‚Äô enclosure. ‚ÄúDespair‚Äôs vessel returned too quickly. No one knew Purity‚Äôs vessel could summon him with such alacrity.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs called a text message,‚Äù Vanity said, hanging back near the lab‚Äôs entrance as Zeal threw more gear into and onto the container. ‚ÄúLook, I just wanted to know what the plan is. Things‚Äôre lookin‚Äô... kindaaa bad out there.‚Äù ‚ÄúThere is no plan,‚Äù he stated unceremoniously. ‚ÄúAttend to your own matters however you wish.‚Äù ‚ÄúThat can‚Äôt be true.‚Äù She sidled a little closer, but not close enough to get nailed by flying tools. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs all this stuff, then? Just goin‚Äô crazy ‚Äòcause you lost your vessel? Thought you didn‚Äôt care about the humans.‚Äù ‚Äã
9:27 PM
‚ÄúVessels can be replaced, but not quickly enough. I would need months to train a replacement to the same level.‚Äù He slammed a long tube of glass into the wall, cracking it in half, and threw it across the room. ‚ÄúA single miscalculation,‚Äù he repeated. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs over. Attend to yourself.‚Äù ‚ÄúSo you‚Äôre just packing up the guy ‚Äòcause you like him?‚Äù A scoff. Good: that was a more Zeal-like expression. ‚ÄúHardly. I am seeking an audience with the yhvram. The creature will assist.‚Äù ‚ÄúYeah yea - huh?‚Äù Vani did a double take. ‚ÄúThe yhvram? Like, the the yhvram?‚Äù ‚ÄúThe one and only.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt talk to anyone anymore! You told me that!‚Äù ‚ÄúIt no longer speaks to us. It still maintains some level of awareness, however, and it still responds to the old glyphs. With the proper request, it may still stir long enough to be useful.‚Äù Vanity gaped at him. ‚ÄúYou really have gone insane. It‚Äôs - things aren‚Äôt that desperate-‚Äù ‚ÄúMalice is on the warpath. I had expected her to move quickly, but I had also expected to have a vessel ready to counter her movements. Your vessel has some potential, but she is so far unwilling to respond in the proper manner, and you refuse to push the matter.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not gonna help! She hates me too now!‚Äù Zeal hefted the homunculus, considering all the attached items. ‚ÄúShe would be unhelpful in the upper realm regardless. The tipping point has been quietly reached and surpassed while we attempted to recover from the previous day‚Äôs ordeal. There is no longer a path to victory without destroying the wellspring.‚Äù ‚ÄúAnd you think the yhvram can do that.‚Äù ‚ÄúI know that none of us are capable of such a feat.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù ‚Äã
9:27 PM
‚ÄúEven entering the same subrealm as the wellspring causes unrecoverable corruption. There is no other way but the yhvram.‚Äù ‚Äú... Mxblah 6/7/2025 4:30 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 79 A long pause. Long enough for Zeal to tsk quietly and return to his packing. Several plans occurred to Vanity during the gap, but none of them would solve the overall problem: that of raw power. It had taken nearly a dozen of them to defeat even a single one of the wellspring-infused celestials, and the feat had almost completely wiped them out. And there were so many more. Malice and Despair: the two most obvious. But beyond them: Fortune, Hatred, Envy - dozens more, and growing by the day. The wellspring‚Äôs influence continued to spread throughout the celestials who were less invested in this conflict. At this point, Vani wouldn‚Äôt really be surprised if some of their core group began to defect. It seemed so hopeless. The yhvram could settle that power difference. It could destroy the wellspring. It could solve everything, if only it could be awakened and convinced to do so. For if the celestials were ‚Äúangels‚Äù and ‚Äúdemons,‚Äù then the yhvram was ‚Äúgod.‚Äù ‚Äú... At least don‚Äôt go alone,‚Äù she said at last. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll come with you.‚Äù ‚ÄúAttend to your own matters,‚Äù Zeal repeated for a third time in as many minutes. ‚ÄúYou will only interfere with my task.‚Äù ‚ÄúWh-whaaat? Come oooon, don‚Äôt be like that! I‚Äôm competent! I succeeded at my last mission!‚Äù ‚ÄúWhich only led to our collective ruin.‚Äù ‚ÄúThat wasn‚Äôt my fault!‚Äù He shook his head. ‚ÄúIt is too complicated and dangerous a mission to entrust to anyone unprepared. No one else will accompany me.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù He didn‚Äôt have to put it in such blunt terms, but... he wasn‚Äôt wrong. Making a request of the yhvram wasn‚Äôt as easy as walking over to its office and asking a question. No, it had been deeply asleep for centuries now, only waking up once - about 90 years ago - to briefly bless the cohort of celestials to which Vanity belonged. Waking it up off-cycle would probably be impossible, and it likely wouldn‚Äôt understand any method of communication they had besides - as Zeal mentioned - the ancient glyphs. ‚Äã
4:30 PM
And even if they did manage to wake it up and did manage to communicate, there wasn‚Äôt even a guarantee that it would do anything. It operated on a different scale than any of them and conflicts that seemed important here might be perceived as insignificant to it. History was full of instances where the yhvram refused to intervene, even when it had been wide awake and in its prime thousands upon thousands of years ago. Or, worse still, it might even take the other side. No one yet knew what it thought about the conflict, after all. In any case, even if the yhvram itself was somehow perfectly agreeable, simply being near the entity that was the shared ancestor of every single celestial held a sort of draw. A desire to meld back into it and return to the original ether, as it were. The pull wasn‚Äôt impossible to resist with enough discipline, but it grew more difficult over time and it would take a lot of time to attempt the awakening and set up the glyphs and make their case. ‚ÄúWhat d‚Äôyou think‚Äôs gonna happen to me if I stay here, huh?‚Äù she asked, trying a different approach. ‚ÄúOr any of us in that circle yesterday. Malice knows how to hold a grudge; she‚Äôs gonna send us all back to the ether as soon as she finds us.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou can hide. Flee.‚Äù ‚ÄúNot forever. They‚Äôre not gonna stop hunting, probably ever. This yhvram plan is kiiiindaa the last chance for all of us. So, lemme help with it.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou would only get in the way.‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôll smack you outta the trance if you get caught up in it. You know how annoying I can be!‚Äù ‚ÄúExtremely. As you are demonstrating presently, in fact.‚Äù ‚ÄúAnd if I get caught in it, you can just keep right on goin‚Äô. No harm; it‚Äôs like I wasn‚Äôt even there at all.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù He looked away. ‚ÄúReady your gatescribe. We leave imminently.‚Äù ‚ÄúYeeessssss! You won‚Äôt regret this!‚Äù Vani exclaimed as she double-checked to make sure she actually had the tool on her. Yep, she had thought something like this might happen; here it was. ‚Äã
4:30 PM
‚ÄúI‚Äôm already regretting it,‚Äù he sighed. ‚ÄúBut you would find some way to follow along anyway, so I might as well keep an eye on you.‚Äù A few minutes passed as Zeal finished his preparations and Vanity grabbed what she could from the shelves nearby. Then, the building shook from a massive - nearby - explosion. ‚ÄúWh - what was that?‚Äù Vani asked, stabilizing one of the shelves that was about to fall over. Debris rained from the walls and ceiling. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre not already-‚Äù ‚ÄúThey are. That was likely the exterior perimeter. Scribe the gate, now.‚Äù The gate to this particular realm was trickier than that to the lower world. Vanity wasn‚Äôt that good with her scribe and had to keep restarting some of the more complicated glyphs. Zeal, beside her, worked quicker and more fluidly. A second explosion knocked items off tables and caused cracks to appear in the ceiling. The lights flickered and one of them died entirely, leaving the room in a dim haze. ‚ÄúThe inner perimeter,‚Äù Zeal noted neutrally, completing his gate. A disk of shifting colors formed in the air. ‚ÄúGive me that.‚Äù In an impressive display of multitasking skill, Zeal took her gatescribe and finished her gate too, while still maintaining his own with his other hand. A loud humming noise culminated in a third explosion; one of the walls sagged towards collapse. The second disk of colors snapped into place. ‚ÄúGo,‚Äù Zeal ordered, passing through his gate. Vanity followed a moment later, taking one last look at the lab. It wasn‚Äôt nostalgic, really, but it was one of the last fairly stable realities she would see for a while. Possibly ever, if things went poorly. She vanished, too. Their gates snapped closed, expelling a brief burst of sparks as the realm‚Äôs ordinary reality reasserted itself. A few minutes later, Malice entered the now-empty lab. - Send a few expendable minions after them. - Send a competent henchman after them. - Send one of the top celestials after them. @Story Notifications Scene 80 August 4th, 2028 ‚ÄúI already quit. Stop coming back,‚Äù Yumi murmured softly, scuffing her shoes on the already-scuffed linoleum. The air carried a scent of disinfectant, which still made her tense up every so often. She hated needles, and thus hospitals. But today was much worse than just a few needles. ‚ÄúThink it over again,‚Äù Compassion said, equally softly despite being inaudible to everyone else in the building. ‚ÄúRemember how much everyone is relying on you.‚Äù ‚ÄúThat didn‚Äôt change my mind last time and it won‚Äôt work this time either,‚Äù she replied, not raising her voice. The waiting area was quiet. Lights buzzed. Other patients and visitors shuffled or held muted conversations nearby. Someone coughed. ‚ÄúLook what my help did for them.‚Äù ‚ÄúA setback is no reason to give up! You‚Äôre a hero; you‚Äôre peerlessly brave and you fight to save others! Things would have been much worse without you there.‚Äù ‚ÄúTell that to Silver.‚Äù A pause. She wouldn‚Äôt have been there at all if Strawberry hadn‚Äôt called her. Yumi continued. ‚ÄúAnd you‚Äôre wrong. I‚Äôm not a hero. I‚Äôm not brave. I didn‚Äôt fight to save anyone.‚Äù ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not what you-‚Äù ‚ÄúPeople can lie, Compy.‚Äù Yumi met her angel‚Äôs eyes for the first time in their conversation. ‚ÄúJust like you celestials. I‚Äôm lazy, I‚Äôm a coward, and I became a hero because I wanted to be awesome.‚Äù She did finger quotes around the last two words, hardly caring if anyone was watching. ‚ÄúIf you want a hero, go find Aquamarine or someone. Don‚Äôt come looking for me.‚Äù Compassion tried again. ‚ÄúThe fact that you have these doubts makes you human, not a coward,‚Äù she said gently. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no one else I‚Äôd trust more to be my partner.‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm 16 years old,‚Äù Yumi said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm supposed to be worrying about my first day back at school. Tests, crushes, stupid friendship drama. Not - not whether I or everyone I know will die tomorrow.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe burdens you take on are-‚Äù ‚Äã
8:15 PM
‚ÄúNo,‚Äù she interrupted. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not some noble sacrifice. It‚Äôs exploitation. I had a lot of time to think yesterday and you know what? I don‚Äôt think you‚Äôve ever told me the truth. Yumi stood up; she needed to walk around. The nurse was late. He had said the procedure should take about an hour and a half. It had now been over two. It‚Äôs fine, she assured herself. He probably just had something else to do. Or he didn‚Äôt add cleanup time. Or he just forgot. Late doesn‚Äôt always mean something went wrong. She didn‚Äôt believe herself. The churning in her stomach made that very clear. Most of the heroes who had survived the events of August 2nd were now fine. Physically, at least. But two had been critically injured and hadn‚Äôt left the hospital or even woken up since. Of course, they were the two that Strawberry had known best. Not that that meant she was having a worse time than Lillian, who... yeah. She should probably check on her after this. But just being here was draining enough that all she wanted to do was crawl home and go back to sleep. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not brave,‚Äù she muttered again, as if reassuring herself. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a coward who hates pain and responsibility and just became a hero because it seemed fun.‚Äù And now I know what happens when I try to take it seriously. She had organized the human side of the attack on August 2nd. She had killed two people and critically injured two more. Not directly, but it didn‚Äôt need to be. Another hour came and went. 8:15 PM

Mxblah 6/12/2025 8:49 PM
@Story Notifications Scene 81 Somehow, Lillian hadn‚Äôt given up. Somehow, she kept up enough of an appearance to stave off questions from her parents. She went to lessons. She conversed at dinner. She got up on time. Somehow, despite everything that had happened, she hadn‚Äôt broken. But really, when she thought about it, the reason she kept going was pretty simple: revenge. Or, to think about it like a hero of light should: justice. The wellspring didn‚Äôt really matter. Celestials could do what they wanted. Even her own angel-less status and Vanity‚Äôs silent appearance on the 2nd failed to add much perturbation to everything else. No. All she had left to do was to make Umber pay for his actions. And by extension, whoever directed him. The only problem was that she had no way to do that. None of the other heroes would be of any help. She didn‚Äôt know how to contact most of them. Strawberry refused to help her, claiming Lillian should just give up and quit like she had. Lapis was in a coma or dead; she wasn‚Äôt answering her phone, at least. And S-Silver... ‚Äú...‚Äù So that‚Äôs why she was over here, walking through a park towards the lakeshore on an insultingly beautiful (but at least uncomfortably hot) summer day. She was trying to find someone who could help her: the most powerful hero in the city. Even now, she still didn‚Äôt understand why the celestials hadn‚Äôt recruited him earlier. Aquamarine. As a professional and famous hero, he of course had standard means of contact. An email, a form, PR staff. She had tried all that yesterday but had gotten nowhere. So, it was time to be a little more direct. Maybe she didn‚Äôt have much magic left. Maybe something terrible would happen when she ran out. But she‚Äôd give just about anything to destroy Umber and his nebulous masters at this point, so self-preservation factored in much lower than it would ordinarily. If she wanted to be safe, she‚Äôd have taken Strawberry‚Äôs advice. But that wasn‚Äôt what a hero would do. ‚Äã
8:49 PM
‚ÄúLooking for backup?‚Äù someone asked. ‚Äú!!!‚Äù Lillian spun quickly to locate the person who sounded like he had just spoken into her ear. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre one of the angels from that... that day...‚Äù ‚ÄúJustice,‚Äù he introduced himself quietly. ‚ÄúFormerly the partner of one of the bravest, most selfless heroes I have met.‚Äù A soft, melancholy pause. ‚ÄúAt your service.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat do you mean...?‚Äù ‚ÄúYou still burn with purpose. You have not lost yourself to despair or the wan comfort of deciding there is nothing more that can be done. You wish to enact justice. And I wish to help you.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù Lillian remembered him now. ‚ÄúHe... didn‚Äôt make it?‚Äù A deep, almost choked ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù A second passed. Misery threatened to overwhelm the fleeting moment, but was forced back down. ‚ÄúLikewise. I understand that I am not the only one who lost friends. Your commitment is not taken lightly.‚Äù A nod of acknowledgement. What was there to say? ‚ÄúMy plan is simple,‚Äù Justice declared with subdued conviction. ‚ÄúI will be your angel. We will journey to the wellspring. And you will destroy it.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù He seemed to notice where they were at this point. ‚ÄúYou were seeking out Serenity?‚Äù ‚ÄúI... wanted Aquamarine‚Äôs help,‚Äù she admitted, carefully storing his offer for the moment. ‚ÄúIt never made sense why no one ever asked the strongest hero to help. I - I‚Äôm pretty sure he could even stand up to Umber...‚Äù ‚ÄúHe likely could,‚Äù Justice agreed, hovering slightly higher as he considered. ‚ÄúBut Serenity herself is the problem. She has remained steadfastly neutral throughout the conflict - although at this point, neutrality itself is akin to choosing a side. It is certainly possible that Aquamarine simply has no knowledge of the state of things, if she never informed him. Perhaps, if he knew, he would be inclined to help. But without Serenity‚Äôs agreement, even this most powerful of vessels could hardly maintain his full strength for long.‚Äù ‚ÄúAre you saying to give up on him?‚Äù ‚Äã
8:50 PM
‚ÄúDestroying the wellspring does not require his aid; it instead requires discretion. It is possible that his belated entry into the fray would create a substantial distraction away from the upper world. But it is equally possible that it would simply draw attention to our attempt to intervene in some way, regardless of where. At the moment, Malice believes herself to be on the very cusp of victory - shaking that belief may cause more trouble than his aid would assist.‚Äù ‚ÄúHe could help me kill Umber.‚Äù ‚ÄúAh. Is that what this is about?‚Äù ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you dare tell me it doesn‚Äôt matter.‚Äù ‚ÄúI would never. But Umber is merely a pawn - he holds no special relevance in the grand scheme besides that of an enforcer. Defeating him would do nothing but raise the guard of our enemy.‚Äù ‚ÄúHe needs to pay for what he did. It‚Äôs about justice. Isn‚Äôt that your name? How can you say it doesn‚Äôt matter?‚Äù ‚ÄúI never declared such an objection. Merely that the current time is not the correct moment to proceed with such a path. Once the wellspring is drained and the conflict has concluded, justice will be served to the wicked. But to make such a deviation now would simply be irresponsible.‚Äù A breath; he considered Lillian‚Äôs expression. ‚ÄúDestroying the wellspring is the single greatest damage you could do to Malice‚Äôs cause - the true orchestrator of all the tragedy Umber has wrought. Do not fixate on the pawn when the queen believes herself invincible.‚Äù ‚Äú...‚Äù Several breaths. ‚ÄúWhat does ‚Äòdestroying the wellspring‚Äô even mean? What would I have to do?‚Äù ‚Äã
8:50 PM
Seemingly relieved that she had moved on, Justice finally did the one thing Lillian had never heard a celestial do before: he gave a straight, seemingly truthful answer. ‚ÄúBy binding yourself to me via the partner bond, I will be able to transport us both to the upper world. We will infiltrate the complex within which Malice conceals the wellspring. And then, as I cannot enter its subrealm due to its corrupting influence on my kind, I will provide you with as much energy as I can before you enter alone to release the energy in an explosive burst to destroy it and ultimately end this war.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou make it sound so easy.‚Äù ‚ÄúThere is no guarantee of success,‚Äù he admitted. ‚ÄúShould we be cornered by any of Malice‚Äôs lackeys, it is unlikely we would be able to defeat them.
